column3: India seen as case study for profound change in modernisation: Nadella
column4: Microsoft CEO, Satya Nadella, at an event said, India is seen as a case study for "profound change in modernisation". According to him, India has transformed the public infrastructure digitally and has formed the right public-private partnerships. Nadella also commended India on the development in technology. Besides this, Nadella discussed the role of AI in the post-COVID-19 world.

column3: Facebook didn't ban Bajrang Dal to protect business, staff: Report
column4: Facebook did not ban right-wing nationalist group Bajrang Dal following warnings by its security team that the move might endanger the company's business prospects and even lead to physical attacks on its staff in India, The Wall Street Journal (WSJ) reported. Facebook was also risking "infuriating ruling Hindu nationalist politicians", its internal security team warned.

column3: Google in talks with Jio, Airtel for providing internet via light
column4: Google is reportedly in talks to partner with Reliance Jio and Bharti Airtel for its Project Taara, which aims to provide internet connectivity through light beams. The project was started by a company within Google called Google X which works on breakthrough technologies. The project aims to provide internet to far-flung areas, at speeds of up to 20 Gbps.

column3: K'taka plant vandalism to have minor impact on iPhone production: Reports
column4: Apple's iPhone production will reportedly face a 'minor impact' due to vandalism and violence that took place on Saturday at its contract manufacturer Wistron’s facility near Bengaluru. Only the iPhone SE 2020 is being manufactured there and part of the production might shift if its factory remains affected, as per reports. Employees vandalised the plant due to non-payment of salaries.

column3: K'taka govt to provide protection to iPhone plant Wistron after vandalism
column4: Karnataka Minister for Large and Medium Scale Industries Jagadish Shettar on Saturday said that the state government will give necessary protection to iPhone manufacturer Wistron after violence broke out at the plant. The incident occurred over non-payment of salary dues for several months. Shettar added that it is not right for employees to take the law in their hands.

column3: Microsoft DirectX creator Eric Engstrom dies at 55
column4: Eric Engstrom, who played a key role in developing DirectX, a software that allowed for richer gaming experience and eventually led to the Xbox, has died aged 55. He died on December 1 from complications following an injury, The Wall Street Journal reported. Engstrom also contributed to the Windows Mobile and ads for Microsoft's online services.

column3: Apple may bring Touch ID back under upcoming iPhones' display: Report
column4: Apple's upcoming iPhone models could feature a Touch ID technology but not on a physical button, according to tipster John Prosser. He said Apple has two prototype iPhones under tests that have Touch ID under the display. However, this doesn't mean that the final product will also feature this technology.

column3: Musk asks Tesla staff to push output to max possible through Dec: Report
column4: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has sent an email to workers encouraging them to push output to the maximum possible through December, Bloomberg reported. "We are fortunate to have the high-class problem of demand being quite a bit higher than production this quarter," the report quoted Musk. The company has a target of delivering 5 lakh cars this year.

column3: Google, Facebook asked to respond on videos alleging Amul's cruelty to cows
column4: The Delhi High Court has asked Google and Facebook to respond to a plea filed by Amul seeking the removal of certain videos that accused Amul of cruelty towards cows. Amul has contended that the videos were "slanderous". The court didn't pass an ad interim injunction stating the videos being in public domain since 2018 as one of the reasons.

column3: Huawei tested AI tech to identify Uighur Muslims, alert police: Report
column4: Huawei tested an AI surveillance system that could identify China's Uighur minorities and send "Uighur alarms" to government authorities, the Washington Post reported. It used a facial recognition software to scan faces in a crowd and determine each person's age, sex and ethnicity. Huawei representatives refuted the allegations saying their "technologies aren't designed to identify ethnic groups".

column3: Need to classify social media platforms as news media: SC Judge
column4: Supreme Court Judge S Ravindra Bhat said there is a need to classify social media platforms as news media and subject them to same journalistic standards. He added the platforms can never be neutral. He even said the news disseminated on these platforms is not factual and fake news and planting bots have "triggered riots that leads to public mischief".

column3: Apple CFO, Apple's ex-design chief candidates for Ferrari CEO: Report
column4: Apple CFO Luca Maestri and former Chief Design Officer Jony Ive are reportedly candidates to be Ferrari's next CEO, Reuters reported. Ferrari CEO Louis Camilleri announced his retirement earlier due to "personal reasons". Former Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao was allegedly in the running for the position too, but Reuters said a source close to Colao has called the claim "groundless".

column3: Bug making iPhone users miss text notifications on iOS 14: Reports
column4: Several users have complained on Apple Community forums that they are not getting notifications for new text messages and iMessages after updating to iOS 14. The glitch is also causing some to miss notifications for apps like WhatsApp, reports said. The thread on the notification problems, which started in September, is at over 40 pages on Apple's support forums.

column3: My screen time was very high, had to cut down notifications: Apple CEO
column4: Apple CEO Tim Cook told Outside Podcast he had to take a "meat axe" to app notifications that were grabbing his attention in order to "free (him) up to do other things". Cook said his screen time was "very high" but didn't reveal the exact number of hours. He also said Apple didn't want people using their products too much.

column3: Rashid Khan pulls off catch after losing balance at boundary line, video goes viral
column4: Adelaide Strikers' Rashid Khan pulled off a catch at boundary line to dismiss Hobart Hurricanes' Colin Ingram. Ingram had slogged a length ball bowled by Adelaide Strikers captain Peter Siddle, after which Rashid caught it at wide long-on and lost his balance. Rashid threw the ball into the air, went beyond the boundary and came back to complete the catch.

column3: Melbourne Renegades get all out for 60, suffer biggest defeat in history of BBL
column4: Aaron Finch-led Melbourne Renegades got all out for just 60 runs in 10.4 overs while chasing down the target of 206 against Sydney Sixers in a Big Bash League match on Sunday. Melbourne Renegades' 145-run loss is the biggest defeat for a team in the entire history of Big Bash League. Further, their 60-run total is the second-lowest BBL total.

column3: 1st tied Test match was caused by direct hit off penultimate ball
column4: Australia needed one run off two balls with one wicket remaining when Windies' Joe Solomon's direct hit resulted in the first-ever tied Test. The match's last over, consisting of eight balls, involved a leg-bye, bye, caught behind, dropped catch and two run-outs. The first-ever tied Test ended on December 14, 1960, almost 84 years since the first Test in 1877.

column3: Gibbs resigns as Colombo Kings head coach mid-tournament as COVID-19 hits family
column4: Herschelle Gibbs has resigned as Colombo Kings' head coach in the middle of Lanka Premier League (LPL) 2020. Gibbs left for South Africa on Saturday night after tendering his resignation. He later tweeted, "Mom in hospital [due to COVID-19] reasons. Brother was also in hospital from COVID-19 and sister recovering from COVID-19...had to come back home."

column3: His legs are a blur when he runs: Mahindra shares video of 'fastest kid in the world'
column4: Mahindra Group Chairman Anand Mahindra tweeted a video about the 'fastest kid in the world', America's Rudolph Ingram. Mahindra wrote, "He’s like a machine. His legs are a blur when he runs. Undoubtedly, [he] will become the fastest man in the world." He added, "There must be such talent hidden in our country of 1.2 billion people...Keep your cellphones ready."

column3: Fastest pacer to 50 ODI wickets hit fastest ODI 50 for India
column4: Ajit Agarkar, who is the quickest fast bowler to reach 50 ODI wickets, slammed the fastest ODI fifty for India off 21 deliveries against Zimbabwe on December 14, 2000. Agarkar surpassed Kapil Dev, who had scored fifty off 22 balls on March 29, 1983, against Windies. Agarkar scored 67*(25) and took three wickets to help India win the match.

column3: Pakistani players just think about themselves: Kaneria on Pandya-Natarajan pic
column4: Former Pakistan spinner Danish Kaneria took to Twitter to share a picture of Team India cricketers Hardik Pandya and T Natarajan, wherein Pandya can be seen giving away his Man of the Series trophy to Natarajan. "Great pic...can't be better...Natarajan must be delighted and motivated," he wrote. "Have Pakistani players ever done it? They only think about themselves," he added.

column3: Ball hit my stomach, it made me angry: Pant on scoring 22 in 5 balls to hit ton
column4: India wicketkeeper-batsman Rishabh Pant revealed the reason why he went for his century in the last over of day's play against Australia A. "The first ball...hit...my stomach, it made me angry," he said. "That's when I said to myself, 'Now, I've to try going for...shots'," added Pant, who scored 22 runs off last five deliveries to get to his century.

column3: Faulkner jokingly dares Siddle to mankad as bowler warns him for leaving crease early
column4: During the 20th over of Hobart Hurricanes' innings, Adelaide Strikers captain Peter Siddle stopped in his run-up and warned non-striker batsman James Faulkner for leaving the crease early. Faulkner had almost started running to the striker's end. Reacting to the warning, Faulkner jokingly dared Siddle to mankad him after which the duo shared a laugh together.

column3: Drone delivers beer, snacks at Michael Jordan's golf course; videos surface
column4: Videos have surfaced showing beer and snacks being delivered to players via a drone on former professional basketball player Michael Jordan's golf course in Florida. Former tennis star Caroline Wozniacki also shared a video of drone delivering snacks. The golf course is named 'The Grove XXIII' after the number Jordan wore while leading the Chicago Bulls to six NBA titles.

column3: Starc's return will be huge for India pink ball Test: Josh Hazlewood
column4: On Australia pacer Mitchell Starc rejoining the team ahead of the first Test against India, teammate Josh Hazlewood said he's "huge part of Australia's team and attack". "Everyone knows his numbers with the pink ball. We welcome him with open arms," he added. Starc had opted out of the T20I series due to a family illness.

column3: He has got his form but hunger is alive: Aakash on Agarwal's 61-run knock
column4: Cricketer-turned-commentator Aakash Chopra has said that Mayank Agarwal's 61-run knock off the 120 balls in the second practice game will make him hungrier to play a big knock in the Test matches. "He gives me a lot of confidence. Mayank Agarwal is one of the most improved players in the last 12 months for Team India," he added.

column3: Test series can never be won by luck: Kuldeep on criticism of 2018-19 series win
column4: On experts questioning India's Test series win in Australia in 2018-19 in the absence of Steve Smith and David Warner, spinner Kuldeep Yadav said that a Test series cannot be won by "luck". "We won two of [the four Tests], and could have won the fourth one too had there been no rain. The criticism holds no merit," he added.

column3: Rahul deserves a chance, should bat at No. 6 in Tests : Brad Hogg
column4: Former Australia spinner Brad Hogg feels KL Rahul should be given another chance in the longer format after a disappointing Australia tour in 2018-19. "He is confident, he is raring to go, and I think he will be the perfect number 6 for India," Hogg said. He believes after Virat's departure Shubman Gill should bat at number 4 in Tests.

column3: Kuldeep can be India's game-changer with pink ball: Pragyan Ojha
column4: Ex-India spinner Pragyan Ojha has backed Kuldeep Yadav to be India's game-changer with the pink ball ahead of the Day-Night Test in Australia. "In domestic pink-ball tournaments, he was successful. Batsmen were finding it difficult to pick him. Especially during the twilight period, batsmen were struggling to read him," Ojha said. "That's when he picked up maximum wickets," he added.

column3: Umesh has been erratic at times, but he has the experience: Kaif
column4: Former India cricketer Mohammad Kaif has said that Team India should play Umesh Yadav as the third seamer in the first Test against Australia. "Umesh has been erratic at times but he has played 45-46 Test matches. He has the experience and has toured Australia previously," Kaif added. Umesh picked four wickets in the first practice match.

column3: Recovery going well: Jadeja in his training video ahead of Test series
column4: India all-rounder Ravindra Jadeja, who was ruled out of the T20I series after being hit on the helmet during the 1st T20I, said he is recovering well ahead of the first Test against Australia. Jadeja shared his training video on Twitter with the message- "Recovery going well #trainingmode". Jadeja didn't come out to field during the first T20I.

column3: Aus have Warner, Smith, Labuschagne this time: Tendulkar on Test series
column4: Talking about the upcoming India-Australia Test series, Sachin Tendulkar said that the hosts have got three "important players" this time from the last time they played India. "They have got David Warner who is back in the team, Steve Smith and Marnus Labuschagne," he stated. "This is a far better squad compared to the earlier one," he added.

column3: As far as captaincy is concerned, no pressure on Rahane: Gavaskar
column4: Ex-India captain Sunil Gavaskar said Ajinkya Rahane would be under no "real pressure" when he takes over the reins from Virat Kohli after the first test in Australia due to his 100% win record. "Both the times that he has led the team, he has won," Gavaskar said. Rahane captained India against Australia in 2017 and against Afghanistan in 2018.

column3: Pak captain Babar Azam ruled out of NZ T20I series with thumb fracture
column4: Captain Babar Azam was ruled out of Pakistan's three-match T20I series against New Zealand after fracturing his right thumb during Sunday's practice session. According to Pakistan Cricket Board, Azam won't be able to attend practice for minimum 12 days. "We have a long season of cricket ahead...we now hope he regains complete fitness as early as possible," coach Misbah said.

column3: Sledging is overrated and irrelevant: Cheteshwar Pujara
column4: Ahead of the four-match Test series against Australia, India batsman Cheteshwar Pujara described sledging to be 'overrated' and 'irrelevant'. "I don't think you can win too many battles with sledging. I don't even know what they are saying when I am in my zone," Pujara said. In 2018-19, Pujara played over 1000 deliveries during the four-match Test series against Australia.

column3: People would name Rahul, but my pick is Shubman for no. 6 spot: Agarkar
column4: Ex-India pacer Ajit Agarkar has said that Shubman Gill should bat at number six position after the Adelaide Test. "I don't see any better options at this point [for number six spot]. People could point to KL Rahul and his white-ball form but if I had to pick, I'll go with Shubman Gill [for it]," he stated.

column3: Shane Warne picks his Australia XI for the pink ball Test vs India
column4: Ex-Australia leg-spinner Shane Warne has picked his country's playing XI for the first Test match against India. Warne picked Matthew Wade and Marcus Harris as openers with Marnus Labuschagne, Steve Smith and Travis Head at number three, four and five respectively. Warne included Cameron Green and picked Mitchell Starc, Pat Cummins, Josh Hazlewood, and Nathan Lyon as the bowling unit.

column3: Aus should make Smith vice-captain immediately: Gilchrist
column4: Ex-Australia wicketkeeper-batsman Adam Gilchrist has said that he sees no reason why Steve Smith shouldn't be given second chance regarding captaincy. "If the selectors feel [Smith is the right guy] and he's [also] keen to do it, I think they should make him vice-captain immediately," he stated. Smith was banned from captaincy for 24 months over the sandpaper scandal.

column3: Moises Henriques added to Australia's squad for first Test vs India
column4: All-rounder Moises Henriques has been added to Australia's squad for the first Test against India as injury woes continue in Australian camp. Henriques comes in for Will Pucovski, who was ruled out of the first Test after he was hit on the helmet by a bouncer during the first tour match last week. Henriques last played a Test in 2016.

column3: Three snow leopards test positive for coronavirus
column4: Three snow leopards, two males and a female, have tested COVID-19 positive at Louisville Zoo, the zoo and US Department of Agriculture's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service confirmed on Friday. The leopards, whose symptoms are mild and include wheezes and dry coughs, are expected to fully recover, zoo officials said. They were likely infected by an asymptomatic staff member.

column3: Mahatma Gandhi's statue outside Indian Embassy in US desecrated during protest
column4: The statue of Mahatma Gandhi outside Indian Embassy in Washington DC was desecrated on Saturday during a protest organised in support of farmers against farm laws. A Khalistan flag was draped over the statue. "The Embassy strongly condemns this mischievous act by hooligans masquerading as protesters against the universally respected icon of peace and justice," it said in a statement.

column3: Drone converted into flying flamethrower to destroy 100 wasp nests in China
column4: A drone has been converted into a flying flamethrower by a volunteer group to destroy 100 wasp nests in China's Zhong county. The volunteer group raised 80,000 yuan (over ₹9 lakh) to buy the drone and fit it with a gasoline tank and an arm-length nozzle. "Now we don't have to worry about being stung," a resident said.

column3: US politician tweets about being 'sexually harassed for years' by NY Governor
column4: A US politician has claimed New York Governor Andrew Cuomo "sexually harassed her for years" while she worked in his administration, saying, "Many saw it, and watched." "And I know I'm not the only woman. I hate that some men, like Cuomo abuse their power," Lindsey Boylan tweeted. "I'm angry to be put in this situation at all," Boylan wrote.

column3: Pics of Nordic prison cells go viral, social media users compare them to apartments
column4: Several pictures of Nordic prison cells have gone viral on social media. Reacting to the pictures, a user tweeted, "Nordic prison cells look like $3,000 apartments in San Francisco." Meanwhile, another user wrote, "This is nicer than my college dorm room." A tweet read, "I have paid for hotel rooms in Stockholm that are less comfortable than that."

column3: 400 students missing after bandits armed with rifles attack school in Nigeria
column4: Hundreds of students are missing after bandits armed with assault rifles attacked a school in Nigeria's Katsina state on Friday, police said. Parents and security personnel gathered to search for roughly half of the school's 800 students, one parent and a school employee told Reuters. One police officer was shot and wounded in the attack.

column3: WWII grenade that UK mom & daughter thought to be fossil explodes in kitchen sink
column4: A World War II grenade that mother-daughter Jodie Crews and Isabella from UK's Kent found on the beach exploded in their kitchen sink. They initially thought it was fossil or bone. "It was an eroded WW2 grenade, which when poked with...hot needle turned into...ball of fire! Had to save animals and house," Jodie wrote on Facebook while sharing photos.

column3: Man hops fence and climbs onto wing of airplane preparing to takeoff in US
column4: A man was taken into custody after he climbed onto the wing of an Alaska Airlines plane at the Las Vegas airport on Saturday. The flight from Las Vegas to Portland was preparing for takeoff from McCarran International Airport when the pilot noticed the man coming toward the aircraft and notified control tower. The man had hopped a perimeter fence.

column3: Gold, silver jewellery washes up on beach in Venezuela; pics surface
column4: Gold and silver jewellery, ornaments, and golden nuggets have washed up on a beach in Venezuela's Guaca. Dozens of villagers said they had found at least one precious object, with unconfirmed reports that some had sold their discoveries for as much as $1,500. "I began to shake...It was the first time something special has happened to me," a fisherman said.

column3: Afghan Taliban head bought life insurance in Pak before dying in US strike: Report
column4: Afghan Taliban chief Mullah Akhtar Mansour purchased a life insurance policy using a fake identity in Pakistan and paid 3 lakh in Pakistani rupees in premium before being killed in a US drone attack, according to media report. Mansour, who was killed in a US drone strike along the Pakistan-Iran border in 2016, assumed the leadership of Taliban in 2015.

column3: US expects to immunise 10 cr against COVID-19 by March: Official
column4: The US expects to have immunised 10 crore people with the coronavirus vaccine by the end of March, Moncef Slaoui, the country's COVID-19 vaccine programme head said. Four crore doses of vaccine will be distributed by the end of December and another 10 crore to 16 crore doses will be delivered in January and February, he added.

column3: Presidential transition complicating vaccine distribution: Gates
column4: Microsoft Co-founder Bill Gates on Sunday said the transition of presidential administrations "is complicating" the COVID-19 vaccine distribution process. He added that he was "pleased" with the Biden administration, since it is "willing to rely on actual experts and not attack those experts". "I think we'll get through this in a positive way," Gates said.

column3: Spain could develop 'COVID-19 herd immunity' by end of summer 2021
column4: Spain's Health Minister Salvador Illa said that the country's population should achieve herd immunity from COVID-19 by the end of summer 2021 if enough people are vaccinated by then. A vaccination programme will start in January, he added. By the end of summer 2021, more than two-thirds of the population of over 4.7 crore should be vaccinated, Illa further said.

column3: First shipments of Pfizer COVID-19 vaccine to arrive in US on Monday
column4: First shipments of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine will start arriving in USA on Monday, General Gustave Perna, Head of President Donald Trump-led administration's Operation Warp Speed said. Shipments will move from Pfizer facilities to UPS and FedEx hubs on Sunday before going out to 636 locations nationwide. "We expect 145 sites across all states to receive vaccine on Monday," Perna added.

column3: Trump supporters protest in support of his election fraud claims
column4: US President Donald Trump's supporters on Saturday protested across the country against his loss in the presidential election. The protesters have supported Trump's allegations that there was voter fraud in the election. Violence was reported at some of the rallies with one being shot and four others being stabbed, according to AFP.

column3: Germany to impose lockdown to curb COVID-19 spread from Dec 16
column4: Germany will go into a lockdown from December 16 to January 10 to curb the spread of coronavirus, German Chancellor Angela Merkel said. "I would've wished for lighter measures. But due to Christmas shopping, the number of social contacts has risen considerably. There's an urgent need to take action," she added. Only essential shops will remain open from December 16.

column3: We 'inadvertently' limited engagement on Trump's flagged tweets: Twitter
column4: After The Verge reported that some users on Twitter were unable to like, reply or retweet US President Donald Trump's tweets, Twitter said it "inadvertently" limited engagements on his tweets that were labelled as "disputed" for a brief period of time but later reversed its action. A Twitter spokesperson said Twitter will continue to label tweets that violate its policies.

column3: Farmers' voices must be heard: Indian-American lawmaker on protests
column4: Speaking on the farmers' protest in India, Indian-American Congressman Ro Khanna has said that farmers are the backbone of India and must have their voices heard. "I hope there's a...fair solution so they can provide for their families. I'm encouraged by the ongoing dialogue," he added. "India and the US share a rich tradition of...peaceful protests," he further said.

column3: Explosion in Rawalpindi market leaves 25 injured
column4: At least 25 people were injured in an explosion near a police station in a market in Pakistan's Rawalpindi city on Sunday, officials said. Initial reports suggested that it was a hand grenade attack but a police official said it was too soon to ascertain the nature of the blast. The affected area in the market has been cordoned off.

column3: 4 killed in recent clashes in Nagorno-Karabakh region: Azerbaijan
column4: Azerbaijan's Defence Ministry on Sunday said that four Azeri servicemen were killed in recent weeks in clashes in the disputed region of Nagorno-Karabakh. It is the first report of casualties since a Russian-brokered ceasefire accord took effect on November 10. Separately, Armenia said that six of their servicemen had been wounded in an Azeri military offensive but didn't say when.

column3: Britain readies navy to protect fishing waters in case of no-deal Brexit
column4: Four Royal Navy patrol ships will be ready on January 1 to help protect Britain's fishing waters in the event of a no-deal Brexit, the country's Ministry of Defence said. Conservative MP Tobias Ellwood described the threat of using Royal Navy gunboats as "irresponsible". Earlier, PM Boris Johnson and the European Union said a no-deal outcome looked very likely.

column3: Israel and Bhutan establish formal diplomatic relations
column4: Israel and Bhutan on Saturday established formal diplomatic relations to "build upon the existing close ties" and "open the path to greater cooperation". The agreement follows several years of secret contacts between the two countries with the aim of establishing relations, Israeli Foreign Minister Gabi Ashkenazi said. "This is a milestone in Israel's deepening ties with Asia," he added.

column3: We shouldn't go back to business as usual with Iran: Israeli PM
column4: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu said, "As long as Iran continues to subjugate and threaten its neighbours...we shouldn't go back to business as usual with Iran." Netanyahu's comment is reportedly aimed at US President-elect Joe Biden, who has said the US will rejoin the nuclear deal if Iran agrees to strict adherence. Netanyahu accused Iran of funding and training terrorist organisations.

column3: Maharaja Ranjit Singh's statue at Lahore Fort vandalised
column4: The statue of 19th-century Sikh ruler Maharaja Ranjit Singh has been vandalised for the second time since its unveiling in 2019 at the Lahore Fort, officials said. The security guards at the fort detained a teenage boy for the vandalism and handed him over to police, an official said. The accused claimed his "religious sentiments" were hurt seeing the statue.

column3: UK praises 'incredible things' being done by India in solar energy sector
column4: British Prime Minister, Boris Johnson, in his speech at climate summit hailed the "incredible things" being done by India in the solar energy sector. He reiterated the UK's pledge to radically cut dependence on fossil fuels. "We're going ahead with...massive solar programme...though we can't hope to emulate the incredible things being done by India...for instance," he added.

column3: Bharatiya Tribal Party withdraws support to Gehlot-led Raj govt: Party leader
column4: Bharatiya Tribal Party (BTP) has withdrawn its support to the Ashok Gehlot-led government in Rajasthan, party leader Chhotubhai Vasava announced on Friday. Two MLAs of the party had supported the Congress government during the trust vote earlier this year. This comes after BJP won more seats than Congress in the recent Zila and Panchayat polls in the state.

column3: I'll observe 1-day fast in support of farmers, urge public to fast too: Delhi CM
column4: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday said that he would be observing a one-day fast on Monday in support of the farmers protesting against the new farm laws. He also appealed to AAP workers and supporters and the public to observe the fast as well. Earlier, he had visited the Singhu Border to show his support to the farmers.

column3: BJP leaders sitting on strike broke CCTV cameras at Delhi CM's house: CMO
column4: BJP leaders sitting on strike in front of Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal's residence broke CCTV cameras installed at his house, CMO said on Sunday. This comes as Mayors of Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD) and leaders continue their demonstration outside the CM's residence, demanding MCD's due of ₹13,000 crore from the Delhi government.

column3: 6 AAP MLAs including Raghav, Atishi detained outside Amit Shah & L-G's houses
column4: Delhi Police on Sunday detained six AAP MLAs, including Raghav Chadha and Atishi, as they allegedly tried to hold a protest near Home Minister Amit Shah and Delhi Lieutenant Governor Anil Baijal's residences respectively. This comes a day after AAP alleged misappropriation of funds by BJP-ruled municipal corporations. The party has sought CBI probe into the matter.

column3: BJP President JP Nadda tests positive for coronavirus, goes into home-isolation
column4: BJP National President JP Nadda on Sunday announced that he has tested positive for coronavirus. "My health is fine, and I'm following all the guidelines of home-isolation on the advice of doctors. Whoever has come in contact with me in the last few days, I request them to isolate themselves and get themselves checked," he tweeted.

column3: Congress wins 620 seats in municipal body polls in Rajasthan
column4: Congress won 620 seats in the polls for the 50 municipal bodies in Rajasthan. The State Election Commission on Sunday released the results of the general election. Out of 1,775 wards of all the bodies, 620 candidates of Congress, 548 of BJP, seven of BSP, two each of CPI and CPI (M), one of RLP and 595 Independent candidates won.

column3: Detractors in Congress denied Sharad Pawar PM post twice: Praful Patel
column4: On two occasions NCP chief Sharad Pawar had opportunity to become PM but was denied the post by his detractors in Congress, said NCP's Praful Patel. "After Rajiv Gandhi's unfortunate death...There was a demand to make Pawar party president...but some drawing room politicians conspired to block this," said Patel. "They didn't want strong leadership for the party," he added.

column3: NCP dismisses reports of Sharad Pawar replacing Sonia as UPA chief
column4: The Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) on Thursday dismissed reports of party chief Sharad Pawar replacing Congress President Sonia Gandhi as the chairperson of the United Progressive Alliance (UPA). "The reports appearing in the media seem to have been planted with vested interest to divert the attention from the ongoing farmers' agitation," NCP chief spokesperson Mahesh Tapase said.

column3: BJP may try to kill CM Mamata if it can't win against her: Bengal Minister
column4: West Bengal Minister and TMC leader Subrata Mukherjee said during a rally that if BJP fails to win the upcoming elections against CM Mamata Banerjee, it "may conspire to assassinate her by sending people secretly". Mukherjee had earlier blamed BJP workers for the attack on the saffron party's chief JP Nadda's convoy during his visit to the state.

column3: India being tested, will meet the challenge: EAM on China standoff
column4: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar has said India was being tested in the seven-month-long border standoff with China in eastern Ladakh. He also added that he was confident that India would meet the national security challenge. He further added that what happened in eastern Ladakh was not actually in China's interest as it has significantly impacted public sentiment in India.

column3: Shah said govt can't buy all crops at MSP: Bhartiya Kisan Union chief
column4: Bhartiya Kisan Union (Haryana) President Gurnam Singh Chaduni has said that the Centre was misleading on minimum support price (MSP). He added Home Minister Amit Shah said the government cannot buy all 23 crops at MSP as it would cost ₹17 lakh crore. Chaduni said that the Centre would continue to buy the crops at the same amount as before.

column3: Senior Raj leader Ghanshyam Tiwari returns to BJP 2 years after quitting
column4: Senior Rajasthan leader Ghanshyam Tiwari returned to BJP on Saturday, two years after he quit the party over differences with former CM Vasundhara Raje. Tiwari, who had floated his own outfit Bharat Vahini Party before 2018 Assembly elections, was seen sharing the stage at a rally with Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot and Congress leader Rahul Gandhi before 2019 general elections.

column3: Assam's BTC poll results show people's faith in PM's leadership: Nadda
column4: BJP President JP Nadda said that Assam's Bodoland Territorial Council (BTC) poll results show people's faith in leadership and policies of PM Narendra Modi. He also congratulated NDA partner UPPL, Assam CM Sarbananda Sonowal and other state BJP leaders for "securing clear majority". While BJP has won nine seats, UPPL has won 12 seats in the polls.

column3: Sonia was unable to handle party affairs after I became Prez: Mukherjee in book
column4: The late Pranab Mukherjee wrote in his memoir that Congress' leadership lost political focus after he became India's President, "While Sonia Gandhi was unable to handle the affairs of the party, Dr (Manmohan) Singh's prolonged absence from the House put an end to any personal contact with other MPs," he wrote. Mukherjee added Singh was "preoccupied with saving the coalition".

column3: We will never forget cowardly attack on Parliament in 2001: PM Modi
column4: PM Narendra Modi on Sunday said the country will never forget the "cowardly attack on our Parliament" in 2001 and paid tributes to security personnel who sacrificed their lives in the attack. The Parliament was adjourned at the time of the attack, but several parliamentarians and staff were present inside the building. All five terrorists were killed outside the building.

column3: Why new Parliament building when half of India hungry?: Haasan to PM Modi
column4: Actor-turned-politician Kamal Haasan on Sunday asked why a new Parliament building was being constructed at a cost of about ₹1,000 crore 'when half of India is starving due to loss of livelihood due to coronavirus'. To protect whom is the new Parliament building being constructed, Haasan asked, adding, "Please respond, my honourable elected Prime Minister."

column3: Dy Election Commissioner to pay 2-day visit to Bengal from Dec 17
column4: Deputy Election Commissioner Sudeep Jain will pay a two-day visit to West Bengal on December 17 and 18. As per reports, Jain will review the preparedness for the polls and meet various state officials and District Magistrates, during his visit. West Bengal is scheduled to go for the Assembly elections next year.

column3: BJP-ruled MCDs hiked 11 taxes in past 3 days: AAP's Durgesh Pathak
column4: Senior AAP leader Durgesh Pathak on Thursday alleged that Delhi's three municipal corporations (MCD), ruled by BJP, have increased around 11 different taxes over the past three days. Pathak added that AAP will soon start a campaign to apprise people about these "inhumane acts". However, North MCD Mayor said the civic bodies haven't hiked any taxes, owing to the pandemic.

column3: Bengal govt will have to answer: Shah on attack on Nadda’s convoy
column4: Union Home Minister Amit Shah on Thursday, while reacting to the alleged attack on the convoy of BJP chief JP Nadda in West Bengal, said, "Bengal government will have to answer to the...people of the state for this sponsored violence." "However much we condemn this incident, it is less. The central government is taking this attack very seriously," Shah added.

column3: Pawar sought amendment to farm law for farmers' benefit: Sanjay Raut
column4: Shiv Sena leader Sanjay Raut on Sunday defended NCP chief Sharad Pawar for urging states to amend the APMC Act when he was the Union Agriculture Minister. Raut, in Sena mouthpiece Saamana, wrote, "Ten years ago when Sharad Pawar sought reforms in the agricultural sector it was in the interest of the farmers. Then Ambani-Adani had not entered this field."

column3: Bangladeshis settling in Bengal, natives being driven out: Nadda
column4: BJP president JP Nadda, who is on a two-day tour of West Bengal, said on Thursday, "People from Bangladesh are coming here and settling, while the natives of West Bengal are being driven out of the state by the TMC." "One of the most corrupt governments is being run here. It's a government of 'chaal chor' (rice thieves)," Nadda added.

column3: Nadda accompanied by BJP leader involved in 55 criminal cases: TMC MP
column4: Commenting on the attack on BJP National President JP Nadda's convoy in West Bengal on Thursday, Trinamool Congress MP Kalyan Banerjee said that Nadda was accompanied by "criminal and armed men" of BJP. "BJP leader Rakesh Singh was in a convoy...he has 55 criminal cases against him," Banerjee added. Singh made "provocative" gestures at the crowd, he stated.

column3: Sushil Kumar Modi takes oath as Rajya Sabha member from Bihar
column4: Former Bihar Deputy CM and senior BJP leader Sushil Kumar Modi on Saturday took oath as a Rajya Sabha member from Bihar. The oath was administered to him by Vice President and Chairman of the Rajya Sabha M Venkaiah Naidu in the Parliament House. Sushil Modi was on Monday declared elected unopposed to the Rajya Sabha.

column3: BJP workers attack one another, blame TMC: Mamata on attack on Nadda
column4: West Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee has alleged that BJP workers are attacking fellow activists and "blaming it on the Trinamool Congress". "At times Home Minister is here, other times Chadda, Nadda, Fadda, Bhadda is here...they create a drama and claim they got thrashed," she added. Her comments came after BJP President JP Nadda's convoy was attacked in West Bengal.

column3: AAP to stage protest outside Delhi L-G, Amit Shah's homes tomorrow
column4: AAP leader Atishi Marlena on Saturday announced that councillors and MLAs of AAP will stage a sit-in in front of homes of Delhi Lieutenant Governor Anil Baijal and Union Home Minister Amit Shah on Sunday. She said that members will sit there till they get consent for CBI enquiry into the alleged misappropriation of ₹2,500 crore funds in North MCD.

column3: Pak actress Mahira tests COVID-19 +ve, says 'It has been rough'
column4: Pakistani actress Mahira Khan took to Instagram on Sunday to share that she has tested positive for coronavirus. "I'm isolating and have also informed all those who were in contact with me over the last few days. It's been rough but it will be ok soon, Inshallah," she wrote. "PS Prayers and movie recommendations are more than welcome," Mahira added.

column3: Lucky Ali sings 'O Sanam' during impromptu gig in Goa, Nafisa Ali shares video
column4: A video, shared by actress Nafisa Ali Sodhi on social media, shows Lucky Ali singing 'O Sanam' in an impromptu gig. "Lucky Ali at Arambol in North Goa after listening to the musical evening was requested for a song and he sang impromptu for all present. Was a lovely setting," she wrote. "The audience is so lucky," a user commented.

column3: Stent placed inside Remo's body after heart attack, he's stable now: Taurani
column4: 'Race 3' producer Ramesh Taurani, while speaking to Times of India about choreographer-director Remo D'souza's health, said, "I spoke to Remo's wife. A stent (a metal mesh tube inserted in surgical procedures to make blood flow freely in blocked coronary arteries) has been put." "He's stable now," Taurani added. Remo had suffered a heart attack and was hospitalised on Friday.

column3: Juhi Chawla loses her diamond earring at Mumbai airport, asks for help on Twitter
column4: Actress Juhi Chawla took to Twitter to seek help in finding her diamond earring she lost at the Mumbai airport today morning. Sharing a picture, Juhi wrote, "This is the matching piece, I have worn these earrings almost everyday for the past 15 years. Please help me find it." She added that she would reward the person who will help.

column3: Alcohol found in actress Arya Banerjee's stomach, death not a case of homicide
column4: The post-mortem report of 'The Dirty Picture' actress Arya Banerjee has confirmed that her death was not a case of homicide. Kolkata Police Joint Commissioner (crime) Murli Dhar Sharma said she was suffering from cirrhosis of liver. "It was not a case of homicide. Alcohol was found in her stomach at the time of her death," he stated.

column3: Maid steals items worth ₹1.31cr from Boman Irani's cousin's B'luru home
column4: Bengaluru Police have arrested a mother-son duo who allegedly stole cash and gold ornaments worth ₹1.31 crore from actor Boman Irani's cousin's house in Halasuru. According to the complaint made by Khursheed Irani, several gold biscuits, ₹85 lakh cash and $15,000 (₹11 lakh) were stolen. The woman worked in Irani's house as house help for over 20 years.

column3: Mithun was instrumental in my 'jinxed' tag getting wiped out: Shirodkar
column4: Actress Shilpa Shirodkar spoke about facing struggles during the initial phase of her acting career and revealed that she was titled 'jinxed' after several of her projects did not get released. "Mithun [Chakraborty]...was instrumental in my jinxed tag getting wiped out," she said. Following the initial struggle, Shilpa did several films with Mithun, including 'Rangbaaz' and 'Apne Dam Par'.

column3: LaBeouf conned me into a relationship claiming to be single: Sia
column4: After British singer FKA twigs filed a lawsuit against actor Shia LaBeouf, accusing him of physical and emotional abuse, Australian singer Sia defended her claims. "I too have been hurt emotionally by Shia, a pathological liar, who conned me into an adulterous relationship claiming to be single," Sia tweeted. She further wrote, "If you love yourself, stay safe, stay away".

column3: I had an incredible 10-year run: Robert on playing Iron Man
column4: Actor Robert Downey Jr, who played Iron Man in the Marvel films for over a decade, said, "Playing...Iron Man was hard and I dug deep. I had an incredible 10-year run that was creatively satisfying." Commenting on ending his stint with 'Avengers: Endgame', he said, "I've done all I could with that character and can do other things now."

column3: Jaimie Alexander to reprise role in 'Thor: Love And Thunder': Reports
column4: Actress Jaimie Alexander will reprise her role of Sif, the Asgardian warrior and childhood friend of Chris Hemsworth's character 'Thor', in Marvel's upcoming film 'Thor: Love And Thunder', Deadline reported. The actress made her first appearance as Sif in 2011's 'Thor' and reprised the role in the 2013 sequel 'Thor: The Dark World'.

column3: It's a blessing that everything worked for me in 2020: Amit Sadh
column4: Actor Amit Sadh, who starred in projects like 'Breathe: Into The Shadows', 'Shakuntala Devi' and 'Yaara' earlier this year, said that it's a blessing that everything worked for him in 2020. "It's been special due to what the fans have given me. They connected with me," he said. The actor added that he wants to portray more challenging roles.

column3: Ajay Devgn's 'Maidaan' release date pushed to October 15
column4: Ajay Devgn's upcoming film 'Maidaan', which was previously scheduled to release on August 13, 2021, will now release on October 15, he announced on social media. "'Maidaan' now releases worldwide in theatres on Dussehra 2021. Shoot commences January 2021," Ajay tweeted. Reportedly, the film is a sports-drama, in which Ajay will play the role of football coach Syed Abdul Rahim.

column3: Katrina, Ishaan, Siddhant starrer 'Phone Bhoot' goes on floors
column4: Filmmaker Gurmmeet Singh's upcoming movie 'Phone Bhoot', starring Katrina Kaif, Ishaan Khatter and Siddhant Chaturvedi, began filming on Saturday. "It is going to be a Fa-boo-less first day! I can feel it in my bones. Phone Bhoot starts today," producer Ritesh Sidhwani wrote on Instagram alongside a picture of a clapboard from the film's set.

column3: No such project in pipeline: Madhavan on rumour of doing Ratan Tata's biopic
column4: When a fan took to Twitter to ask R Madhavan if he will play the lead role in Ratan Tata's biopic and shared a poster of the same, Madhavan clarified that it was a fan-made poster. "No such project is even on the pipeline or being discussed," Madhavan tweeted. He will next star in the biopic-drama 'Rocketry: The Nambi Effect'.

column3: I wished I could post pictures showing off my biceps like people do: Anil
column4: In his latest Instagram post, actor Anil Kapoor shared pictures of himself and admitted that he always wanted to "show off" his biceps on social media. "We all dream of someday...I just always wished that someday I could also post pictures showing off my biceps and triceps like people do...well today is that someday! Celebrating the small victories," he wrote.

column3: He has a lot of swag: Pulkit Samrat on Bigg Boss 14's Eijaz Khan
column4: Speaking about television actor and Bigg Boss 14's contestant Eijaz Khan, actor Pulkit Samrat said, "I've been fond of Eijaz's work since my television days. He has a lot of swag and I used to be jealous of it." He further said, "His presence is very charismatic and I wish him all the best."

column3: Varun starrer 'Ekkis' is not shelved, shoot to begin in Sept: Sriram
column4: Filmmaker Sriram Raghavan denied the speculations about his upcoming Varun Dhawan starrer film 'Ekkis' getting shelved and stated that they will start shooting for the biopic in September 2021. "We were supposed to shoot in September this year...But...Ekkis has been pushed forward to next year. I need specific weather in September-October to shoot in battle locations," he explained.

column3: Country music star Charley Pride passes away at the age of 86
column4: Charley Pride, the country music star who gathered more than 50 top-10 hits between 1967 and 1987 and won several Grammy Awards, passed away at the age of 86. According to Fox News, the musician's publicist stated that the cause of his death was complications from COVID-19. Pride's popular songs included 'Kiss an Angel Good Mornin' and 'Mountain of Love'.

column3: Abhishek to team up with Dinesh Vijan and Tushar Jalota for a film
column4: Actor Abhishek Bachchan will team up with producer Dinesh Vijan and debutant director Tushar Jalota for an upcoming film. "I'm really looking forward to working with both Dinesh Vijan and Tushar Jalota," Abhishek said. Dinesh has previously worked with actors like Irrfan Khan and Sushant Singh Rajput and Tushar served as an associate director on films 'Ram Leela' and 'Padmaavat'.

column3: She's 65 years young now: Prateik on mother Smita's death anniversary
column4: Actor Prateik Babbar shared a post on Instagram to mark his mother Smita Patil's 34th death anniversary and called her "perfect mother, woman, role model". "Every year she grows younger...she's 65 years young now. She will continue to live with me, within me, to infinity and beyond. My beautiful mama queen," he wrote alongside the late actress' picture.

column3: Bhiku Mhatre has given me a career: Manoj on his character in 'Satya'
column4: Actor Manoj Bajpayee, who played gangster Bhiku Mhatre in the 1998 Ram Gopal Varma directorial 'Satya', said the character gave him a career in the film industry. "I feel lucky that I was blessed with that kind of a role which changed a lot of things for me...people still remember Bhiku Mhatre with so much fondness," he added.

column3: Beyoncé's 8-yr-old daughter added to 'Brown Skin Girl' Grammy nomination
column4: Blue Ivy Carter, the 8-year-old daughter of Beyoncé and Jay-Z, has been nominated in the 'Best Music Video' category at the 2021 Grammy Awards for her role in the song 'Brown Skin Girl' alongside her mother. Blue wasn't listed in the category when the nominations were originally announced in November and was added to the list on Friday.

column3: I used to stammer, acting was a far away thing for me: Sharad
column4: Actor Sharad Kelkar, who recently starred in 'Laxmii', commented on facing rejections and said, "I used to stammer, so acting was a faraway thing for me... rejections were [there]." Stating that the rejection made him stronger, the actor added, "Stammering was a problem so I got rid of that. It took me two years to get rid of stammering."

column3: Have a soft spot for 'The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift': Nolan
column4: During a recent interview, filmmaker Christopher Nolan mentioned that he is a fan of the 'Fast and Furious' movies and added, "I've got a very soft spot for Tokyo Drift." Further speaking about the franchise on the Happy Sad Confused podcast, Nolan said, "Everyone always complains that sequels get bigger but we're the people making sequels get bigger."

column3: Own a car without buying it : Revv Subscriptions
column4: You can now drive a new car every month as Revv provides the option to subscribe to your favourite car for 1-36 months with ₹0 down payment, ₹0 road tax and without the hassle of maintenance and service. The car will be sanitized and delivered to your doorstep ensuring complete safety for you and your loved ones.

column3: Musk passes Gates as world's 2nd richest, gets $100bn richer in 2020
column4: Tesla CEO Elon Musk passed Bill Gates to become the world's second-richest person after his net worth soared $7.2 billion to $127.9 billion on Monday, according to Bloomberg. The 49-year-old has added $100.3 billion to his fortune this year. Gates, who has donated $27 billion to his foundation since 2006, has a net worth of $127.7 billion.

column3: Tesla's market value crosses $500 bn as shares surge six-fold this year
column4: Tesla Inc crossed $500 billion in market value on Tuesday as its share price surged six-fold this year. Tesla's shares rose as much as 3.9% to a record high of $542.35 in early trading. CEO Elon Musk has added $100.3 billion to his net worth so far this year, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

column3: Tesla asked to give ₹1 cr to used car buyer for hiding damage in China
column4: Tesla was ordered by a Chinese court to pay over ₹1 crore to the buyer of a used Model S car after concluding it concealed structural damage on the vehicle it sold on its official website. It was reportedly discovered part of the vehicle had been cut and welded back together. Tesla will appeal the ruling to a higher court.

column3: Battery-operated bikes to be included in Delhi's EV policy: Report
column4: Delhi's EV policy is being revised to include a segment on battery-operated bicycles and tricycles, HT reported. The government has drafted a proposal to offer monetary incentives on their purchase. The proposed revision includes cycles both in the passenger and cargo categories. In case of individual buyers, purchase incentive will be 25% of the MRP with a cap of ₹5,000.

column3: US govt opens probe into 1.15L Tesla vehicles over suspension issue
column4: The US NHTSA opened an investigation into around 1.15 lakh Tesla vehicles over a front suspension safety issue. It said it was opening a preliminary evaluation into 2015-2017 Model S and 2016-2017 Model X vehicles after receiving 43 complaints alleging failure of the left or right front suspension fore links. "The complaints appear to indicate an increasing trend," NHTSA said.

column3: Tesla reveals women comprise 17% of its total US leadership roles
column4: Tesla revealed in its first-ever US diversity report that women comprise 17% of the company's leadership roles and 21% of the overall workforce. It added that Black people make up 4% of its US leadership roles and 10% of its total workforce. "While women are historically underrepresented...we recognise we have work to do in this area," Tesla said.

column3: US startup claims to have made 1st 'no charging' solar EV
column4: US-based Aptera Motors has introduced the "first solar electric vehicle" that requires "no charging" for most daily use and has a range of up to over 1,600 kilometres per full charge. Every Aptera is designed to harvest enough sunlight to travel over 17,702 kilometres per year in most regions. Liquid-cooled electric motors propel Aptera from 0-100 kilometres/hour in 3.5 seconds.

column3: Baidu becomes 1st to get fully driverless road tests permit in Beijing
column4: Baidu has become the first to receive permits by the Beijing transportation authorities for five of its vehicles to conduct fully driverless road tests. It plans to remove safety drivers from test vehicles after gradually reducing human intervention. However, a remote safety operator will still be able to take control in an emergency via Baidu's 5G Remote Driving Service.

column3: Govt to set up 69,000 EV charging points across India: Gadkari
column4: Road Transport and Highways Minister Nitin Gadkari said the government is planning to set up at least one e-charging kiosk at around 69,000 petrol pumps across the country to induce people to go for electric vehicles (EVs). Gadkari had asked industry stakeholders to work towards making India an EV hub by 2025. GST on EVs has been reduced to 5%.

column3: Musk asks Tesla staff to push output to max possible through Dec: Report
column4: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has sent an email to workers encouraging them to push output to the maximum possible through December, Bloomberg reported. "We are fortunate to have the high-class problem of demand being quite a bit higher than production this quarter," the report quoted Musk. The company has a target of delivering 5 lakh cars this year.

column3: General Motors to not acquire 11% stake in Nikola
column4: General Motors (GM) and Nikola on Monday announced a reworked deal that replaced their previous agreement under which GM would acquire 11% equity stake in the startup and produce the proposed electric pickup Badger. The companies have instead signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding which is subject to negotiation. Nikola was previously accused of fraud by a short seller.

column3: Apple moves self-driving car unit under exec who oversees Siri: Report
column4: Apple has moved its self-driving car unit under the leadership of John Giannandrea, Senior Vice President of Machine Learning and AI Strategy, who also oversees the development of Apple's virtual assistant Siri, Bloomberg reported. Apple began working on its autonomous car project, known as Titan, in 2014. CEO Tim Cook in 2017 called autonomous systems "mother of all AI projects".

column3: Tesla teams to visit Indonesia to discuss investment in EV components
column4: Tesla will send delegations to Indonesia next month to discuss potential investment in a supply chain for its electric vehicles. Government officials and Tesla CEO Elon Musk have discussed investment opportunities in Indonesia over a call. Indonesia earlier pointed out it has the "biggest" nickel reserves. Musk plans to offer a "giant contract for a long period of time".

column3: Apple CFO, Apple's ex-design chief candidates for Ferrari CEO: Report
column4: Apple CFO Luca Maestri and former Chief Design Officer Jony Ive are reportedly candidates to be Ferrari's next CEO, Reuters reported. Ferrari CEO Louis Camilleri announced his retirement earlier due to "personal reasons". Former Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao was allegedly in the running for the position too, but Reuters said a source close to Colao has called the claim "groundless".

column3: Tesla to shut down production of Model S, X for 18 days: Report
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla will shut down the production of its high-end Model S and Model X electric vehicles from December 24 to January 11 in Fremont, California, CNBC reported. Employees will be given a full week's pay along with few paid holidays. Deliveries of these models amounted to only 11% of total vehicle deliveries during Tesla's third quarter of 2020.

column3: Volkswagen CEO reveals they began 'Mission T' to catch up with Tesla
column4: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess, in a blog post, revealed he organised a three-day workshop nicknamed 'Mission T' to discuss how they could "catch up with Tesla". He added that they brought 31 senior executives from Volkswagen, Audi and Porsche together amid the COVID-19 pandemic to discuss how they could further their Project Artemis to take on Tesla.

column3: Hyundai, Kia agree to $210M US penalty for delay in vehicles' recall
column4: Hyundai and Kia Motors have agreed to $140 million and $70 million civil penalties, respectively, after US auto safety regulators said they delayed recall of 1.6 million vehicles for engine issues. The settlement covers recall in 2015 and 2017 for manufacturing issues. Kia denied the allegations but agreed to settle the matter to "avoid a protracted dispute with the government".

column3: Toyota halts operations at Karnataka plant as union strike continues
column4: Toyota Motor Corporation again halted operations at its car plant in Karnataka's Bidadi from Monday, as members of its workers' union continued a strike after the suspension of a worker wasn't withdrawn. Earlier, Toyota Kirloskar Motor (TKM) had declared a lockout at both its plants in Bidadi on November 10. The company said that the union had compromised COVID-19 guidelines.

column3: Tesla would consider buying a legacy automaker on friendly terms: Musk
column4: Tesla would consider leveraging the company's $554 billion market capitalisation to buy a legacy automaker, CEO Elon Musk said in an interview with Axel Springer. "We're definitely not going to launch a hostile takeover," Musk said. "If somebody said, 'Hey, we think it would be a good idea to merge with Tesla,' we certainly could have that conversation," he added.

column3: Delhi govt launches forum to discuss electric vehicle policy
column4: Delhi government on Friday launched the 'Delhi EV Forum', a common platform for multiple stakeholders to hold discussions on the government's electric vehicle (EV) policy. "Delhi EV Forum will be the first such forum in India...The first meeting will be held virtually on December 18," Delhi DDC Vice Chairperson said. The policy's objective is to combat air pollution in Delhi.

column3: Tesla to raise $5 billion as market cap crosses $600 billion
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla on Tuesday announced that it will be raising $5 billion, marking its second capital raise in the last three months. The additional shares will be sold "from time to time" and "at-the-market" prices. Its shares are up nearly 670% this year with its market capitalisation crossing $600 billion. Tesla will join S&P 500 index later this month.

column3: Japan must compensate ex-Nissan Chairman for arbitrary arrest: UN panel
column4: The UN Working Group on Arbitrary Detention on Monday ruled that Former Nissan Chairman Carlos Ghosn's multiple arrests and detentions in Japan were "arbitrary" and urged Japanese government to pay compensation. Japan said the panel doesn't have an "accurate understanding of the country's criminal justice system". Ghosn, who was arrested in 2018 in Japan, fled to Lebanon last year.

column3: Workers of Toyota unit near B'luru to continue strike over workload
column4: Factory workers at Toyota Kirloskar Private Limited's Bidadi unit, located near Bengaluru, announced that they will continue their ongoing strike over increased workload, among other concerns. They said that they don't get time to drink water or use the washroom. The unit has been in a lockout since November 10, after 41 workers were suspended for allegedly questioning the management.

column3: Aus vaccine trial scrapped as participants returned false +ve HIV test results
column4: The University of Queensland and pharmaceutical company CSL have abandoned the clinical trial of their COVID-19 vaccine after several participants returned false positive HIV test results. CSL said the vaccine was safe and was proving effective, but that significant changes would be needed to HIV testing procedures in the healthcare setting to accommodate the rollout of the vaccine.

column3: AstraZeneca to test combining Oxford vaccine with Sputnik V vaccine
column4: AstraZeneca, which is developing a coronavirus vaccine with Oxford University, said it would investigate combining its vaccine with Russia's Sputnik V vaccine. "Being able to combine different vaccines may be helpful to improve protection and/or to improve vaccine accessibility," AstraZeneca said. A 'mix and match' trial between AstraZeneca and Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccines was announced earlier.

column3: Five genes linked to most severe form of COVID-19 found
column4: Scientists in the UK have identified five genes that are linked with the most severe form of COVID-19. The genes partially explain why some people become extremely sick with COVID-19, while others are not affected, according to their study. "Our results immediately highlight which drugs should be at the top of the list for clinical testing," a scientist said.

column3: 4 volunteers who got Pfizer vaccine developed temporary facial paralysis: US FDA
column4: Four trial participants who received the Pfizer and BioNTech's coronavirus vaccine developed Bell's palsy, a form of temporary facial paralysis, according to the US' Food and Drug Administration (FDA). No members of the placebo group experienced similar adverse effects. There were no "meaningful imbalances" in serious health complications between the two groups, the FDA said in a report.

column3: India's 1st mRNA vaccine candidate gets DCGI nod for human trials
column4: India's first indigenous mRNA vaccine candidate has received approval to initiate Phase 1 and 2 human clinical trials from Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI). Pune-based Gennova Biopharmaceuticals developed the COVID-19 vaccine candidate, HGCO19, in collaboration with US-based HDT Bio. The vaccine demonstrated "safety and immunogenicity" in rodent and non-human primate models, Gennova said.

column3: Human-made objects to outweigh living things by the end of 2020: Study
column4: Scientists have said that the weight of human-made objects will likely exceed that of living things by the end of the year. In a study published in the scientific journal Nature, scientists compared the overall living biomass on Earth, estimated to be around 1.1 teratonnes, to human-made mass. "We find that Earth is exactly at the crossover point," they said.

column3: Indian-American Raja Chari among 18 astronauts selected for next moon missions
column4: Indian-American astronaut Raja Chari is among the 18 astronauts selected to begin training for upcoming Artemis missions to the moon, NASA announced on Wednesday. The first woman and the next man on the moon will come from this group of 18 astronauts. "Proud to be part of the team working to take humans to the moon to stay," Chari tweeted.

column3: Emissions hit new high, world heading for temperature rise of 3°C: UN report
column4: Greenhouse gas emissions reached a new high last year, putting the world on track for an average temperature rise of 3°C this century, a UN report said. This is far beyond Paris Agreement goals of limiting global warming to well below 2°C and pursuing 1.5°C. Emissions of carbon dioxide equivalent (GtCO2e) in 2019 hit a new record of 59.1 gigatonnes.

column3: Saliva-like droplets sprayed in stadium to study how fans spread aerosols
column4: Scientists have sprayed fine droplets, made to resemble saliva, over empty stands at the Netherlands' largest football stadium to model how a football crowd might spread aerosols through the air. Scientists aim to find out more about the behaviour of airborne particles, which could spread the coronavirus within a crowd and thus be able to remove them from the air.

column3: Aliens exist; they're in contact with US & Israel: Israel's ex-space security chief
column4: Aliens are real and secretly in contact with America and Israel but are keeping their existence quiet because "humanity isn't ready", said Haim Eshed, who headed Israel's space security programme for nearly 30 years. The 87-year-old further claimed there’s a "Galactic Federation" of aliens and their cooperation with the US includes a secret underground base on Mars.

column3: Humanity will face 60°C temperatures in 2050s, warns WEF
column4: As many as two billion people will face 60°C temperatures for more than a tenth of the year in the 2050s, the World Economic Forum (WEF) warned citing a book. Up to 140 million people are expected to be displaced by 2050 because of food and water insecurity as well as extreme weather, it further said quoting the World Bank.

column3: Delhi startup builds tech to do COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 cr samples per week
column4: Delhi-based IT startup Thalamus Irwine claims to have developed an artificial intelligence and IoT-based solution that can complete a COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 crore samples in one week. It has also partnered with state-run ITI to host its data. Serosurveys can help track the geographic spread of the virus by analysing antibodies in blood samples.

column3: Russian cosmonauts to receive Sputnik V COVID-19 vaccine
column4: Russian space agency Roscosmos has said that Russian cosmonauts "will be among the first to be vaccinated" against COVID-19 with the Sputnik V vaccine but insisted that it will be done on a voluntary basis only. The vaccine will play an important role in ensuring the safety of Russia's space program, Minister of Health of the Russian Federation said.

column3: Researchers develop first AI tool to detect COVID-19 probability
column4: A team of researchers from the University of Vermont and Cedars-Sinai has developed the first software to predict the probability of COVID-19 infections. AI-COVID uses details from routine blood tests and can assign the probability of a patient being COVID-19 negative with high accuracy. This can help hospitals reduce the number of patients referred for PCR testing.

column3: 7 of top 10 killers pre-COVID-19 were non-communicable diseases: WHO
column4: Non-communicable diseases accounted for seven of the top 10 causes of death before the coronavirus pandemic, the World Health Organization (WHO), citing data from 2000 to 2019, said. Heart disease has been world's biggest cause of death for the last 20 years, it added. In 2019, people were living for over six years longer than in 2000, it further said.

column3: SpaceX's Mars rocket test aborted 1 second before liftoff
column4: A key test of SpaceX's Starship SN8 rocket, which is expected to carry humans to the Moon and Mars, was automatically aborted one second before liftoff on Tuesday. The test would have launched the Starship 12.5 km (41,000 feet) from Earth into the space, for the first time ever, before attempting to land the vehicle near the launch site.

column3: India not historically responsible for climate change: Javadekar
column4: Environment Minister Prakash Javadekar has said India is not historically responsible for climate change but is taking steps to reduce emissions. He said India is the only G20 nation to be in compliance with the Paris Agreement. India has already achieved 21% of its target of reducing emissions intensity of GDP by 33%-35% by 2030, he added.

column3: IUCN lists 31 species as 'Extinct', European Bison sees recovery
column4: The IUCN released an update of its Red List of Threatened Species which moved 31 species into the 'Extinct' category. However, the European Bison has moved from 'Vulnerable' to 'Near Threatened' category. Besides this, all of the world's freshwater dolphin species are now listed as threatened on the list. The lost shark has entered the 'Critically Endangered' (Possibly Extinct) category.

column3: New salamander species added to US' North Carolina's list of 63 species
column4: The US' North Carolina State added a new salamander species to its list of 63 species. The 'Carolina Sandhills Salamander' was previously categorised as an unusual population of the 'Southern Two-lined Salamander'. However, researchers used sequencing technology to show that the new species differs genetically. It also differs in colouration, size and natural history from complex's other members.

column3: Japan's greenhouse emissions fell 2.7% to record low in FY 2019-20
column4: Japan's greenhouse gas emissions fell 2.7% to a record low in the financial year 2019-20. The drop was Japan's sixth straight annual drop. Emissions dropped to 1.213 billion metric tonnes of CO2 equivalent from 1.247 billion tonnes the previous year. The levels recorded are the lowest since comparable data became available in the financial year 1990-91.

column3: Superhighway system to travel via Solar System faster discovered: Scientists
column4: UC San Diego revealed researchers have discovered a new "superhighway" network to travel through the Solar System much faster. Such routes can drive comets and asteroids near Jupiter to Neptune in less than 10 years. Scientists found the routes by computing how "millions" of Solar System orbits fit within already-known space manifolds.

column3: Deforestation in Amazon destroyed area bigger than Spain in 18 yrs: Study
column4: Deforestation in the Amazon destroyed an area bigger than Spain from 2000 to 2018, wiping out 8% of the world's biggest rainforest,  a study by RAISG said. An atlas of the region showed that 5.13 lakh square kilometres of the rainforest has been lost since 2000. The highest loss of 49,240 square kilometres was recorded in 2003.

column3: Method to harvest drinking water from air developed: IIT Guwahati
column4: IIT Guwahati researchers claim to have made novel materials that can harvest water from humid air. They mimicked the pitcher plant, an insect-eating plant with a slippery surface and used the concept of chemically patterned Slippery Liquid-Infused Porous Surfaces. The team produced a patterned hydrophilic SLIP by spraying sponge-like porous polymeric material on top of a simple A4 printer paper.

column3: SL records 2nd-highest human deaths due to conflict with elephant: Report
column4: Sri Lanka has recorded the second-highest human deaths due to the human-elephant conflict in the world after India, Daily News reported. Sri Lanka's COPA revealed the number of human deaths has increased from an average of 85 humans to 122 per year in the past 12 months in Sri Lanka. However, it has recorded the highest number of elephant deaths.

column3: Declare a State of Climate Emergency in your nations: UN to leaders
column4: World leaders should declare "States of Climate Emergency" in their countries until carbon neutrality is reached, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said at a climate summit. "Can anybody still deny that we are facing a dramatic emergency?" he asked. He added G20 members are spending 50% more in their stimulus packages on fossil fuel-linked sectors and consumption, than on low-carbon energy.

column3: Mi India to launch Mi QLED 4K TV in India on Dec 16
column4: Mi India has announced to launch Mi QLED 4K TV in India on December 16th. The TV will be equipped with premium features including Dolby Vision, Dolby Audio apart from the proprietary Vivid Picture Engine and PatchWall, it said. The company added that it plans to expand its lineup under the 'Make In India' initiative to nearly 100% in 2021.

column3: Internal storage quota issue caused 45-minute worldwide outage: Google
column4: Google in a statement on Monday said that it experienced an authentication system outage for approximately 45 minutes due to an "internal storage quota issue". "This was resolved and all services are now restored," Google added. "We apologise to everyone affected, and we'll conduct a thorough follow up review to ensure this problem cannot recur in the future," Google said.

column3: The dichotomy of OnePlus was super intriguing: Robert Downey Jr.
column4: OnePlus brand ambassador actor Robert Downey Jr. has said that teaming with OnePlus and seeing their growth is pretty eye-opening. He added, "The dichotomy of OnePlus was super intriguing." It was a unique situation where they were dominant in certain markets, like India, but had ground to gain in others, making creative process equally as challenging and rewarding, he said.

column3: Google services including YouTube, Gmail, Google Maps go down worldwide
column4: Several users from across the world took to Twitter on Monday to complain that they were facing issues with Google services like YouTube, Gmail, Google Drive, Google Maps and Google Meet. While YouTube's homepage showed 'Something went wrong...' message, Gmail displayed 'Temporary Error (500)'. According to Downdetector, issues with Google services began at 4:51 pm.

column3: 7,000 people booked for violence at Karnataka's iPhone manufacturing plant
column4: A total of 7,000 people were booked, including 5,000 contract workers, in connection with the violence and vandalism at Wistron iPhone manufacturing plant in Karnataka's Kolar. Employees vandalised the plant due to non-payment of salaries. Wistron has clarified that the incident caused up to ₹52 crore in losses, a day after estimating damages worth ₹440 crore in a police complaint.

column3: We're back up and running: Google's YouTube after hour-long outage
column4: Google-owned YouTube took to Twitter to update its users that its service was "back up and running" after an hour-long worldwide outage. Google's major services including YouTube, Google Maps, Google Drive and Gmail suffered an hour-long outage on Monday. YouTube's homepage displayed 'Something is not right...' message during the outage.

column3: Violence at K'taka iPhone plant caused up to ₹52 cr loss not ₹440 cr: Wistron
column4: Apple's supplier Wistron has clarified that ransacking of its iPhone manufacturing facility near Bengaluru caused up to ₹52 crore in losses, a day after estimating damages worth ₹440 crore in a police complaint. The company said major production facilities and warehouses had not suffered as serious damage as reported by local media, adding it is negotiating with the insurance company.

column3: 6-yr-old in US spends ₹12 lakh on iPad game from mother's credit card
column4: After a 41-year-old woman in US filed a fraud claim for charges made from her credit card, she discovered her six-year-old had ended up paying $16,293 (about ₹12 lakh) to Apple for purchases in a video game. Apple declined to refund the amount since she hadn't claimed it within 60 days. "There's a setting, you should've known," Apple told her.

column3: Not in India's DNA to be deterred by crisis, every crisis an opportunity: Ambani
column4: Reliance Industries Chairman Mukesh Ambani spoke to Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg about COVID-19's impact on India and said, "I think it's not in India’s DNA to be deterred by a crisis." Speaking at Facebook Fuel for India 2020 event, Ambani added, "Every crisis is an opportunity for new growth." Ambani also said, "India faced COVID-19 with enormous resilience and resolve."

column3: Will take vaccine publicly when my turn comes: Bill Gates
column4: Microsoft Co-founder Bill Gates has said that when his turn comes up, he will take the COVID-19 vaccine publicly to increase the confidence of the people in the vaccine. "When it's my turn...I'm not going to budge," he said. Gates warned that the next four to six months could be the worst of the coronavirus pandemic in the US.

column3: Noida-based firm which works with defence forces claims data hack
column4: A Noida-based defence tech service provider, which works with the country's defence and paramilitary forces and intelligence agencies, has alleged that critical and classified data have been accessed by hackers. The hacked emails were of "extremely sensitive" nature and "of substantial financial value", the firm said. It added that it has suffered a financial loss of ₹50 crore.

column3: US FTC asks Facebook, Amazon to explain how they use users' data
column4: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) has ordered Facebook, Amazon and Twitter to explain how they use the personal information that they collect on their users. The FTC is seeking information related to how they determine which ads are shown to users and how the algorithms are used. It has also sent orders to WhatsApp, TikTok, YouTube, Snap and Reddit.

column3: Goal is to make India surpass China in mobile manufacturing: Prasad
column4: India aims to surpass China in mobile manufacturing with production-linked incentive (PLI) scheme attracting global majors in this segment, Union Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said. "That's my goal and I am very clearly defining it," he added. The government is looking to make India a hub of other electronic products as well with the PLI scheme's expansion to other sectors.

column3: HC seeks Centre, AAP's response on plea to ban online gambling sites
column4: The Delhi High Court has asked the Centre and the Aam Aadmi Party (AAP) government to respond on a PIL seeking ban on websites involved in gambling. The petitioner contended that despite being prohibited by the law, online gambling activities were "being carried out because of a lack of enforcement of the laws in question".

column3: Pegasus spyware cited in petition against WhatsApp Payments in SC
column4: Israeli spy software 'Pegasus' was mentioned in a petition in Supreme Court to argue that WhatsApp's system wasn't secure to allow payment services' launch. WhatsApp's counsel called the allegation of the system being vulnerable to hacking "baseless". The petition sought RBI and NPCI's intervention to ensure data protection of various UPI Platforms including WhatsApp Payments and Google Pay.

column3: Microsoft Outlook email services down for some users
column4: Some of Microsoft Outlook email service users have been experiencing an intermittent outage. Microsoft's site status confirmed that some Outlook users may not be able to access their mailbox using Outlook.com because of a glitch in its Active Directory infrastructure. The page indicates that other services like Skype, OneDrive and Teams are all working fine.

column3: Scientists digitally rebuild dinosaur's brain, learn about its diet
column4: The University of Bristol's scientists have "rebuilt" the brain of a Thecodontosaurus, that roamed England some 205 million years ago, using advanced imaging and 3D modelling techniques.
