column4: The US State of California has filed a petition in a court to force Amazon to comply with outstanding subpoenas over a state investigation into its handling of COVID-19. It has accused Amazon of failing to adequately follow California's information requests into Amazon's COVID-19 protocols. Amazon said California's "claims of noncompliance with their demands don't line up with the facts".

column3: Will look into inaction against Bajrang Dal if referred: FB Oversight Board
column4: Facebook's Oversight Board will investigate why the platform took no action against the right-wing nationalist group Bajrang Dal if the matter is referred to the panel, the board's Indian representative Sudhir Krishnaswamy told ET. The WSJ earlier reported that Facebook did not ban Bajrang Dal after its security team warned that the move could endanger Facebook's business and its employees.

column3: Twitter fined $547,000 in Ireland over breach that made tweets public
column4: Ireland's Data Protection Commission (DPC) has fined Twitter €450,000 (about $547,000) for failing to notify a data breach that made some private tweets public. This marks the DPC's first cross-border sanction against an American company under Europe's General Data Protection Regulation. Twitter said the delay in notifying DPC was an "unanticipated consequence of staffing" during the holidays.

column3: Apple launches store privacy labels to show users apps' data collection
column4: Apple has launched its privacy "nutrition labels" feature across all App Stores, including iOS, iPadOS, macOS, watchOS and tvOS, that would show users the apps' data collection practices. The label will give users an idea of what information an app collects and present that visually on the app page. The labels need to be up to date and accurate.

column3: Creator of Google Wallet sells his startup for $365 mn to GoDaddy
column4: Google Wallet creator Osama Bedier, who left Google to pursue "other opportunities" in 2013, has sold his startup Poynt for $365 million to GoDaddy. Bedier, who is also Poynt's CEO, will join the GoDaddy leadership team and lead a new commerce division. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter of 2021, GoDaddy said on Tuesday.

column3: Rahim fined 25% of his match fee for almost hitting his teammate in anger
column4: Beximco Dhaka captain Mushfiqur Rahim has been fined 25% of his match fee over a heated exchange with his teammate Nasum Ahmed during a domestic T20 match. He also earned one demerit point for his indiscipline on the field. If Rahim receives four or more points in this tournament, the Beximco Dhaka captain could receive a match ban.

column3: 'You are scared to fight me': YouTuber offers ₹370 cr to McGregor to box him
column4: YouTuber-turned-amateur boxer Jake Paul, in a rant posted on social media, challenged former UFC champion Conor McGregor and offered him $50 million (₹370 crore) to fight in a boxing match. "My team sent you a $50 million offer...But, you're scared to fight me, Conor! You're ducking me because you don't want to lose to a YouTuber," the 23-year-old said.

column3: Kane Williamson and partner Sarah blessed with a baby girl, share 1st pic
column4: New Zealand captain Kane Williamson and his partner Sarah Raheem have been blessed with a baby girl, with Williamson announcing the news on Instagram today. Williamson shared a picture of himself with his newborn baby girl and wrote, "Overjoyed to welcome a beautiful baby girl into our family." Williamson and Sarah have been a couple since at least late 2015.

column3: Inzamam criticises Waqar Younis for calling Babar Azam's injury 'major setback'
column4: Former Pakistan captain Inzamam-ul-Haq has criticised Pakistan bowling coach Waqar Younis for saying that Babar Azam's injury came "at the wrong time" and that it is a "major setback" for them. "I don’t think the management should say that we are concerned, as it sends out a message to the opposition that our morale is down," Inzamam said.

column3: Sreesanth moves closer to professional cricket return, named in Kerala probables
column4: Fast bowler Sreesanth has moved closer to a return to professional competitive cricket after being named in a 26-member probables list by Kerala for the upcoming Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy. The 37-year-old, who was banned by the BCCI over his alleged involvement in spot-fixing, had completed the ban period in September this year. The tournament will begin on January 10.

column3: ICC announces qualification pathway for 2022 men's T20 World Cup
column4: ICC has announced the qualification pathway for men's T20 World Cup in Australia, which will take place in October-November 2022. As many as 86 teams will be competing for 15 spots. A total of 225 T20Is will be played in qualifying phase across 13 months. Hungary, Romania and Serbia will compete in their first men's T20 WC qualifying pathway.

column3: Team India's playing XI announced a day before first Test against Australia
column4: The BCCI on Wednesday announced Team India's playing XI for the first Test against Australia which will take place in Adelaide from Thursday. Prithvi Shaw has been chosen as Mayank Agarwal's opening partner over Shubman Gill, while Wriddhiman Saha has been picked as wicketkeeper ahead of Rishabh Pant. Jasprit Bumrah, Mohammad Shami and Umesh Yadav are the three pacers selected.

column3: Latest rankings for Test all-rounders out; Jadeja, Ashwin only Indians in top 10
column4: The ICC on Tuesday released the latest rankings for Test all-rounders. Spinners Ravichandran Ashwin and Ravindra Jadeja are the only two Indians in the top 10. Further, England fast bowlers Stuart Broad and Chris Woakes jumped one spot each to be ranked 10th and seventh, respectively. Ben Stokes tops the list with 446 rating points.

column3: Tom Moody returns to SunRisers Hyderabad as director of cricket
column4: Former Australian cricketer Tom Moody, who had coached SunRisers Hyderabad from its inception in 2013 to 2019, has returned to the franchise as the director of cricket. Trevor Bayliss will continue as the head coach of the franchise. Under Moody's coaching, SunRisers had won the IPL in 2016 and finished runners-up in 2018.

column3: I should've studied Shubman in KKR nets, might be too late now: Pat Cummins
column4: Talking about his KKR teammate Shubman Gill, who might feature for India in the first Test against Australia, fast bowler Pat Cummins said, "I should have studied him in the KKR nets. It might be too late now." Cummins added, "He is obviously a class player, and it will be interesting to see if he gets picked."

column3: Federer is 39 and still at the top: Ronaldo on motivation levels of athletes
column4: Juventus forward Cristiano Ronaldo has said the truth to his longevity in football lies in "the head and his motivation to not slow down". "I don't want people to say 'Cristiano was an incredible player but now he's slow'," Ronaldo added. "In sports...you can gain maturity. Look at Roger Federer, he's 39 and still at the top," he further said.

column3: ICC release latest rankings for Test bowlers, get trolled by Stuart Broad
column4: The ICC on Tuesday released the latest rankings for Test bowlers, with England fast bowler Stuart Broad jumping one place to be ranked second. The 34-year-old trolled the ICC and commented, "How? I have not played [Test cricket] since August." Broad also climbed one position in rankings for Test all-rounders and is now ranked 10th.

column3: I deleted my Twitter account after losing 2018-19 Test series against India: Starc
column4: Australia pacer Mitchell Starc has revealed he deleted his Twitter account after Australia lost 2018-19 home series against India. "Since then...I haven't been reading anything really and not really caring what other people's opinions are," he added. "It's just had me in...clearer mindset to focus on what I can control and bowl the way I want to," Starc said.

column3: Rahane held the team together during the Test series in 2018-19: Paine
column4: Australia Test captain Tim Paine credited Test vice-captain Ajinkya Rahane for keeping Virat Kohli-led Team India together during their previous Test series in Australia in 2018-19. "He (Rahane) was the glue last time around so he is a huge focus for us," said Paine. This time around Rahane would captain the side once Virat flies back after the first Test.

column3: Indian bowlers can't get carried away with bouncy wickets in Aus: Kapil
column4: Former India all-rounder Kapil Dev said Indian bowlers shouldn't get excited with Australia's pace-friendly wickets and "start bowling short" during the four-match Test series. "Our fast bowlers are not that used to bowling on Australian pitches...It's very important to understand their pace and back their strengths," Kapil said. He added that Australia have the edge going into the Test series.

column3: Perfect role model but Virat's captaincy still work-in-progress: Laxman
column4: Ex-India cricketer VVS Laxman said captain Virat Kohli leads by example but there is scope for improvement as far as his captaincy is concerned. "He's a perfect role model of how a captain should be. There's still work-in-progress as far as captaincy is concerned," Laxman said. He added that he feels Virat does become little defensive, especially with field changes.

column3: Suresh Raina to play for UP in Syed Mushtaq Ali T20 tournament
column4: Former India cricketer, Suresh Raina, who retired from international cricket earlier this year, is set to feature for Uttar Pradesh in the upcoming Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy. Raina on Sunday had also shared images of his training in the nets, stating, "All set for the camp, warming up for the upcoming season."

column3: Bumrah will be key for India to retain the Test series vs Aus: Allan Border
column4: Ex-Australia captain Allan Border believes pacer Jasprit Bumrah "is the one who is going to be a key" for India if they plan to retain the Test series against Australia. "For India to win...If he fires up like he did last time, get important wickets, ruffle a few feathers...I reckon he could be the real difference," Border said.

column3: WADA tracking COVID-19 vaccines to avoid breach of anti-doping rules
column4: The World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) is tracking composition of COVID-19 vaccines to avoid athletes failing dope test. The agency has assured athletes that if a vaccine causes a possible anti-doping rule violation then they will ensure vaccines and the principles of anti-doping don't come into conflict. WADA said they have reached a memorandum of understanding with various pharmaceutical companies.

column3: I believe staying in the moment, Virat is our captain now: Rahane on captaining
column4: On being asked about captaining India in the final three Tests against Australia, Test vice-captain Ajinkya Rahane said he'll think about it after the first Test. "I believe staying in the moment...Right now, Virat is our captain. We think about this Test match and then after that when he leaves, we will think [about final three]," he stated.

column3: Aston Villa captain given 9-month driving ban for crashing into parked vehicles
column4: Aston Villa captain Jack Grealish has been banned from driving for nine months and fined £82,499 over two incidents of careless driving. In March, Grealish had hit two parked vehicles in Dickens Heath, Solihull. The 25-yr-old was then caught driving at speeds of up to 98 mph on a 70 mph limit motorway in October.

column3: Rohit Sharma leaves for Australia ahead of Test series: Report
column4: India opener Rohit Sharma has reportedly left for Australia and will be available for the final two Tests of the four-match series. According to ANI, Rohit left for Australia via Dubai in the early hours of Tuesday. Rohit was dropped from the tour after he suffered a hamstring injury during the IPL but was later added to the Test squad.

column3: Pant will play as wicketkeeper, if India go with 5 bowlers: Ian Chappell
column4: Talking about Team India's combination in the upcoming Tests, former Australia captain Ian Chappell said that if India play five bowlers then Rishabh Pant might play as wicketkeeper-batsman. "Pant is better as a batsman [than Wriddhiman Saha]," he added. He, however, also added that if India play batting-heavy line-up then the visitors will go for the "better wicketkeeper [Saha]".

column3: Yuvraj named in Punjab's 30-man probable squad for Syed Mushtaq Ali Trophy
column4: Yuvraj Singh has been named in Punjab's 30-man probable squad for the Syed Mushtaq Ali T20 tournament. Yuvraj who turned 39 recently, has reportedly been training regularly in Mohali. However, the former India all-rounder, who had announced his retirement from all forms of cricket last year, is yet to receive approval from BCCI President Sourav Ganguly.

column3: Will decide after the India series: Paine on his future as player and captain
column4: Australia's Test captain Tim Paine said he will be contemplating about his future as a player and a leader after the series against India. "At the moment, the focus is on...for the rest of the series and then we will see," Paine said. He added he has been talking with coach Justin Langer and the chief selector about his future.

column3: I haven't taken COVID-19 vaccine yet, don't want to 'cut the line': Pfizer CEO
column4: American pharmaceutical corporation Pfizer's CEO Albert Bourla told CNBC that he hasn't taken the COVID-19 vaccine yet. "As soon as I can, I will," Bourla said, adding that he and his company's executives do not want to "cut the line" and set a bad example. "I'm 59 years old, in good health, I'm not working on the frontline," Bourla said.

column3: Paris authorities fined over ₹80 lakh for having too many women in top jobs
column4: France's public service ministry has fined the Paris city authorities 90,000 euros (more than ₹80 lakh)  for employing too many women in senior positions in 2018. The city hall appointed 11 women and 5 men to top posts, breaching a law passed to maintain a gender balance. "This fine is obviously absurd, unfair, irresponsible and dangerous," said Paris Mayor.

column3: Aus soldier quits after pic of him drinking from fake leg of Taliban fighter emerges
column4: John Letch, one of Australia's top special forces soldiers, has stepped down after a photo of him drinking from a prosthetic leg of a dead Taliban fighter emerged. 'The Guardian' had published a pixelated photo of Letch earlier this month. It is believed to be taken in 2009 at an unofficial bar inside Australia's special forces base in Tarin Kowt.

column3: WHO chief should be probed over genocide in Ethiopia: Economist
column4: WHO chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus should be probed over genocide in Ethiopia, Nobel Peace Prize nominee David Steinman said in a complaint to International Criminal Court. He "was a crucial decision-maker in relation to...actions that included killing...and torturing Ethiopians", Steinman said. Ghebreyesus shared control over Ethiopia's security forces between 2013 and 2015, Steinman alleged.

column3: Japan's 'Twitter killer' sentenced to death for murders of 9 people
column4: A Japanese court on Tuesday sentenced a man dubbed "Twitter killer" to death for the 2017 murders of nine people, eight women and a man, local media reported. Takahiro Shiraishi, 30, was convicted of murdering, raping, dismembering, and storing the nine victims' bodies in his apartment. Shiraishi made contact with victims via Twitter after they expressed suicidal thoughts.

column3: Half of S'pore migrant workers in dormitories have had COVID-19
column4: Nearly half of Singapore's migrant workers residing in dormitories have had COVID-19, nearly three times higher than the official tally, according to the government. A total of 54,505 workers had tested positive using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) tests as of Sunday but an additional 98,289 had tested positive using serology tests. Singapore's COVID-19 tally stands at more than 58,000 cases.

column3: China not transparent on COVID-19 vaccine emergency use: Brazil
column4: Brazil's health regulator ANVISA has criticised China for not providing enough information about allowing the emergency use of Chinese-made CoronaVac vaccine, currently undergoing trials in Brazil. The agency said that allowing the emergency use of CoronaVac without the relevant data would pose "risks to the Brazilian population". The vaccine is currently undergoing Phase III trials in Sao Paulo.

column3: 1st known case of COVID-19 in non-captive wild mink found in US
column4: The first known case of COVID-19 in a non-captive wild mink has been confirmed, according to an alert issued by the US Department of Agriculture. The wild mink tested positive around an infected mink farm in Utah. The strain of the virus in the wild mink is "indistinguishable" from that in infected mink on farms around the state.

column3: Indonesia to give free COVID-19 vaccine to all its residents
column4: Indonesian President Joko Widodo on Wednesday said that COVID-19 vaccines would be free to its residents after the country's food and drug agency gives emergency use authorisation. Widodo added that he would take the first shot to promote public confidence in the vaccine's safety. Earlier this month, the country had received its first shipment of Chinese-made vaccine, CoronaVac.

column3: US FDA finds Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine safe, 94.1% effective
column4: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) staff members have said that Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine didn't raise any specific safety issues in adults over the age of 18. In a report, the staff also confirmed that the vaccine has an overall efficacy of 94.1%. This comes ahead of a meeting of FDA's advisers on whether to grant it emergency use authorisation.

column3: Australia sues Facebook for promoting VPN, collecting user data
column4: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) on Wednesday sued Facebook, accusing it of collecting user data without permission. The Australian regulator added that Facebook promoted a virtual private network (VPN) as a way for people to protect their data, while secretly using the information to pick targets for commercial acquisitions. Facebook shut its VPN product in 2019.

column3: Singapore investigates posts supporting Indian farmers' protest
column4: Singapore Police on Tuesday said it's investigating posts on social media showing people gathering in support of Indian farmers in the country. The police added that they haven't granted any permit "for these cause-based assemblies". "Those who break the law will be dealt with firmly, and this may include termination of visa or work passes, where applicable," police further said.

column3: Desecration of Mahatma Gandhi's statue in Washington appalling: US
column4: White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany on Tuesday said that the desecration of Mahatma Gandhi's statue outside the Indian embassy in Washington is "appalling". She added that Mahatma Gandhi fought for values like peace, justice and freedom that the US represents. The statue was desecrated on Saturday during a demonstration in support of Indian farmers against the new farm laws.

column3: Execution of journalist was based on law: Iranian Prez Rouhani
column4: Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Monday said that the execution of journalist Ruhollah Zam was based on law and that Iran's judiciary is independent. The comments come as many countries including France and the US condemned the execution of the journalist. Zam was executed on Saturday for his work online that helped inspire nationwide economic protests in 2017.

column3: Yemen at highest risk of humanitarian catastrophe in 2021: IRC
column4: International Rescue Committee (IRC) on Wednesday warned that Yemen is at the highest risk of a humanitarian catastrophe in 2021, for the third year running. Widespread hunger, continued conflict and the tumbling of international aid dramatically worsen the current crisis in Yemen, IRC said. Twenty-four million people in the region now require humanitarian aid, IRC aid director for Yemen said.

column3: Donald Trump still pursuing election litigation: White House
column4: White House Press Secretary Kayleigh McEnany on Tuesday said that US President Donald Trump is "still pursuing ongoing litigation" related to the November 3 presidential election. The comments came a day after the Electoral College formally confirmed Joe Biden's victory over Trump in the elections. McEnany described the Electoral College vote as just "one step in the constitutional process".

column3: ICC prosecutors reject Uighur genocide complaint against China
column4: International Criminal Court prosecutors have said that they can't investigate China for alleged genocide and crimes against Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang. The chief prosecutor's office added that it can't act because the alleged acts took place on the territory of China, which isn't a signatory to The Hague-based ICC. Uighurs had given a dossier of evidence to ICC in July.

column3: Hungary bans same-sex couples from adopting children
column4: Hungarian lawmakers on Tuesday passed a law that bans same-sex couples from adopting children. The law put forward by PM Viktor Orbán's right-wing government allows only married couples to adopt children, with some exceptions for single people. Same-sex marriage is illegal in Hungary, but adoption had been possible until now if one partner applied as a single person.

column3: Happy that 'lawless' Trump is leaving White House: Iran President
column4: Calling US President Donald Trump "lawless" and a "terrorist", Iranian President Hassan Rouhani on Wednesday said that he is happy that Trump is leaving the White House. However, Rouhani added that he was not "overjoyed about Mr. Biden's arrival". US President-elect Joe Biden is set to take office on January 20 as the 46th president of the United States.

column3: Somalia cuts diplomatic ties with Kenya citing political interference
column4: Somalia has cut ties with Kenya due to "constant political violation" and its "interference in Somalia's independence", the country's Information Minister Osman Dube said. Somalia recalled its diplomats from Kenya while Kenyan diplomats have been ordered to leave within seven days, he added. This comes after Muse Bihi Abdi, President of Somalia's breakaway region of Somaliland, visited Kenya.

column3: Won’t allow anarchy in name of religion: B'desh PM on Victory Day
column4: Speaking on the occasion of Victory Day in Bangladesh, PM Sheikh Hasina on Wednesday said, "We won't allow anyone to create any division and anarchy in the name of religion." "This Bangladesh is the Bangladesh of Sheikh Mujib and 16.5 crore Bengalis, this country is for all," she added. Bangladesh was liberated from the Pakistani occupation on December 16, 1971.

column3: Boko Haram claims kidnapping of hundreds of students in Nigeria
column4: Boko Haram has claimed responsibility for the abduction of over 300 students from an all-boys school in Nigeria's Katsina. "I am Abubakar Shekau...What happened in Katsina was done to promote Islam and discourage un-Islamic practices," the group's leader said in a voice message. Earlier, the army said it had located the hideout of the men and an operation was underway.

column3: Fashion mogul Peter Nygard arrested after US sex trafficking charges
column4: Fashion mogul Peter Nygard was arrested in Canada after US authorities charged him with racketeering and sex trafficking over the last 25 years. Nygard used company money, resources "to recruit and maintain adult and minor-aged female victims" in the US, Canada and the Bahamas to sexually gratify himself and his associates, the US authorities claimed. Nygard has denied any wrongdoing.

column3: Pak Prez approves new law for speedy trials, castration of rapists
column4: Pakistan President Arif Alvi on Tuesday signed a new anti-rape law, which allows chemical castration of rapists and speeding up of rape convictions. The law requires special fast-track courts to conclude the trials of alleged rapists and issue verdicts within four months. The move follows outcry over the gang rape of a woman in front of her children in September.

column3: Bolsonaro congratulates Biden, says 'ready to work with you'
column4: Brazilian President Jair Bolsonaro, one of the closest allies of US President Donald Trump, congratulated President-elect Joe Biden after the Electoral College formally confirmed his victory in the Presidential elections. Bolsonaro said he is "ready to work" with Biden and "continue to build a Brazil-USA alliance". Earlier, Bolsonaro had alleged "there was a lot of fraud" in the US election.

column3: Bihar Cabinet approves free coronavirus vaccine for all in state
column4: Bihar Cabinet on Tuesday approved a proposal to provide free COVID-19 vaccine to all the people of the state. "Our decision is a big gift to people of the state after formation of the government," Deputy Chief Minister Tarkishore Prasad said. The Cabinet also decided to generate 20 lakh jobs in government and non-government sectors in the next five years.

column3: BJP leaders sitting on strike broke CCTV cameras at Delhi CM's house: CMO
column4: BJP leaders sitting on strike in front of Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal's residence broke CCTV cameras installed at his house, CMO said on Sunday. This comes as Mayors of Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD) and leaders continue their demonstration outside the CM's residence, demanding MCD's due of ₹13,000 crore from the Delhi government.

column3: I'll observe 1-day fast in support of farmers, urge public to fast too: Delhi CM
column4: Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal on Sunday said that he would be observing a one-day fast on Monday in support of the farmers protesting against the new farm laws. He also appealed to AAP workers and supporters and the public to observe the fast as well. Earlier, he had visited the Singhu Border to show his support to the farmers.

column3: BJP President JP Nadda tests positive for coronavirus, goes into home-isolation
column4: BJP National President JP Nadda on Sunday announced that he has tested positive for coronavirus. "My health is fine, and I'm following all the guidelines of home-isolation on the advice of doctors. Whoever has come in contact with me in the last few days, I request them to isolate themselves and get themselves checked," he tweeted.

column3: Detractors in Congress denied Sharad Pawar PM post twice: Praful Patel
column4: On two occasions NCP chief Sharad Pawar had opportunity to become PM but was denied the post by his detractors in Congress, said NCP's Praful Patel. "After Rajiv Gandhi's unfortunate death...There was a demand to make Pawar party president...but some drawing room politicians conspired to block this," said Patel. "They didn't want strong leadership for the party," he added.

column3: PM lights Swarnim Vijay Mashaal to mark start of 50th anniversary of 1971 war win
column4: PM Narendra Modi on Wednesday lit up 'Swarnim Vijay Mashaal' at National War Memorial, marking the beginning of the 50th anniversary year of India's victory over Pakistan in 1971 war. Four Victory Mashaals lit from Eternal Flame will be carried to various parts of India including to villages of Param Vir Chakra and Maha Vir Chakra awardees of 1971 war.

column3: Startup uses Tharoor's caricature in ad without consent; MP takes legal action
column4: Edtech startup Mastree used MP Shashi Tharoor's caricature without his consent for their advertisement with caption, "Gift your child Shashi Tharoor's confidence." Tharoor has sought a public apology and a legally binding commitment to 'cease and desist such practices'. "I was shocked...of their advertising using my name and caricature as if to imply I had endorsed their courses," Tharoor said.

column3: Shah said govt can't buy all crops at MSP: Bhartiya Kisan Union chief
column4: Bhartiya Kisan Union (Haryana) President Gurnam Singh Chaduni has said that the Centre was misleading on minimum support price (MSP). He added Home Minister Amit Shah said the government cannot buy all 23 crops at MSP as it would cost ₹17 lakh crore. Chaduni said that the Centre would continue to buy the crops at the same amount as before.

column3: After attack on Nadda's convoy, Kailash Vijayvargiya gets bulletproof car
column4: BJP National General Secretary Kailash Vijayvargiya has been provided with a bulletproof vehicle by the Centre, days after he came under attack while travelling with party chief JP Nadda in West Bengal. In the December 10 attack, several vehicles in Nadda's cavalcade were damaged. Stones were pelted at the convoy at Diamond Harbour in South 24 Parganas district of Bengal.

column3: BJP wins 32 out of 49 seats in Goa Zilla Panchayat polls, Cong wins 4
column4: The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in Goa on Monday made big gains in the Zilla Panchayat elections, winning 32 out of 49 seats on offer. The Congress won four seats in the polls, while the NCP and the AAP bagged one seat each. The AAP has won its first-ever seat in an election in the coastal state.

column3: EC seeks Kerala CM's explanation on free COVID-19 vaccine announcement
column4: Kerala State Election Commission has sought an explanation from Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan for allegedly violating the model code of conduct by saying that the COVID-19 vaccine would be made available free of cost in the state. Vijayan had made the announcement on Saturday shortly before campaigning for the third phase of local bodies polls came to a close.

column3: India being tested, will meet the challenge: EAM on China standoff
column4: External Affairs Minister S Jaishankar has said India was being tested in the seven-month-long border standoff with China in eastern Ladakh. He also added that he was confident that India would meet the national security challenge. He further added that what happened in eastern Ladakh was not actually in China's interest as it has significantly impacted public sentiment in India.

column3: Cong MLCs manhandle, remove K'taka Legislative Council Dy Chairman
column4: Congress MLCs on Tuesday manhandled and forcefully removed Deputy Chairman SL Dharmegowda from the chair in Karnataka Legislative Council. Congress MLC Prakash Rathod said BJP and JD(S) made him sit illegally when the House was not in order and therefore they evicted him. BJP MLC Lehar Singh Siroya said, "We've never seen such a shameful day in our Council's history."

column3: AAP to contest UP elections in 2022: Arvind Kejriwal
column4: Aam Aadmi Party chief and Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal has said the party will contest the state elections in Uttar Pradesh in 2022. "A lot of people from UP who live in Delhi have told us that UP too deserves the welfare and benefits like Delhi," he added. He also said that all parties in UP have betrayed the people.

column3: BJP launched campaign to divide farmers, defame movement: Akhilesh
column4: Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav on Tuesday said that the farmers are agitating for the past 20 days and instead of listening to them, the government has adopted a stubborn attitude. He added, "Not only this, but the BJP has also launched a campaign to divide farmers and discredit the movement and defame it."

column3: COVID-19 +ve Haryana minister Anil Vij shifted to Gurugram hospital
column4: Haryana minister Anil Vij, who had tested positive for COVID-19, was shifted to Medanta hospital in Gurugram from Rohtak's Post Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences on Tuesday. A doctor said, "The Health Minister has been diagnosed with COVID-19 pneumonia, leading to infection in lungs." Vij had got one shot of the two-dose trial of the COVID-19 vaccine Covaxin last month.

column3: Assam cabinet clears proposal to shut govt-run madrassas, Sanskrit tols
column4: The Assam cabinet on Sunday approved the proposal to shut down all-government-run madrassas and Sanskrit tols (schools). The decision was taken during the cabinet meeting chaired by Assam Chief Minister Sarbananda Sonowal. The Bill regarding the proposal will be tabled in the upcoming winter session of the state Assembly, the state's Parliamentary Affairs Minister Chandra Mohan Patowary said.

column3: Congress wins 620 seats in municipal body polls in Rajasthan
column4: Congress won 620 seats in the polls for the 50 municipal bodies in Rajasthan. The State Election Commission on Sunday released the results of the general election. Out of 1,775 wards of all the bodies, 620 candidates of Congress, 548 of BJP, seven of BSP, two each of CPI and CPI (M), one of RLP and 595 Independent candidates won.

column3: Assam's BTC poll results show people's faith in PM's leadership: Nadda
column4: BJP President JP Nadda said that Assam's Bodoland Territorial Council (BTC) poll results show people's faith in leadership and policies of PM Narendra Modi. He also congratulated NDA partner UPPL, Assam CM Sarbananda Sonowal and other state BJP leaders for "securing clear majority". While BJP has won nine seats, UPPL has won 12 seats in the polls.

column3: Cong mayor candidate loses by 1 vote to BJP opponent in Kerala local body polls
column4: Congress mayoral candidate N Venugopal lost to BJP candidate by one vote in Kochi Corporation North Island ward in Kerala's local body elections. "There was problem with the voting machine. That may be reason for BJP's victory," Venugopal said. "I haven't decided to go to court with the voting machine issue so far. Will check what happened exactly," he added.

column3: BJP leaders' statements on farmers' protest condemnable: Gehlot
column4: Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot on Monday said that BJP leaders' statements criticising farmers' protest are "most unfortunate and condemnable". "The government must find an amicable solution and address the grievances of farmers sympathetically instead of blaming gangs, anti-national elements for these protests," Gehlot said. "The farm laws...must be taken back," he added.

column3: 100 BJP workers booked for organising 'welcome rally' in Gr Noida
column4: Police have registered a case against over 100 BJP workers for allegedly organising an unauthorised rally in Greater Noida on Sunday. Police said the "welcome rally" was allegedly for newly appointed party functionary Pandit Ashish Vats. "Vats, along with a group of BJP workers, reached the toll plaza in eight to 10 cars...[which] violated social distancing norms," the Sub-Inspector said.

column3: CPI, CPI(M) leaders protest in Hyderabad against farm laws
column4: CPI and CPI(M) leaders, among other Left party leaders in Telangana, on Monday protested in Hyderabad against the government's three new farm laws. They held placards demanding abrogation of the three "pro-corporate" farm laws and boycott of certain big corporates. Senior Congress leader V Hanumantha Rao observed a fast from 10 am to 4 pm at his residence in Hyderabad.

column3: Kolkata Municipal Corporation polls likely in March 2021: Official
column4: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) elections​ are likely to be held in March 2021, senior officials of West Bengal State Election Commission said. "As per the Supreme Court's directive, the state government has sent a communication to us saying that the KMC polls may be held within four weeks after the final electoral roll is adopted," an official said.

column3: Why should protests take place in America & London for farmers?: MoS
column4: Union Minister of State for Home Affairs G Kishan Reddy on Monday said that why should demonstrations take place in America, Canada and London in support of farmers' protests happening in India. He added, "Who is behind this? Some people want to carry out anti-India activities by misusing your (farmers') name. I request farmers to remain vigilant."

column3: Who are the world's top 10 highest-paid celebrities of 2020 as per Forbes?
column4: Kylie Jenner ($590 million earnings) has topped Forbes' list of 2020's 100 highest-paid celebrities. She's followed by her brother-in-law Kanye West ($170 million earnings). Roger Federer ($106.3 million), Cristiano Ronaldo ($105 million) and Lionel Messi ($104 million) made it to top 5. Others in top 10 include Neymar ($95.5 million), Howard Stern ($90 million) and Dwayne Johnson ($87.5 million).

column3: Brother of Arjun Rampal's girlfriend granted bail in drug case
column4: A special NDPS court on Tuesday granted bail to Agisilaos Demetriades, the brother of actor Arjun Rampal's girlfriend Gabriella, in connection with a drug case related to Sushant Singh Rajput's death case. He was arrested by the Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) on October 18. Agisilaos was in touch with other drug peddlers related to the case, NCB had said.

column3: 52-yr-old Josh Brolin shares nude pic, fans say 'Thanos has a retirement plan'
column4: Josh Brolin, who played 'Thanos', shared his nude picture, taken by wife Kathryn Brolin. "At the end of the day a life will [be] judged by how often you were naked. Nobody told they meant metaphorically," the 52-year-old wrote. "Thanos has a retirement plan," a user commented while another wrote, "What Thanos really did at the end of 'Infinity War'."

column3: If I see it again, you're f***ing gone: Cruise to film crew on COVID-19 rule breach
column4: In a leaked audio, Tom Cruise can be heard screaming at crew members on 'Mission Impossible 7' sets over an apparent breach of COVID-19 rules. "We are creating thousands of jobs, you m***********s...If I see it again, you're f***ing gone," he said in the audio obtained by The Sun. "If...I can't deal with your logic, you're fired," Cruise added.

column3: Sona asked if tweet calling Utsav 'd**k-pic sharing idiot' was a campaign, she replies
column4: Sona Mohapatra responded to a Twitter user who asked her if she had been running a #MeToo campaign against comedian Utsav Chakraborty. "I've seen screenshots of the messages...Utsav used to share...Writing a tweet with...opinion isn't running a campaign. Keep your bulls**t in your corner," she wrote. In 2019, Sona had tweeted, "We've an idiot, d**k-pic sharing Utsav types gathering compassion."

column3: Sarabhai vs Sarabhai writer criticises Pak version, calls it 'daylight robbery'
column4: 'Sarabhai vs Sarabhai' writer Aatish Kapadia shared on Facebook that a "word to word" and "frame to frame" "unofficial" remake of the show is currently on air in Pakistan. "It has been shamelessly put on a free video streaming platform and the actors have performed my written word so badly," he added. Kapadia further called the remake a "daylight robbery".

column3: Sapna, who gave birth after secret wedding in January, shares 1st glimpse of son
column4: Haryanvi singer-dancer Sapna Choudhary, who gave birth to a baby boy in October after her secret wedding to Veer Sahu in January, took to Instagram to share the first glimpse of her son. In the picture, Sapna can be seen holding her son in her arms with his face hidden. Sapna had confirmed her wedding in November.

column3: Choreographer Ganesh Acharya reveals he has lost 98-kg weight
column4: Choreographer Ganesh Acharya, in a recent promo of 'The Kapil Sharma Show', revealed that he has lost 98-kg weight. In the promo, Kapil Sharma jokes, "Do aadmi gayab kar diye aapne." Earlier in an interview in 2017, Ganesh had revealed that his weight almost touched 200 kg in 2015 after he had gained weight for a movie.

column3: TV actor arrested in Mumbai for robbing elderly people by posing as policeman
column4: Firoz Jafari, a television actor, was arrested from his Mumbai residence for allegedly conning several senior citizens in Nagpur, Uttarakhand, Punjab and Uttar Pradesh into parting with their jewellery after posing as policeman. He allegedly posed in traffic junctions and cautioned his victims about fake robbery attempts. He'd then offer to place their jewellery safely in purse and rob them.

column3: Aanand L Rai to direct a biopic on Viswanathan Anand: Reports
column4: Aanand L Rai will reportedly direct a biopic based on the life of ex-world chess champion Viswanathan Anand. The yet-to-be-titled film will be produced by Rai's Colour Yellow Productions and Mahaveer Jain's Sundial Entertainment, film trade analyst Taran Adarsh tweeted. The filmmaker is currently shooting a romantic-drama titled 'Atrangi Re', which stars Sara Ali Khan, Dhanush and Akshay Kumar.

column3: He's been my greatest motivator: Shatrughan on Raj Kapoor's birth anniversary
column4: Taking to Twitter on Monday, Shatrughan Sinha shared a post on Raj Kapoor's 96th birth anniversary. He wrote, "Remembering with warmth & fondness the 1st & the best showman of Indian cinema, handsome, debonair, most talented actor, producer, director...#RajKapoor." Shatrughan added, "He has been my greatest motivator, role model as I grew up watching his brilliant craft."

column3: Arjun Rampal seeks time till Dec 21 to appear before NCB in drugs case
column4: Actor Arjun Rampal has sought time till December 21 to appear before Narcotics Control Bureau (NCB) in a drug-related case. Arjun was summoned by the NCB on December 16 for questioning in connection with the case. NCB had raided Arjun's residence and seized medicines which are controlled substances covered under the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances (NDPS) Act.

column3: Remo is humble, working with him was insane: Siddharth Gupta
column4: Siddharth Gupta, while sharing his experience of working with Remo D'Souza in the song 'Dil Na Todunga', said, "The experience...was insane!" He added that the choreographer-director gives the artistes enough space which makes it easy for them to give their best shot. "He's so humble which I believe is one of his best qualities," Siddharth further said.

column3: Sad that a deadly virus had to make us spend more time with families: Hina
column4: Actress Hina Khan, who took a trip to the Maldives with her parents amid the coronavirus pandemic, said, "It is so sad that a deadly virus had to exist to push us and make us pause our lives to spend more time with our families." She added, "I will continue to spend more time with them, though I do nevertheless."

column3: Never bothered about outcome: Kartik on Love Aaj Kal's performance
column4: Kartik Aaryan, on being asked how he handled the "dismal performance" of 'Love Aaj Kal', said, "I don't think I had to 'handle' anything." He added, "It has given me so much as an actor that I genuinely never bothered about the outcome." "A great box office performance would've been nice, but...below-average one doesn't bother me at all," Kartik said.

column3: Om Puri shot despite having typhoid: Wife on his last film Omprakash Zindabad
column4: Late actor Om Puri's last film 'Omprakash Zindabad' is set to release in theatres on December 18. Talking about the same, wife Nandita Puri said, "It feels good to see his last film release in theatres." She further said the film was shot five years ago, adding, "I remember him filming in Lucknow and despite having typhoid, finishing...shoot on time."

column3: Money only difference between Bengali & Hindi film industry: Jisshu
column4: Actor Jisshu Sengupta, who has starred in films like 'Durgamati: The Myth' and 'Sadak 2', talked about the difference between the Bengali and Hindi film industry and said, "The only difference between the two industries is money." He added, "It's the only thing because Bengal industry is smaller and Hindi has...international market. Other filming aspects of the entire production are...same."

column3: Television personality Sharon Osbourne tests positive for COVID-19
column4: Television personality Sharon Osbourne, known for co-hosting 'The Talk', revealed that she has tested positive for COVID-19. "After a brief hospitalisation, I'm now recuperating at a location away from Ozzy Osbourne (her husband)," Sharon tweeted. She added that Ozzy has tested negative for the coronavirus infection. Sharon further wrote that 'The Talk' is on "scheduled hiatus".

column3: Happy taking the risk: Vikas on releasing 'The Last...' in theatres amid COVID-19
column4: Filmmaker-chef Vikas Khanna, whose directorial debut 'The Last Color' released in theatres amid the coronavirus pandemic, has said he was very clear about the release strategy. "The number of jobs that you create when you release a film in theatres was the bigger priority for me. And I'm happy about taking that risk," he added. The film stars Neena Gupta.

column3: Nawazuddin's brother seeks anticipatory bail in child molestation case
column4: Actor Nawazuddin Siddiqui's youngest brother Minazuddin Siddiqui has moved a POCSO court in Mumbai seeking anticipatory bail in a case of alleged molestation of a minor girl. The hearing on the matter will take place on Wednesday. The case, alleging the molestation of a minor child in 2012, was filed by the Nawazuddin's estranged wife Aaliya on July 27.

column3: Waking up every morning with my mother makes me happy: Sara on lockdown
column4: Sara Ali Khan said that COVID-19 lockdown made her realise that waking up every morning with her mother (Amrita Singh) makes her happy. "Sitting at home for nine months can be difficult for someone as ambitious as me," she added. "I used to have 500 things [to do], believing that [achieving them] will make me happy," Sara further said.

column3: I'll only do positive roles now, no more villain roles: Sonu Sood
column4: Sonu Sood has said he'll only do positive and author-backed roles now. "Lots of changes have happened in my life in...last one year...As far as my career as...actor is concerned, no more villain roles," he added. "I'm being offered many good roles. I need to work out...time frame to do at least a couple of films a year," said Sonu.

column3: Haven't watched many web shows, I prefer to watch news: Sidharth
column4: Actor Sidharth Shukla, who will make his digital platform debut with the upcoming third season of 'Broken But Beautiful' web series, revealed that he prefers watching the news over web-shows. Speaking about the first two seasons of the series, which starred Vikrant Massey, he told Mid-Day, "I haven't had the time to watch the show...I know that it was...successful."

column3: Biopic on Major Dhyan Chand announced, film to release in 2022
column4: A biopic on hockey legend Major Dhyan Chand has been announced and it'll be directed by Abhishek Chaubey, who previously helmed films like 'Sonchiriya' and 'Udta Punjab'. The film, which is scheduled to release in 2022, will be produced by Ronnie Screwvala and co-produced by Premnath Rajagopalan. Talking about the project, Abhishek said, "It's...matter of pride to direct his biopic."

column3: I feared I'll remain unknown: Manikarnika director on feud with Kangana
column4: Commenting on his feud with Kangana Ranaut, 'Manikarnika: The Queen of Jhansi' director Radha Krishna Jagarlamudi (Krish) said his only fear was that he would remain unknown to the world. Krish had alleged in 2019 that Kangana wrongly claimed credit as the director of the film and "hijacked" his movie. Krish was speaking on Samantha Akkineni's show 'Sam Jam'.

column3: Own a car without buying it : Revv Subscriptions
column4: You can now drive a new car every month as Revv provides the option to subscribe to your favourite car for 1-36 months with ₹0 down payment, ₹0 road tax and without the hassle of maintenance and service. The car will be sanitized and delivered to your doorstep ensuring complete safety for you and your loved ones.

column3: Tesla's market value crosses $500 bn as shares surge six-fold this year
column4: Tesla Inc crossed $500 billion in market value on Tuesday as its share price surged six-fold this year. Tesla's shares rose as much as 3.9% to a record high of $542.35 in early trading. CEO Elon Musk has added $100.3 billion to his net worth so far this year, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.

column3: Auto industry lost ₹2,300cr a day in lockdown: Parliamentary panel
column4: The automotive industry suffered ₹2,300 crore loss per day during the COVID-19 lockdown, according to a parliamentary panel report submitted to Rajya Sabha Chairman M Venkaiah Naidu. The sector witnessed an estimated job loss of about 3.45 lakh, the report said. All major original equipment manufacturers (OEM) cut down their production by 18-20% due to low demand, it added.

column3: Baidu becomes 1st to get fully driverless road tests permit in Beijing
column4: Baidu has become the first to receive permits by the Beijing transportation authorities for five of its vehicles to conduct fully driverless road tests. It plans to remove safety drivers from test vehicles after gradually reducing human intervention. However, a remote safety operator will still be able to take control in an emergency via Baidu's 5G Remote Driving Service.

column3: Tesla asked to give ₹1 cr to used car buyer for hiding damage in China
column4: Tesla was ordered by a Chinese court to pay over ₹1 crore to the buyer of a used Model S car after concluding it concealed structural damage on the vehicle it sold on its official website. It was reportedly discovered part of the vehicle had been cut and welded back together. Tesla will appeal the ruling to a higher court.

column3: US startup claims to have made 1st 'no charging' solar EV
column4: US-based Aptera Motors has introduced the "first solar electric vehicle" that requires "no charging" for most daily use and has a range of up to over 1,600 kilometres per full charge. Every Aptera is designed to harvest enough sunlight to travel over 17,702 kilometres per year in most regions. Liquid-cooled electric motors propel Aptera from 0-100 kilometres/hour in 3.5 seconds.

column3: Amazon's Zoox unveils autonomous EV that can travel both ways
column4: Amazon-owned self-driving car platform Zoox has unveiled a fully autonomous electric vehicle with no steering wheel which can travel in either direction. Equipped with two battery packs, the four-seater robotaxi can run for 16 hours on a single charge and can attain a maximum speed of 120 kmph. CEO Aicha Evans said Zoox plans on launching an app-based ride-hailing service.

column3: US govt opens probe into 1.15L Tesla vehicles over suspension issue
column4: The US NHTSA opened an investigation into around 1.15 lakh Tesla vehicles over a front suspension safety issue. It said it was opening a preliminary evaluation into 2015-2017 Model S and 2016-2017 Model X vehicles after receiving 43 complaints alleging failure of the left or right front suspension fore links. "The complaints appear to indicate an increasing trend," NHTSA said.

column3: Apple CFO, Apple's ex-design chief candidates for Ferrari CEO: Report
column4: Apple CFO Luca Maestri and former Chief Design Officer Jony Ive are reportedly candidates to be Ferrari's next CEO, Reuters reported. Ferrari CEO Louis Camilleri announced his retirement earlier due to "personal reasons". Former Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao was allegedly in the running for the position too, but Reuters said a source close to Colao has called the claim "groundless".

column3: Govt to set up 69,000 EV charging points across India: Gadkari
column4: Road Transport and Highways Minister Nitin Gadkari said the government is planning to set up at least one e-charging kiosk at around 69,000 petrol pumps across the country to induce people to go for electric vehicles (EVs). Gadkari had asked industry stakeholders to work towards making India an EV hub by 2025. GST on EVs has been reduced to 5%.

column3: Tesla reveals women comprise 17% of its total US leadership roles
column4: Tesla revealed in its first-ever US diversity report that women comprise 17% of the company's leadership roles and 21% of the overall workforce. It added that Black people make up 4% of its US leadership roles and 10% of its total workforce. "While women are historically underrepresented...we recognise we have work to do in this area," Tesla said.

column3: Musk asks Tesla staff to push output to max possible through Dec: Report
column4: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has sent an email to workers encouraging them to push output to the maximum possible through December, Bloomberg reported. "We are fortunate to have the high-class problem of demand being quite a bit higher than production this quarter," the report quoted Musk. The company has a target of delivering 5 lakh cars this year.

column3: Tesla teams to visit Indonesia to discuss investment in EV components
column4: Tesla will send delegations to Indonesia next month to discuss potential investment in a supply chain for its electric vehicles. Government officials and Tesla CEO Elon Musk have discussed investment opportunities in Indonesia over a call. Indonesia earlier pointed out it has the "biggest" nickel reserves. Musk plans to offer a "giant contract for a long period of time".

column3: General Motors to not acquire 11% stake in Nikola
column4: General Motors (GM) and Nikola on Monday announced a reworked deal that replaced their previous agreement under which GM would acquire 11% equity stake in the startup and produce the proposed electric pickup Badger. The companies have instead signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding which is subject to negotiation. Nikola was previously accused of fraud by a short seller.

column3: Apple moves self-driving car unit under exec who oversees Siri: Report
column4: Apple has moved its self-driving car unit under the leadership of John Giannandrea, Senior Vice President of Machine Learning and AI Strategy, who also oversees the development of Apple's virtual assistant Siri, Bloomberg reported. Apple began working on its autonomous car project, known as Titan, in 2014. CEO Tim Cook in 2017 called autonomous systems "mother of all AI projects".

column3: Battery-operated bikes to be included in Delhi's EV policy: Report
column4: Delhi's EV policy is being revised to include a segment on battery-operated bicycles and tricycles, HT reported. The government has drafted a proposal to offer monetary incentives on their purchase. The proposed revision includes cycles both in the passenger and cargo categories. In case of individual buyers, purchase incentive will be 25% of the MRP with a cap of ₹5,000.

column3: Tesla to shut down production of Model S, X for 18 days: Report
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla will shut down the production of its high-end Model S and Model X electric vehicles from December 24 to January 11 in Fremont, California, CNBC reported. Employees will be given a full week's pay along with few paid holidays. Deliveries of these models amounted to only 11% of total vehicle deliveries during Tesla's third quarter of 2020.

column3: Volkswagen CEO reveals they began 'Mission T' to catch up with Tesla
column4: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess, in a blog post, revealed he organised a three-day workshop nicknamed 'Mission T' to discuss how they could "catch up with Tesla". He added that they brought 31 senior executives from Volkswagen, Audi and Porsche together amid the COVID-19 pandemic to discuss how they could further their Project Artemis to take on Tesla.

column3: Mahindra's Korean unit SsangYong defaults on $55 million loan
column4: Automaker Mahindra & Mahindra's South Korean unit SsangYong Motor Company has defaulted on loan repayment of about $55 million. Around $27.5 million was owed to Bank of America, $18.3 million to JP Morgan Chase and $9.1 million to BNP Paribas on December 14. Mahindra has been looking for a buyer for all or most of its 75% stake since June.

column3: Delhi govt launches forum to discuss electric vehicle policy
column4: Delhi government on Friday launched the 'Delhi EV Forum', a common platform for multiple stakeholders to hold discussions on the government's electric vehicle (EV) policy. "Delhi EV Forum will be the first such forum in India...The first meeting will be held virtually on December 18," Delhi DDC Vice Chairperson said. The policy's objective is to combat air pollution in Delhi.

column3: Hyundai, Kia agree to $210M US penalty for delay in vehicles' recall
column4: Hyundai and Kia Motors have agreed to $140 million and $70 million civil penalties, respectively, after US auto safety regulators said they delayed recall of 1.6 million vehicles for engine issues. The settlement covers recall in 2015 and 2017 for manufacturing issues. Kia denied the allegations but agreed to settle the matter to "avoid a protracted dispute with the government".

column3: Workers of Toyota unit near B'luru to continue strike over workload
column4: Factory workers at Toyota Kirloskar Private Limited's Bidadi unit, located near Bengaluru, announced that they will continue their ongoing strike over increased workload, among other concerns. They said that they don't get time to drink water or use the washroom. The unit has been in a lockout since November 10, after 41 workers were suspended for allegedly questioning the management.

column3: Tesla would consider buying a legacy automaker on friendly terms: Musk
column4: Tesla would consider leveraging the company's $554 billion market capitalisation to buy a legacy automaker, CEO Elon Musk said in an interview with Axel Springer. "We're definitely not going to launch a hostile takeover," Musk said. "If somebody said, 'Hey, we think it would be a good idea to merge with Tesla,' we certainly could have that conversation," he added.

column3: Tesla to raise $5 billion as market cap crosses $600 billion
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla on Tuesday announced that it will be raising $5 billion, marking its second capital raise in the last three months. The additional shares will be sold "from time to time" and "at-the-market" prices. Its shares are up nearly 670% this year with its market capitalisation crossing $600 billion. Tesla will join S&P 500 index later this month.

column3: Aus vaccine trial scrapped as participants returned false +ve HIV test results
column4: The University of Queensland and pharmaceutical company CSL have abandoned the clinical trial of their COVID-19 vaccine after several participants returned false positive HIV test results. CSL said the vaccine was safe and was proving effective, but that significant changes would be needed to HIV testing procedures in the healthcare setting to accommodate the rollout of the vaccine.

column3: Five genes linked to most severe form of COVID-19 found
column4: Scientists in the UK have identified five genes that are linked with the most severe form of COVID-19. The genes partially explain why some people become extremely sick with COVID-19, while others are not affected, according to their study. "Our results immediately highlight which drugs should be at the top of the list for clinical testing," a scientist said.

column3: AstraZeneca to test combining Oxford vaccine with Sputnik V vaccine
column4: AstraZeneca, which is developing a coronavirus vaccine with Oxford University, said it would investigate combining its vaccine with Russia's Sputnik V vaccine. "Being able to combine different vaccines may be helpful to improve protection and/or to improve vaccine accessibility," AstraZeneca said. A 'mix and match' trial between AstraZeneca and Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccines was announced earlier.

column3: India's 1st mRNA vaccine candidate gets DCGI nod for human trials
column4: India's first indigenous mRNA vaccine candidate has received approval to initiate Phase 1 and 2 human clinical trials from Drugs Controller General of India (DCGI). Pune-based Gennova Biopharmaceuticals developed the COVID-19 vaccine candidate, HGCO19, in collaboration with US-based HDT Bio. The vaccine demonstrated "safety and immunogenicity" in rodent and non-human primate models, Gennova said.

column3: Indian-American Raja Chari selected by NASA to fly to ISS on SpaceX mission
column4: Indian-American astronaut Raja Chari has been selected by NASA alongside two other astronauts to fly to the International Space Station (ISS) on SpaceX Crew-3 mission in 2021. It'll be the first spaceflight for Chari and Matthias Maurer, and the third for NASA astronaut Tom Marshburn. Raja Chari is the only Indian-American among 18 astronauts selected for NASA's Moon mission.

column3: Pics of 2020's last solar eclipse seen in parts of the world surface online
column4: Pictures of the last solar eclipse of 2020, witnessed on December 14, have surfaced online. The total solar eclipse was visible for people living in parts of Chile and Argentina. In some parts of South America, south-west Africa and Antarctica, people witnessed a partial solar eclipse. The total solar eclipse was not visible from India.

column3: Human-made objects to outweigh living things by the end of 2020: Study
column4: Scientists have said that the weight of human-made objects will likely exceed that of living things by the end of the year. In a study published in the scientific journal Nature, scientists compared the overall living biomass on Earth, estimated to be around 1.1 teratonnes, to human-made mass. "We find that Earth is exactly at the crossover point," they said.

column3: Humanity will face 60°C temperatures in 2050s, warns WEF
column4: As many as two billion people will face 60°C temperatures for more than a tenth of the year in the 2050s, the World Economic Forum (WEF) warned citing a book. Up to 140 million people are expected to be displaced by 2050 because of food and water insecurity as well as extreme weather, it further said quoting the World Bank.

column3: NASA shares images of supermassive black holes merging
column4: NASA has shared images of two supermassive black holes in Galaxy NGC 6240 which are in the process of merging. "Seen as the bright dots near the center of this image, the black holes are just 3,000 light years apart," it said. "Eventually they will drift together, forming a larger black hole millions of years from now," NASA added.

column3: Japan finds pieces of asteroid inside space capsule that returned to Earth
column4: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency has found pieces of an asteroid inside a space capsule delivered by the Hayabusa2 space probe. The capsule was recovered in Australia on December 6, following its journey through space. The Japanese probe collected surface dust last year from the asteroid Ryugu, around 300 million kilometres away, during two phases of its six-year mission.

column3: Videos of Geminids meteor shower surface online
column4: Videos of the Geminids meteor shower, recognised as the best annual meteor shower a stargazer can see, have surfaced online. According to NASA, the Geminids travel 78,000 mph (35 km/s). The parent of the Geminids is 3200 Phaethon, which is arguably considered to be either an asteroid or an extinct comet, NASA said.

column3: 1st known case of COVID-19 in non-captive wild mink found in US
column4: The first known case of COVID-19 in a non-captive wild mink has been confirmed, according to an alert issued by the US Department of Agriculture. The wild mink tested positive around an infected mink farm in Utah. The strain of the virus in the wild mink is "indistinguishable" from that in infected mink on farms around the state.

column3: Delhi startup builds tech to do COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 cr samples per week
column4: Delhi-based IT startup Thalamus Irwine claims to have developed an artificial intelligence and IoT-based solution that can complete a COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 crore samples in one week. It has also partnered with state-run ITI to host its data. Serosurveys can help track the geographic spread of the virus by analysing antibodies in blood samples.

column3: Researchers develop first AI tool to detect COVID-19 probability
column4: A team of researchers from the University of Vermont and Cedars-Sinai has developed the first software to predict the probability of COVID-19 infections. AI-COVID uses details from routine blood tests and can assign the probability of a patient being COVID-19 negative with high accuracy. This can help hospitals reduce the number of patients referred for PCR testing.

column3: Scientists digitally rebuild dinosaur's brain, learn about its diet
column4: The University of Bristol's scientists have "rebuilt" the brain of a Thecodontosaurus, that roamed England some 205 million years ago, using advanced imaging and 3D modelling techniques. They said unlike its plant-eating relatives, Thecodontosaurus may have eaten meat and could have walked on two legs. Experts also reconstructed its inner ears and estimated that it had a high hearing frequency.

column3: India to soon be manufacturing hub of space assets: PM Modi to space industry
column4: Prime Minister Narendra Modi in his interaction with the space sector's key industries, startups and academia expressed that India will soon become a manufacturing hub of space assets. He also assured participants that they will be co-passengers with ISRO in this age of space research. He added that private investment in the sector will lead to creation of hi-tech jobs.

column3: Superhighway system to travel via Solar System faster discovered: Scientists
column4: UC San Diego revealed researchers have discovered a new "superhighway" network to travel through the Solar System much faster. Such routes can drive comets and asteroids near Jupiter to Neptune in less than 10 years. Scientists found the routes by computing how "millions" of Solar System orbits fit within already-known space manifolds.

column3: India not historically responsible for climate change: Javadekar
column4: Environment Minister Prakash Javadekar has said India is not historically responsible for climate change but is taking steps to reduce emissions. He said India is the only G20 nation to be in compliance with the Paris Agreement. India has already achieved 21% of its target of reducing emissions intensity of GDP by 33%-35% by 2030, he added.

column3: Bacteria can travel between continents via dust, impact climate: Study
column4: A study by scientists, including those from the University of Granada, revealed bacteria can travel between continents "hidden" in atmospheric dust. These microbes may not only affect human and animal health but also impact climate and ecosystems. Their transport occurs via atmospheric particles called iberulites that humans can inhale. These aerosols act like a "launch vehicle" for bacteria.

column3: SL records 2nd-highest human deaths due to conflict with elephant: Report
column4: Sri Lanka has recorded the second-highest human deaths due to the human-elephant conflict in the world after India, Daily News reported. Sri Lanka's COPA revealed the number of human deaths has increased from an average of 85 humans to 122 per year in the past 12 months in Sri Lanka. However, it has recorded the highest number of elephant deaths.

column3: New salamander species added to US' North Carolina's list of 63 species
column4: The US' North Carolina State added a new salamander species to its list of 63 species. The 'Carolina Sandhills Salamander' was previously categorised as an unusual population of the 'Southern Two-lined Salamander'. However, researchers used sequencing technology to show that the new species differs genetically. It also differs in colouration, size and natural history from complex's other members.

column3: China to open world's largest radio telescope to int'l scientists
column4: China will open the world's largest radio telescope for use by foreign astronomers. The Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST) has a diameter of half a kilometre and a receiving area equivalent to about 30 football fields. China has said it will accept requests in 2021 from foreign scientists wishing to carry out measurements.

column3: Corals from Aus' 'Coral IVF' trial survive bleaching, on track to reproduce
column4: Coral populations from Australia's first "Coral IVF" trial on the Great Barrier Reef in 2016 have survived bleaching events and are on track to reproduce next year. Scientists said the larvae restoration technique worked just as they predicted and large corals can grow from tiny microscopic larvae within few years. The technique was first used just off Heron Island.

column3: Declare a State of Climate Emergency in your nations: UN to leaders
column4: World leaders should declare "States of Climate Emergency" in their countries until carbon neutrality is reached, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said at a climate summit. "Can anybody still deny that we are facing a dramatic emergency?" he asked. He added G20 members are spending 50% more in their stimulus packages on fossil fuel-linked sectors and consumption, than on low-carbon energy.

column3: IUCN lists 31 species as 'Extinct', European Bison sees recovery
column4: The IUCN released an update of its Red List of Threatened Species which moved 31 species into the 'Extinct' category. However, the European Bison has moved from 'Vulnerable' to 'Near Threatened' category. Besides this, all of the world's freshwater dolphin species are now listed as threatened on the list. The lost shark has entered the 'Critically Endangered' (Possibly Extinct) category.

column3: ISRO successfully launches India's 42nd communication satellite CMS-01
column4: The ISRO on Thursday successfully launched India's 42nd communication satellite from Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC) SHAR, Sriharikota. The PSLV-C50 launch vehicle put the communication satellite CMS-01 in orbit, that will provide coverage for disaster management and satellite internet connection. It's the first one in a new series of communication satellites after the INSAT and the GSAT series.

column3: Brazilian filmmaker drops iPhone from plane, it survives 300m drop & records free fall
column4: According to Brazilian media outlet G1's report, Brazilian documentary filmmaker Ernesto Galiotto dropped his iPhone 6s from a small plane's window accidentally while trying to capture a video. Galiotto claimed he found the phone near a beach by using GPS tracking and discovered it had survived the 300-metre drop. The phone had also recorded a video of the free fall.

column3: Fake call centre that cheated 4,500 foreigners of ₹90 crore busted in Delhi
column4: Delhi Police busted a fake call centre where employees posed as personnel from law enforcement agencies and extorted money from foreigners saying that their details were found at crime scenes. The police made 54 arrests in connection with the call centre that cheated 4,500 foreigners of ₹90 crore. The mastermind of the fake call centre was allegedly operating from Dubai.

column3: Bitcoin price surpasses $20,000 for the first time
column4: The price of Bitcoin surpassed $20,000 for the first time on Wednesday, its highest ever. The cryptocurrency's price jumped 4.5% to move as high as $20,440. Bitcoin has gained more than 170% this year over demand from larger investors attracted to its potential for quick gains, purported inflation-resistant qualities, and expectations that it will become a mainstream payment method.

column3: No permission given for relaunch of PUBG Mobile in India: Govt
column4: The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology in a response to an RTI query by GEM Esports clarified that the government has given "no permission" for the relaunch of PUBG Mobile app in the country. Earlier, reports claimed that PUBG Mobile made specifically for Indian public will be launched. PUBG Mobile was among several apps banned by government in September.

column3: Govt to publish list of 'trusted sources' for purchase of telecom equipment
column4: The Cabinet on Wednesday approved the setting up of a national security directive on telecommunication sector, Union IT Minister Ravi Shankar Prasad said. Under the directive, the government will declare a list of trusted sources from whom telecommunications companies can procure equipment. The list will be prepared "to maintain the integrity of the supply chain security", the government said.

column3: Twitter to remove misleading tweets on COVID-19 vaccinations
column4: Twitter has said that starting next week, it will ask users to remove tweets that spread "false or misleading narratives about COVID-19 vaccinations". This rule will apply to tweets falsely claiming conspiracies, such as coronavirus vaccines are used to "intentionally cause harm to or control populations", or theories about adverse impacts of receiving vaccinations that have been widely debunked.

column3: Putting OTT under I&B aimed to bring content in one place: I&B Secy
column4: The idea behind government's move to bring OTT and content platforms under the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (I&B) was to bring content at one place while keeping platforms at another, I&B Ministry Secretary Amit Khare said. "I am clarifying this because...there used to be a discussion that online and offline content should not be treated differently," Khare added.

column3: Facebook claims Apple's iOS changes are bad for businesses in ads in US
column4: Facebook on Wednesday took out a series of full-page newspaper advertisements in US claiming Apple's mobile software changes are bad for small businesses. The ads targeted Apple's upcoming changes to its iOS 14 that prevent companies from gathering user data and using them for advertising. "We're standing up to Apple for small businesses everywhere," the headline of the ads said.

column3: Twitter shares hit 6-yr-high after JPMorgan upgrades its rating
column4: Shares of Twitter soared as much as 6% on Wednesday to record a six-year-high of $56.11 since October 2014 after JPMorgan upgraded its rating to "Overweight" from "Neutral". "We believe Twitter will show the biggest rebound [in online advertising] given its sharper pandemic-driven ad decline," JPMorgan said. Twitter shares are up more than 70% in 2020.

column3: US board condemns naming local hospital after Mark Zuckerberg, his wife
column4: US' San Francisco Board of Supervisors has passed a resolution condemning the naming of a local hospital after Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Dr Priscilla Chan, alleging Facebook "endangered public health" by allowing misinformation to spread. The hospital was renamed the Priscilla Chan and Mark Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center after they donated $75 million.

column3: Google wins EU approval for $2.1 billion Fitbit deal
column4: Google on Thursday won the European Union's antitrust approval for its $2.1 billion bid for Fitbit after it agreed to certain restrictions. Google pledged to maintain access for rival fitness and health apps and devices for 10 years. It also agreed to store the Fitbit user data separately from the Google data and to not use it for Google Ads.

column3: Google faces 3rd antitrust lawsuit by US states over abuse of power
column4: A group of US State Attorneys General filed a lawsuit against Google on Wednesday for "anticompetitive conduct, exclusionary practices, and deceptive misrepresentations". This lawsuit focuses on Google's real-time auctions for ads. "Google repeatedly used its monopolistic powers to control pricing" and "engage in market collusions to rig auctions," Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton wrote.

column3: Parliamentary panel questions FB's alleged inaction against Bajrang Dal
column4: Facebook India head Ajit Mohan appeared before a Parliamentary panel on Wednesday over the issue of citizens' data safety. Congress MP Shashi Tharoor-led panel questioned Mohan about a Wall Street Journal report which alleged that Facebook did not ban the right-wing nationalist organisation, Bajrang Dal, over concerns of risk to its business and employees, PTI reported.

column3: Twitter ends 'Quote Tweet' prompts, retweets back as before
column4: Twitter on Wednesday said it will no longer automatically show the 'Quote Tweet' prompt when users try to retweet something. It added its goal through the feature was to "encourage more thoughtful amplification", which "didn't happen in practice". Twitter said the use of Quote Tweets increased, but 45% of them included single-word affirmations and 70% had less than 25 characters.

column3: Google acquires firm that can turn old PCs into Chrome devices
column4: Google has acquired Neverware, a company that turns old PCs into Chrome devices, for an undisclosed amount. Neverware on its website said the company and its software CloudReady are now part of Google and the Chrome OS team. CloudReady converts old PCs into a system that runs Chrome OS, which is a lighter software and thereby reduces e-waste.

column3: Addressing cybersecurity important for financial inclusion: RBI Guv
column4: RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das on Wednesday said that addressing the issues of cybersecurity and data protection is important for gaining confidence of the excluded section, which is necessary for promoting financial inclusion. He added that financial inclusion in India is poised to grow "exponentially" as millennials are joining the workforce and social media is blurring the urban-rural divide.

column3: Google workers demand reinstatement, apology for allegedly fired AI expert
column4: A group of Google's AI researchers have demanded that the company reinstate and apologise to AI researcher Timnit Gebru who was allegedly fired over an academic paper she co-authored. They have also demanded that the team's Vice President Megan Kacholia be removed from its management chain, Bloomberg reported. CEO Sundar Pichai earlier said he was investigating the incident.

column3: Govt regulation isn't necessarily a bad thing: Instagram Head
column4: Adam Mosseri, the Head of Instagram, told Economic Times in an interview that government regulation is not "necessarily a bad thing and, very often, it is necessary". "We don't really want to be in the business of making content decisions," Mosseri said. "We think privacy is an area where we would love more specific guidance from governments," he further added.

column3: Data Protection Bill won't get cleared in its current version: BJP MP
column4: BJP MP Rajeev Chandrasekhar, while speaking at the Global Technology Summit 2020, said the Data Protection Bill, 2019 will not get cleared in its current version. The committee is going to redraw the bill, he added. "Throughout this process witnesses would...argue as if privacy is a favour that is being done by the state for the citizens," he further said.

column3: IBM CEO Arvind Krishna to take over as Chairman from January
column4: IBM Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Arvind Krishna will take over as the Chairman of the company from January 1, replacing Executive Chairman, Ginni Rometty. Rometty, who stepped down as IBM's CEO earlier this year, will occasionally be asked to act as an independent contractor after her retirement, the company said. Arvind Krishna has been a part of IBM since 1990.

column3: Niue island demands redelegation of national webspace from ICANN
column4: Niue, an island in the South Pacific Ocean, has demanded a redelegation of national webspace .nu from the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN). Pär Brumark, who is leading the delegation on behalf of Niue, claims that no phone call was made to Niue when initial delegation happened. The .nu webspace is controlled by Internet Foundation in Sweden.

column3: No element in Bajrang Dal's content that necessitates ban: Facebook
column4: Facebook’s India head Ajit Mohan on Wednesday said before a Parliamentary panel that its fact-checking team has not found any such element that necessitates a ban on the Bajrang Dal, as per reports.
