Mohan was questioned by a panel chaired by Shashi Tharoor about a media report suggesting that Facebook didn't ban Bajrang Dal due to business and safety reasons.

column3: Facebook, Google colluded to weaken ad competition: US antitrust lawsuit
column4: An antitrust lawsuit by Texas and nine other states alleged that Google and Facebook, two of the biggest players in online advertising, consolidated their power and weakened competition through collusion. "Facebook decided to dangle the threat of competition in Google's face and then cut a deal to manipulate the auction," it said. High-ranking company officials approved the deal, it said.

column3: Honda recalls 737,000 Accord, Insight cars in US over software flaw
column4: Honda is recalling 737,000 Accord gas and hybrid cars from 2018 to 2020 and Insight hybrid cars from 2019 to 2020 after discovering a glitch in its software. The programming flaw in its control computer can cause the rear camera, turn signals and windshield wipers to malfunction. The move comes as part of a larger recall of 1.79-million cars worldwide.

column3: Which sportspersons earned the most in 2020 as per Forbes?
column4: Twenty-time Grand Slam champion Roger Federer is the highest-paid sportsperson of 2020 with $106.3-million earnings, as per Forbes' highest-paid celebrities list. He is followed by Cristiano Ronaldo ($105 million) and Lionel Messi ($104 million). PSG forward Neymar is next with $95.5-million earnings. LA Lakers' LeBron James is fifth-highest paid athlete with $88.2-million earnings.

column3: Kohli scores most runs against Australia as India captain, breaks 51-year-old record
column4: During the first day of the first Australia-India Test, Virat Kohli set the record for scoring the most runs against Australia as India captain. Kohli overtook Mansur Ali Khan Pataudi, who had registered 829 runs against Australia as India captain from 1964 to 1969. Kohli took 17 innings to overtake Pataudi, who had scored 829 runs in 20 innings.

column3: India end Day 1 of their first-ever Day-Night Test on Australian soil at 233/6
column4: After winning the toss and deciding to bat first, India ended the first day of their first-ever Day-Night Test on Australia soil at 233/6. Team India captain Virat Kohli top-scored on the day with 74 runs. He was run-out in the 77th over after a mix-up with Ajinkya Rahane. Mitchell Starc picked up two wickets for Australia.

column3: Yogasana formally recognised as a competitive sport in India
column4: The Ministry of AYUSH and Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports today announced the formal recognition of Yogasana as a competitive sport. Sports Minister Kiren Rijiju said that they are planning to include Yogasana as a sport discipline in Khelo India games and in the University Games. "We will also pitch it at the National Games," he added.

column3: Gunaah Hai Yeh: Australian journalist on Rohit, Kohli fans disliking each other
column4: Australian journalist Chloe-Amanda Bailey took to Twitter to question why Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma fans dislike each other despite both playing for the same team. In her tweet, she used a meme from the film 'Sarfarosh' which read "Gunaah Hai Yeh! (It's a crime)". Reacting to Bailey's post, Wasim Jaffer shared a meme reading "Noticed you copied my style".

column3: Only Aussie to take hat-trick on Test debut writes letter to debutant Green, pic viral
column4: Ex-pacer Damien Fleming, the only Australian to take a hat-trick on Test debut, took to social media to share a letter he wrote to Test debutant Cameron Green. "Consider this letter as an invitation to join the Australians With Hat-tricks on Test Debut Club...Quite frankly, I'm sick of winning the club's golf day every year," a part of letter read.

column3: Ponting rightly predicts Shaw's dismissal as he talks about his flaw, video viral
column4: Ex-Australia captain Ricky Ponting, while commentating in the Australia-India Test, rightly predicted Prithvi Shaw's dismissal. "If he does have a chink in his armour it's the ball which does come back into him...Quite often he leaves a big gap between bat and pad and that's where the Aussies will target," said Ponting. Shaw was bowled by Mitchell Starc for 0(2).

column3: Russia's int'l sporting ban halved to 2 years, country to still miss next 2 Olympics
column4: Russia has had a four-year ban from international sports events halved to two years by Court of Arbitration for Sport. The ban still covers events including the next editions of Summer and Winter Olympics. Russia was handed a four-year ban in December 2019 after allegations that falsified lab data was sent to WADA investigators by the Russian Anti-Doping Agency (RUSADA).

column3: I am being mentally tortured: Pakistan's Mohammad Amir quits international cricket
column4: Pakistan fast bowler Mohammad Amir has announced that he is retiring from international cricket. "I cannot play cricket under this management. I am being mentally tortured," he said. He added, "I cannot tolerate this. I have already tolerated a lot of mental torture from 2010 to 2015 when I was banned."

column3: How many Day-Night Tests have been played so far and which team has won the most?
column4: A total of 14 Day-Night Test matches have been played so far, with each of the match producing a result. Australia have played the most number of Day-Night Tests (seven) and have won each of the seven matches. India have played one Day-Night Test so far, which they won against Bangladesh at Kolkata's Eden Gardens in November 2019.

column3: Hockey captain Manpreet marries Malaysian girlfriend of Pakistan descent Illi
column4: Indian men's hockey team captain Manpreet Singh married his longtime girlfriend Illi Najwa Saddique in Mithapur village in Punjab's Jalandhar on Wednesday. Manpreet had been dating Illi, who is a Malaysian national of Pakistan descent, for more than eight years. Illi, who has been given a Punjabi name 'Navpreet Kaur', was working in a private university in Malaysia.

column3: Shane Warne calls Cheteshwar Pujara 'Steve', criticised for 'casual racism'
column4: Ex-Australia leg-spinner Shane Warne has been criticised for calling India batsman Cheteshwar Pujara as 'Steve' during the first day of the first Australia-India Test in Adelaide. "Referring to Pujara as ‘Steve’ is: a) unprofessional, b) disrespectful, c) racist...Learn to say his name," a fan wrote. "Sick, Casual racism," tweeted Jamie Alter.

column3: Virat Kohli has never lost a Test match after winning toss
column4: Team India captain Virat Kohli has never lost a Test match after winning a toss. Kohli has won 25 tosses in Test cricket so far and has led India to 21 victories and four draws in those matches. India won the toss and elected to bat first against Australia in the Day-Night Test in Adelaide today.

column3: I have always been myself, I am the representation of new India: Virat Kohli
column4: Responding to ex-Australia captain Greg Chappell's remark that 'Virat Kohli is the most Australian non-Australian cricketer of all time', the Team India captain said, "I have always been myself." He added, "The way my personality and character is, I am the representation of new India." "The new India takes up challenges and is filled with optimism and positivity," Kohli said.

column3: We'd be happy if Pujara bats 15 out of 20 days of Tests in Australia: Gavaskar
column4: Talking about India's Test specialist Cheteshwar Pujara, ex-India captain Sunil Gavaskar said, "Out of 20 days of Test cricket that we have ahead of us, we would be really happy if he bats for 15 days." He added, "Pujara loves batting...he loves being at the crease...he loves wearing the bowlers down. In the last two years, he has also improved."

column3: Shane Warne calls red ball 'pathetic', says it should be replaced by pink ball
column4: Australian spin legend Shane Warne has said that pink ball should be used in all Test matches in place of the "pathetic" red ball. "Red ball doesn’t swing, it doesn’t do anything, goes soft after 25 overs. It has been pathetic for so long now," he added. Warne further said that pink ball is easier to see for everyone.

column3: Ramiz Raja tells youth to 'not mistake wealth for respect' as Amir retires at 28
column4: Former Pakistan batsman Ramiz Raja, while reacting to Pakistan fast bowler Mohammad Amir's retirement aged 28, tweeted, "Sad untimely exit of a potential superstar!" He added, "And a lesson for aspiring youth: Respect your talent and understand your responsibilities. Don’t mistake wealth for respect. Respect is earned by having a strong character and not by worldly glitzy shit!"

column3: Time for Rahane to step up and relish the opportunity to lead: Virat
column4: India captain Virat Kohli, who would be flying back after the first Test against Australia for the birth of his first child, said Rahane should really step up and enjoy the opportunity to lead Team India. "I'm quite excited about how Ajinks (Rahane) goes. I think he is someone who'll enjoy the responsibility of captaining while I'm away," said Kohli.

column3: Perfect role model but Virat's captaincy still work-in-progress: Laxman
column4: Ex-India cricketer VVS Laxman said captain Virat Kohli leads by example but there is scope for improvement as far as his captaincy is concerned. "He's a perfect role model of how a captain should be. There's still work-in-progress as far as captaincy is concerned," Laxman said. He added that he feels Virat does become little defensive, especially with field changes.

column3: Teenage wrestler Anshu Malik wins silver at Individual World Cup
column4: Wrestler Anshu Malik finished second in the women's 57kg category to win India's first medal at the Individual World Cup in Belgrade, Serbia. The 19-year-old lost in the final 5-1 against Moldova's Anastasia Nichita. "It was a tough match, but she didn't give up. Her overall performance in the competition was good," said Anshu's father Dharamvir, a former international wrestler.

column3: Maradona's body 'must be conserved' for DNA in paternity case: Court
column4: An Argentine court on Wednesday ruled that late footballer Diego Maradona's body "must be conserved" in case his DNA is needed in a paternity case. His five recognised children and six with filiation requests are part of an inheritance process. The court said the former Argentine footballer's body must not be cremated at some later date.

column3: It's a decision that was absolutely clear in my mind: Virat on paternity leave
column4: India captain Virat Kohli said he is "absolutely clear in his mind" and has no qualms regarding missing three Tests against Australia for the birth of his first child. "As committed as you are to play for your country, this is a very, very special moment in life that you want to be there for at any cost," Virat said.

column3: Australian Open 2021 delayed, will now begin from Feb 8 in Melbourne: ATP
column4: The 2021 edition of Australian Open, which was scheduled from January 18, will now start on February 8 in Melbourne, ATP confirmed in its updated calendar. Meanwhile, the men's qualification will take place in Doha from January 10-13. The three-week delay will allow players to arrive in Melbourne and undergo quarantine before two ATP 250 events and the ATP Cup.

column3: Rahane blessed with smart brain, should lead India well in Aus: Sachin
column4: Sachin Tendulkar believes India Test vice-captain Ajinkya Rahane is equipped with a "smart brain" to be able to lead India well against Australia in the absence of Virat Kohli. "He is balanced. He is aggressive but it's controlled aggression. Whatever time I have spent with him, I know he is a hard-working player," Tendulkar said.

column3: Will decide after the India series: Paine on his future as player and captain
column4: Australia's Test captain Tim Paine said he will be contemplating about his future as a player and a leader after the series against India. "At the moment, the focus is on...for the rest of the series and then we will see," Paine said. He added he has been talking with coach Justin Langer and the chief selector about his future.

column3: Trump can't live at his Florida golf club after presidency, say neighbours
column4: Neighbours of Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago golf club in Florida warned the US President that he cannot live at the club after he leaves the White House. They said a 1993 agreement Trump made with the town prohibits anyone from living there, including him. This comes as Trump plans to move with his wife and son to the private club.

column3: China helps Pakistan return $1 billion of Saudi Arabia's loan
column4: With China's help, Pakistan has returned $1 billion to Saudi Arabia as a second instalment of a $3 billion soft loan. "China has come to our rescue," a Pakistan foreign ministry official told Reuters. Saudi demanded early repayment of the loan after Pakistan sought its support on the Kashmir issue. Pakistan needs to repay another $1 billion next month.

column3: If Russia wanted to kill Navalny, it would have finished the job: Putin
column4: Russian President Vladimir Putin on Thursday denied that Russia was behind the poisoning of opposition leader Alexey Navalny, adding that if the FSB spy agency wanted to kill him, they would have "finished" the job. "Who needs to poison him," Putin said about Navalny at his annual press conference. Navalny was poisoned with Novichok nerve agent in August.

column3: Irish train driver's partner's platform proposal for marriage goes viral
column4: A video of an Irish train driver's partner's platform proposal for marriage has gone viral. Paula Carbó Zea saw the words 'Will you marry me?', spelt out on four placards, as she drove her train into Pearse Station in Dublin on Tuesday. Carbó Zea said a lot of her colleagues had helped to make the proposal possible.

column3: Women post pics of legs in stockings to support jailed ex-Miss Belarus
column4: Women are posting photos of their legs in stockings to support former Miss Belarus Olga Khizhinkova who was jailed for protesting against the re-election of Belarus President Alexander Lukashenko. Several women posted photos of their legs beside packets of the stockings modelled by Khizhinkova, many tying the red and white protest flag, used by the opposition, around their thighs.

column3: 820-foot-tall world's largest crane completes its biggest ever lift, pics surface
column4: The world's largest crane completed its biggest ever lift today, hoisting a 575-ton steel cylinder into place at a nuclear site in the UK. The super-crane, nicknamed Big Carl, lifted the first of three massive steel rings which form a cylinder around the nuclear reactor being built near Bridgwater, Somerset. The crane can be 820-foot-high in its tallest configuration.

column3: Instagram star 'Zombie Angelina Jolie' freed days after being jailed in Iran
column4: Iranian Instagram star Sahar Tabar has been freed days after being jailed for 10 years, according to campaigners and activists in Iran. Masih Alinejad, a journalist, said that Tabar, who shot to prominence after posting photos in which she resembled what has been described as a zombie version of Angelina Jolie, was freed after "massive media pressure".

column3: Europe first region to cross 5,00,000 coronavirus deaths
column4: Europe on Thursday became the world's first region to cross five lakh coronavirus deaths, according to an AFP tally. The 52 countries and territories of the European region counted at least 5,00,069 deaths as against Latin America and the Caribbean's 4,77,404 fatalities. Italy, the UK, France, Russia and Spain account for more than half of the deaths in Europe.

column3: Saudi Arabia starts mass vaccination drive against COVID-19
column4: Saudi Arabia has started a mass vaccination drive against coronavirus after the first shipment of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine arrived in the kingdom. People above 65 and those with chronic ailments will be among the first to be vaccinated in the country. "This is...beginning of the end of...crisis," Saudi Health Minister, who was among the first to be vaccinated, told reporters.

column3: We have failed: Swedish King on Sweden's COVID-19 strategy
column4: Speaking about Sweden's response to the coronavirus pandemic, Swedish King Carl XVI Gustaf said, "I believe we've failed." "We've had a large number of deaths and that's terrible. That's something that brings us all suffering," he added. Sweden, which never imposed a full lockdown, has reported 7,893 COVID-19 deaths as compared to Norway and Finland's 404 and 484 deaths, respectively.

column3: Spain's PM quarantines after contact with COVID-19 +ve French Prez
column4: Spain's PM Pedro Sanchez on Thursday said that he will self-isolate until December 24 after being in contact with French President Emmanuel Macron, who has tested positive for COVID-19. Sanchez had met Macron in Paris on Monday. Similarly, Portugal's PM António Costa and European Council President Charles Michel are also self-isolating after meeting Macron this week.

column3: Senior Biden adviser Cedric Richmond tests positive for COVID-19
column4: Cedric Richmond, a senior adviser to US President-elect Joe Biden, has tested positive for COVID-19, the transition team said on Thursday. The incoming White House senior adviser had attended a rally for the Senate runoffs in Georgia along with the President-elect on Tuesday. Biden, who had open-air "interactions" with Richmond, tested negative for coronavirus, the transition team added.

column3: Wish you a speedy recovery: PM Modi to Macron after he tests COVID-19 positive
column4: After French President Emmanuel Macron tested positive for COVID-19 on Thursday, Prime Minister Narendra Modi tweeted, "Wishing my dear friend Macron a speedy recovery and the best of health." PM Modi tweeted his wishes in both French and English. Macron had taken the RT-PCR test at the onset of the first symptoms, according to the French President's office.

column3: Advisory panel to US FDA endorses emergency use of Moderna vaccine
column4: An advisory panel to the US Food and Drug Administration has endorsed the emergency use of Moderna Inc's coronavirus vaccine. The advisory panel concluded that the shot outweighs its risks in people aged 18 years and older. Earlier this week, the US began the mass vaccination drive against COVID-19 with Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. US has reported over 1.7 crore COVID-19 cases.

column3: America stood with India as it faced Chinese aggression: US official
column4: The US has stood with India as it faced Chinese aggression along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) over the last six-seven months, a White House official said. "We've...shown our moral support for India to be able to stand up to the Chinese," the official added. "We've been very concerned with China's increasing aggression...across the globe," the official further said.

column3: Rail link between West Bengal and Bangladesh resumes after 55 yrs
column4: Rail services between West Bengal's Haldibari and Bangladesh's Chilahati resumed in the Indian state's Cooch Behar district after a gap of 55 years. "Freight trains are running initially, later passenger trains will also run," a railway official told ANI. Prime Minister Narendra Modi and his Bangladeshi counterpart Sheikh Hasina jointly inaugurated the rail-link virtually.

column3: New agreement needed to revive Iran nuclear deal under Biden: IAEA
column4: International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) chief Rafael Grossi said that reviving the 2015 Iran nuclear deal under US President-elect Joe Biden would require striking a new agreement setting out how Iranian breaches should be reversed. Under President Donald Trump, the US quit the deal in 2018 and reimposed sanctions on Iran. Iran responded by breaching many restrictions under the deal.

column3: Have nothing to do with potential prosecution of Biden's son: Trump
column4: US President Donald Trump on Thursday tweeted that he has "nothing to do with the potential prosecution of Hunter Biden, or the Biden family". "It is just more Fake News. Actually, I find it very sad to watch!" he added. Trump's denial comes a week after US President-elect Joe Biden's son Hunter revealed that his "tax affairs" were being investigated.

column3: 18 fishermen held in Libya freed after more than 100 days: Italy
column4: Eighteen fishermen who were held in Libya for more than 100 days for allegedly fishing in Libyan waters have been freed, Italy said. Italian Foreign Minister Luigi Di Maio said that he and PM Giuseppe Conte went to Benghazi to bring the fishermen back. The group includes eight Italians, six Tunisians, two Indonesians and two Senegalese, AFP reported.

column3: US Joint Chiefs chairman meets Taliban negotiators in Qatar
column4: The US Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Mark Milley, met with Taliban negotiators in Qatar this week, the military said on Thursday. Milley later flew to Afghanistan to meet Afghan President Ashraf Ghani. "The most important part of the discussions that I'd with both...Taliban and...[Afghan government] was the need for an immediate reduction in violence," Milley said.

column3: Alexey Navalny working with US intelligence: Russian Prez Putin
column4: Russian President Vladimir Putin has denied allegations that the Kremlin was behind Alexey Navalny's poisoning and accused the opposition leader of working with US intelligence agencies. His comments came after an investigative report revealed that a Russian intelligence team trailed Navalny before he was poisoned in August. Putin claimed that the report relied on data provided by US spy agencies.

column3: Hungary broke EU asylum rules: European Court of Justice
column4: The European Court of Justice ruled that Hungary has broken EU laws protecting migrants and refugees after denying them a right to apply for asylum and deported them to "transit zones" on its border with Serbia. "We'll continue to protect...borders of Hungary...and will do everything we can to prevent...formation of international migrant corridors," Hungarian Justice Minister said in response.

column3: 344 boys kidnapped from Nigerian boarding school released: Official
column4: Hundreds of boys kidnapped last week from a boarding school in Nigeria have been released, Katsina state Governor Aminu Bello Masari said. He added that 344 boys, whose abduction was claimed by Boko Haram, have been freed and were all in a good condition. "I think...we have recovered most of the boys, if not all of them," Masari further said.

column3: US drug overdose deaths reach record high amid COVID-19 pandemic
column4: The ongoing COVID-19 pandemic has led to a rise in fatal drug overdoses in the US, officials said on Thursday. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported over 81,000 drug overdose deaths in the year to May, the highest ever in a 12-month period. Those with substance use disorders were hit hard by the pandemic, the CDC Director said.

column3: Not yet decided if I'll run or not for president in 2024: Putin
column4: Speaking about the 2024 presidential election in Russia, President Vladimir Putin on Thursday said that he has not yet decided whether or not he would contest it. Earlier, Russian voters had approved changes to the constitution that will allow Putin to potentially stay in power until 2036. Putin has led Russia as president or prime minister since 1999.

column3: TMC MLA Silbhadra resigns from party, 3rd leader to quit in 2 days
column4: Trinamool Congress MLA Silbhadra Datta has resigned from the party, becoming the third leader to quit in two days. Earlier, MLA Jitendra Tiwari quit the party and as chief of the Asansol Municipal Corporation, however, he said he won't resign from the MLA post. On Wednesday, TMC leader Suvendu Adhikari resigned from the membership of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly.

column3: Bihar Cabinet approves free coronavirus vaccine for all in state
column4: Bihar Cabinet on Tuesday approved a proposal to provide free COVID-19 vaccine to all the people of the state. "Our decision is a big gift to people of the state after formation of the government," Deputy Chief Minister Tarkishore Prasad said. The Cabinet also decided to generate 20 lakh jobs in government and non-government sectors in the next five years.

column3: Trinamool Congress leader Suvendu Adhikari resigns as MLA
column4: Trinamool Congress leader Suvendu Adhikari resigned from the membership of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly on Wednesday. This comes days after Adhikari quit as West Bengal transport minister and from other posts. "He is welcome in the party if he wishes to join us," BJP state unit president Dilip Ghosh was earlier quoted as saying by IANS.

column3: Suvendu Adhikari quits as member of Trinamool Congress
column4: Trinamool Congress leader Suvendu Adhikari has quit as a member of the party as well as from all other positions held by him in the party and its associate organs. Adhikari resigned from the membership of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly on Wednesday. He had quit as West Bengal Transport Minister and from other posts earlier.

column3: PM lights Swarnim Vijay Mashaal to mark start of 50th anniversary of 1971 war win
column4: PM Narendra Modi on Wednesday lit up 'Swarnim Vijay Mashaal' at National War Memorial, marking the beginning of the 50th anniversary year of India's victory over Pakistan in 1971 war. Four Victory Mashaals lit from Eternal Flame will be carried to various parts of India including to villages of Param Vir Chakra and Maha Vir Chakra awardees of 1971 war.

column3: EC seeks Kerala CM's explanation on free COVID-19 vaccine announcement
column4: Kerala State Election Commission has sought an explanation from Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan for allegedly violating the model code of conduct by saying that the COVID-19 vaccine would be made available free of cost in the state. Vijayan had made the announcement on Saturday shortly before campaigning for the third phase of local bodies polls came to a close.

column3: Kerala CM claims victory in local body polls, says BJP, UDF should introspect
column4: Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan claimed victory in local body polls and said it's "a befitting reply to those who are trying to destroy Kerala". "BJP and UDF who have taken anti-development campaign should withdraw from it and do an introspection," he added. Vijayan-led Left Democratic Front was leading in 514 out of 941 gram panchayats, according to State Election Commission.

column3: Centre asks WB to relieve 3 IPS officers immediately, CM criticises order
column4: The Centre on Thursday asked the West Bengal government to immediately relieve three Indian Police Service officers for joining a central deputation. In response to the Centre's order, Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee called it "blatant misuse of power" and said she won't cow-down before the "expansionist" and "undemocratic" forces. "It's unconstitutional and completely unacceptable," she tweeted.

column3: BJP wins 32 out of 49 seats in Goa Zilla Panchayat polls, Cong wins 4
column4: The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) in Goa on Monday made big gains in the Zilla Panchayat elections, winning 32 out of 49 seats on offer. The Congress won four seats in the polls, while the NCP and the AAP bagged one seat each. The AAP has won its first-ever seat in an election in the coastal state.

column3: COVID-19 +ve Haryana minister Anil Vij shifted to Gurugram hospital
column4: Haryana minister Anil Vij, who had tested positive for COVID-19, was shifted to Medanta hospital in Gurugram from Rohtak's Post Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences on Tuesday. A doctor said, "The Health Minister has been diagnosed with COVID-19 pneumonia, leading to infection in lungs." Vij had got one shot of the two-dose trial of the COVID-19 vaccine Covaxin last month.

column3: Cong MLCs manhandle, remove K'taka Legislative Council Dy Chairman
column4: Congress MLCs on Tuesday manhandled and forcefully removed Deputy Chairman SL Dharmegowda from the chair in Karnataka Legislative Council. Congress MLC Prakash Rathod said BJP and JD(S) made him sit illegally when the House was not in order and therefore they evicted him. BJP MLC Lehar Singh Siroya said, "We've never seen such a shameful day in our Council's history."

column3: BJP launched campaign to divide farmers, defame movement: Akhilesh
column4: Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav on Tuesday said that the farmers are agitating for the past 20 days and instead of listening to them, the government has adopted a stubborn attitude. He added, "Not only this, but the BJP has also launched a campaign to divide farmers and discredit the movement and defame it."

column3: Startup uses Tharoor's caricature in ad without consent; MP takes legal action
column4: Edtech startup Mastree used MP Shashi Tharoor's caricature without his consent for their advertisement with caption, "Gift your child Shashi Tharoor's confidence." Tharoor has sought a public apology and a legally binding commitment to 'cease and desist such practices'. "I was shocked...of their advertising using my name and caricature as if to imply I had endorsed their courses," Tharoor said.

column3: AAP to contest UP elections in 2022: Arvind Kejriwal
column4: Aam Aadmi Party chief and Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal has said the party will contest the state elections in Uttar Pradesh in 2022. "A lot of people from UP who live in Delhi have told us that UP too deserves the welfare and benefits like Delhi," he added. He also said that all parties in UP have betrayed the people.

column3: Cong demands account of foreign donations made to PM CARES Fund
column4: The Congress on Wednesday demanded an account of the foreign donations received by the PM CARES Fund. Congress General Secretary Randeep Surjewala tweeted, "Questions to PM - Why did Indian Embassies publicise & receive donation to PM Cares Fund? Why was the Fund advertised on banned Chinese apps?" He added, "How much money was received from Pakistan & who donated?"

column3: Kamal Haasan is spoiling families through 'Bigg Boss': TN CM
column4: Tamil Nadu CM Edappadi K Palaniswami alleged that Makkal Needhi Maiam chief and 'Bigg Boss' host Kamal Haasan is "spoiling" families through the Tamil TV series. "What will happen if a man hosting 'Bigg Boss' enters politics? Not one family...will be good if they watch it," he added. "Haasan [doesn't have] ambition to do good for the country," Palaniswami stated.

column3: TMC MLA Jitendra Tiwari quits party hours after Suvendu Adhikari
column4: Trinamool Congress MLA Jitendra Tiwari on Thursday quit the party and as chief of the Asansol Municipal Corporation. However, he said he won't resign from the MLA post. Tiwari had accused the West Bengal government of depriving Asansol of central funds under the Smart Cities Mission project. Earlier on Thursday, TMC leader Suvendu Adhikari quit as a party member.

column3: Cong mayor candidate loses by 1 vote to BJP opponent in Kerala local body polls
column4: Congress mayoral candidate N Venugopal lost to BJP candidate by one vote in Kochi Corporation North Island ward in Kerala's local body elections. "There was problem with the voting machine. That may be reason for BJP's victory," Venugopal said. "I haven't decided to go to court with the voting machine issue so far. Will check what happened exactly," he added.

column3: Farm laws issue can be solved in 5 mins if PM steps in: Sanjay Raut
column4: Shiv Sena leader Sanjay Raut said that the government can resolve the issue raised by protesting farmers in 30 minutes by sitting with them. "If the Prime Minister intervenes himself, it will be resolved in five minutes. Modi ji is such a big leader, everyone will listen to him," he added. Farmers have been protesting over Centre's new farm laws.

column3: Not a protest site: Javadekar after Rahul walks out of Standing Committee
column4: Union Minister and BJP leader Prakash Javadekar said that Congress' Rahul Gandhi attended two of the 14 meetings of Parliamentary Standing Committee on Defence in one and a half years. "He's himself absent and then blames govt...Standing Committee isn't a protest site," Javadekar added. This comes after Gandhi and Congress members walked out of Defence Parliamentary Panel meeting.

column3: 100 BJP workers booked for organising 'welcome rally' in Gr Noida
column4: Police have registered a case against over 100 BJP workers for allegedly organising an unauthorised rally in Greater Noida on Sunday. Police said the "welcome rally" was allegedly for newly appointed party functionary Pandit Ashish Vats. "Vats, along with a group of BJP workers, reached the toll plaza in eight to 10 cars...[which] violated social distancing norms," the Sub-Inspector said.

column3: CPI, CPI(M) leaders protest in Hyderabad against farm laws
column4: CPI and CPI(M) leaders, among other Left party leaders in Telangana, on Monday protested in Hyderabad against the government's three new farm laws. They held placards demanding abrogation of the three "pro-corporate" farm laws and boycott of certain big corporates. Senior Congress leader V Hanumantha Rao observed a fast from 10 am to 4 pm at his residence in Hyderabad.

column3: Kolkata Municipal Corporation polls likely in March 2021: Official
column4: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) elections​ are likely to be held in March 2021, senior officials of West Bengal State Election Commission said. "As per the Supreme Court's directive, the state government has sent a communication to us saying that the KMC polls may be held within four weeks after the final electoral roll is adopted," an official said.

column3: BJP leaders' statements on farmers' protest condemnable: Gehlot
column4: Rajasthan CM Ashok Gehlot on Monday said that BJP leaders' statements criticising farmers' protest are "most unfortunate and condemnable". "The government must find an amicable solution and address the grievances of farmers sympathetically instead of blaming gangs, anti-national elements for these protests," Gehlot said. "The farm laws...must be taken back," he added.

column3: Why should protests take place in America & London for farmers?: MoS
column4: Union Minister of State for Home Affairs G Kishan Reddy on Monday said that why should demonstrations take place in America, Canada and London in support of farmers' protests happening in India. He added, "Who is behind this? Some people want to carry out anti-India activities by misusing your (farmers') name. I request farmers to remain vigilant."

column3: 5 members quit Mission Impossible 7 as Cruise shouts & swears at them again: Report
column4: Five 'Mission Impossible 7' crew members have reportedly quit, after lead actor and producer Tom Cruise shouted and swore at them for second time on set on Tuesday. Earlier, an audio clip of Cruise shouting at crew members for an apparent breach of COVID-19 rules had leaked. He was heard threatening to fire members who don't obey guidelines on set.

column3: NCB sends notice to Karan Johar in drugs case, seeks details of parties he organised
column4: The NCB has issued notice to filmmaker Karan Johar seeking details of parties he organised. The NCB has asked Johar to send his response and produce documents/electronic evidence with respect to the "house party video" in which several celebrities were accused of being in a "drugged state". This comes amid NCB's crackdown on the use of drugs in Bollywood.

column3: Sona replies after Twitter user writes 'hope he's not a rapist' on father's pic
column4: Singer Sona Mohapatra replied to a Twitter user who commented, "I hope he is not a rapist, because u find all men rapists," on her father's picture. Sona had shared the picture of her father, Navy veteran Dilip Mohapatra, wearing his medals. Sona said, "This...jingoistic is happy to put...words in my mouth that I have never uttered, believed."

column3: Kareena confirms Varun Dhawan is engaged to Natasha Dalal, calls her his fiancée
column4: Kareena Kapoor referred to Natasha Dalal as Varun Dhawan's fiancée on her show 'What Women Want'. "You've been with your fiancée since...school days...How did you decide 'We've to get married'?" she asked. "I felt like getting married after I saw my brother and sister-in-law...We wouldn't have minded a live-in scene...But I think my parents wanted us...[to get married]," he replied.

column3: Actor Ravi Bhatia splits from Indonesian wife, says they married as she was pregnant
column4: TV actor Ravi Bhatia, who starred in the show 'Jodha Akbar', confirmed that he has separated from his wife, Indonesian air hostess Yulida Handayani after three years of marriage. "When we got married, she was three months pregnant. Marriage is a big decision," he stated. "Cultural differences were some of the reasons for the break-up," Ravi added.

column3: Was on bed rest with legs raised for 3 months: Khattar's wife on pregnancy issues
column4: Ishaan Khatter's father Rajesh Khattar's wife Vandana, speaking about issues she faced during pregnancy, revealed to Miss Malini that two months into her pregnancy, she was informed she had a weak uterine lining. She added she was prescribed bed rest, with her legs raised for three months. "I...couldn't even put my legs down to go to the bathroom," said Vandana.

column3: Sunny denies reports of getting Y-category security after speaking on protests
column4: Actor and BJP MP Sunny Deol has denied reports that he was given Y-category security by the government after he expressed his views on the ongoing farmers' protests. Taking to Twitter, Sunny wrote that he has been accorded Y-category security since July 2020. "An attempt has been made to link this security provision to...ongoing...protest which is wrong," he added.

column3: I feel euphoric: Sir Ian McKellen on receiving COVID-19 vaccine
column4: Veteran actor Sir Ian McKellen, who starred in films like 'X-Men: Days of Future Past' and 'The Lord of the Rings', received a COVID-19 vaccine in the first week of the UK's vaccination programme. After receiving the vaccine, the 81-year-old actor said, "It's a...special day, I feel euphoric!" He added, "I would have no hesitation in recommending it to anyone."

column3: After watching my music videos, people feel I can become actor: Armaan
column4: Singer Armaan Malik has said a lot of people have approached him with acting offers. "After watching my music videos, people feel I can become...actor," he added. Armaan further said he wants to be well prepared before venturing into films. "I don't want to do anything half-heartedly...I don't want to act just for the sake of it," he said.

column3: Gal reveals her husband, children have cameos in 'Wonder Woman 1984'
column4: Actress Gal Gadot revealed that her husband, Jaron Varsano, and their children Alma (9), and Maya (3), have cameos in her upcoming film 'Wonder Woman 1984', along with director Patty Jenkins' husband and son. "This movie is more than just a movie for...me, for Patty. It completely changed my life," she said in an interview with Kevin McCarthy.

column3: Web has given a new life not only to actors but to stories: Shweta
column4: Actress Shweta Tripathi Sharma, who has worked in both films and web series, said, "The web has given a new life not only to actors but to stories, storytellers, musicians. On OTT, characters are not dry-cleaned." Speaking about her and Ali Fazal's 'Mirzapur' characters, she said, "Guddu and Munna have their set of flaws but you still like them."

column3: Never seen him tired: Mona on working with Aamir in 'Laal Singh Chaddha'
column4: Speaking about her experience of working with Aamir Khan on their upcoming film 'Laal Singh Chaddha', actress Mona Singh said, "I have never seen him tired. I have never seen him complain." She further explained, "We...shot in situations where it was extremely cold and he was just in a ganji. Not once did I hear him crib."

column3: 51st IFFI to be organised in Goa from January 16-24
column4: The 51st edition of the International Film Festival of India (IFFI) will be held in Goa from January 16-24, Information and Broadcasting Minister Prakash Javadekar said. The film festival was scheduled to take place from November 20-28 but was postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic. It will be conducted in a hybrid format with physical and virtual screenings.

column3: Abhay Deol, Karan Deol in talks to star in Ajay's 'Velley': Reports
column4: Abhay Deol and Sunny Deol's son Karan Deol are reportedly in talks to star in 'Velley', which is the remake of Telugu crime-comedy film 'Brochevarevarura'. It'll reportedly be produced by Ajay Devgn and directed by Deven Munjal, who has worked on films like 'Om Shanti Om' and 'Main Hoon Na'. The film will reportedly go on floors next year.

column3: Sara was dropped from Heropanti 2 after being linked to drugs case: Reports
column4: Sara Ali Khan, who was summoned by NCB in a drugs case linked to Sushant Singh Rajput's death case, was reportedly in the final stages of securing the lead role in Tiger Shroff's upcoming film, 'Heropanti 2'. However, she was dropped as makers didn't want to "jeopardize" the project, reports added. Tara Sutaria will star opposite Tiger in the film.

column3: Didn't know excruciating back pain was a symptom: COVID-19 +ve Ellen
column4: American television host Ellen DeGeneres, who tested positive for coronavirus last week, took to social media on Wednesday to share an update on her health. She said, "I am feeling 100 per cent. I feel really good." Ellen added, "One thing they don't tell you is you get, somehow, excruciating back pain. I didn't know that was a symptom."

column3: No insider would've played the roles I did: Chandan on insider-outsider debate
column4: Sharing his thoughts on the insider-outsider debate, actor Chandan Roy Sanyal said, "I don't think I've lost out on roles...because I'm an outsider, especially because someone like me isn't considered for such roles." He added, "No insider would've played the roles that I did." "Having said that, I feel there's no insider-outsider...Everybody is looking for their next job," said Chandan.

column3: Sonu Sood, Shraddha named 2020's hottest vegetarians by PETA India
column4: Sonu Sood and Shraddha Kapoor have been declared the hottest vegetarians of the year 2020 by PETA India. "Sonu and Shraddha are helping to change the world every time they sit down to eat," PETA India Director of Celebrity and Public Relations Sachin Bangera said. Sonu shared the picture of his trophy on Twitter and thanked the organisation.

column3: Dhanush joins Ryan Gosling and Chris Evans starrer 'The Gray Man'
column4: Actor Dhanush will share screen space with Hollywood actors Ryan Gosling, Chris Evans and Ana de Armas in the Russo Brothers' upcoming film 'The Gray Man'. The movie, which is based on Mark Greaney's 2009 novel of the same name, will also feature actors Jessica Henwick, Wagner Moura, and Julia Butters.

column3: If she invites me, I would love to go: Kushal on ex Gauahar's wedding
column4: Commenting on his ex-girlfriend Gauahar Khan getting married to Zaid Darbar, actor Kushal Tandon said, "I'm in touch with her...I am happy that she is getting married...If she invites me to her wedding, I would love to go." However, he further added, "I'll be shooting that time, so I'm not sure if I will be able to attend the wedding."

column3: Tiger shares pic with 'Salt Bae', says 'So inspiring watching your craft live'
column4: Actor Tiger Shroff on Wednesday took to Instagram to share a few pictures of himself with Turkish celebrity chef Nusret Gökçe, also known as Salt Bae. "So inspiring watching your craft live, thanks for the meal @nusr_et," the actor captioned. Nusret also shared a picture with Tiger on Instagram Stories and wrote, "Brother."

column3: OTT gave me the chance to be in middle of frame: Chandan Roy Sanyal
column4: Chandan Roy Sanyal, who was recently seen in web show 'Aashram', has said OTT gave him the chance to be in the middle of the frame. "Earlier, I'd be on...side. That's exciting for me. I'm looking forward," he added. Talking about 'Aashram', Chandan said, "[It] became...mass loved project. I've had people from all over...world getting in touch for the show."

column3: We're more like best friends rather than sisters: Kareena on Karisma
column4: Actress Kareena Kapoor in an interview spoke about her bond with her sister Karisma Kapoor and said, "We are really close. We're more like best friends rather than sisters." She further said her sister has always been supportive and added, "Even if she doesn't believe in something I do, she'll always allow me and support me to do that."

column3: Best part of my life will always be you: Genelia on Riteish's b'day
column4: Marking Riteish Deshmukh's 42nd birthday, actress Genelia Deshmukh posted a montage of their pictures on Instagram and shared a note for her husband. "We've gone through all our phases in life together. From being clueless teenagers to husband and wife to parents and it's all been beautiful but the best part of my life will always be YOU," she wrote.

column3: I wouldn't have done it that big: Clooney on Cruise's COVID-19 rule breach rant
column4: George Clooney has reacted to Tom Cruise's expletive-filled outburst on 'Mission Impossible 7' sets. Cruise screamed at crew members over an apparent breach of COVID-19 rules. Clooney said, "I wouldn't have done it that big...it's not my style to take everybody to task that way." Clooney further said Cruise isn't wrong, adding, "He didn't overreact because it's a problem."

column3: Own a car without buying it : Revv Subscriptions
column4: You can now drive a new car every month as Revv provides the option to subscribe to your favourite car for 1-36 months with ₹0 down payment, ₹0 road tax and without the hassle of maintenance and service. The car will be sanitized and delivered to your doorstep ensuring complete safety for you and your loved ones.

column3: Auto industry lost ₹2,300cr a day in lockdown: Parliamentary panel
column4: The automotive industry suffered ₹2,300 crore loss per day during the COVID-19 lockdown, according to a parliamentary panel report submitted to Rajya Sabha Chairman M Venkaiah Naidu. The sector witnessed an estimated job loss of about 3.45 lakh, the report said. All major original equipment manufacturers (OEM) cut down their production by 18-20% due to low demand, it added.

column3: Apple moves self-driving car unit under exec who oversees Siri: Report
column4: Apple has moved its self-driving car unit under the leadership of John Giannandrea, Senior Vice President of Machine Learning and AI Strategy, who also oversees the development of Apple's virtual assistant Siri, Bloomberg reported. Apple began working on its autonomous car project, known as Titan, in 2014. CEO Tim Cook in 2017 called autonomous systems "mother of all AI projects".

column3: US govt opens probe into 1.15L Tesla vehicles over suspension issue
column4: The US NHTSA opened an investigation into around 1.15 lakh Tesla vehicles over a front suspension safety issue. It said it was opening a preliminary evaluation into 2015-2017 Model S and 2016-2017 Model X vehicles after receiving 43 complaints alleging failure of the left or right front suspension fore links. "The complaints appear to indicate an increasing trend," NHTSA said.

column3: Apple CFO, Apple's ex-design chief candidates for Ferrari CEO: Report
column4: Apple CFO Luca Maestri and former Chief Design Officer Jony Ive are reportedly candidates to be Ferrari's next CEO, Reuters reported. Ferrari CEO Louis Camilleri announced his retirement earlier due to "personal reasons". Former Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao was allegedly in the running for the position too, but Reuters said a source close to Colao has called the claim "groundless".

column3: Honda recalls 737,000 Accord, Insight cars in US over software flaw
column4: Honda is recalling 737,000 Accord gas and hybrid cars from 2018 to 2020 and Insight hybrid cars from 2019 to 2020 after discovering a glitch in its software. The programming flaw in its control computer can cause the rear camera, turn signals and windshield wipers to malfunction. The move comes as part of a larger recall of 1.79-million cars worldwide.

column3: US startup claims to have made 1st 'no charging' solar EV
column4: US-based Aptera Motors has introduced the "first solar electric vehicle" that requires "no charging" for most daily use and has a range of up to over 1,600 kilometres per full charge. Every Aptera is designed to harvest enough sunlight to travel over 17,702 kilometres per year in most regions. Liquid-cooled electric motors propel Aptera from 0-100 kilometres/hour in 3.5 seconds.

column3: Tesla reveals women comprise 17% of its total US leadership roles
column4: Tesla revealed in its first-ever US diversity report that women comprise 17% of the company's leadership roles and 21% of the overall workforce. It added that Black people make up 4% of its US leadership roles and 10% of its total workforce. "While women are historically underrepresented...we recognise we have work to do in this area," Tesla said.

column3: Battery-operated bikes to be included in Delhi's EV policy: Report
column4: Delhi's EV policy is being revised to include a segment on battery-operated bicycles and tricycles, HT reported. The government has drafted a proposal to offer monetary incentives on their purchase. The proposed revision includes cycles both in the passenger and cargo categories. In case of individual buyers, purchase incentive will be 25% of the MRP with a cap of ₹5,000.

column3: Tesla asked to give ₹1 cr to used car buyer for hiding damage in China
column4: Tesla was ordered by a Chinese court to pay over ₹1 crore to the buyer of a used Model S car after concluding it concealed structural damage on the vehicle it sold on its official website. It was reportedly discovered part of the vehicle had been cut and welded back together. Tesla will appeal the ruling to a higher court.

column3: Baidu becomes 1st to get fully driverless road tests permit in Beijing
column4: Baidu has become the first to receive permits by the Beijing transportation authorities for five of its vehicles to conduct fully driverless road tests. It plans to remove safety drivers from test vehicles after gradually reducing human intervention. However, a remote safety operator will still be able to take control in an emergency via Baidu's 5G Remote Driving Service.

column3: General Motors to not acquire 11% stake in Nikola
column4: General Motors (GM) and Nikola on Monday announced a reworked deal that replaced their previous agreement under which GM would acquire 11% equity stake in the startup and produce the proposed electric pickup Badger. The companies have instead signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding which is subject to negotiation. Nikola was previously accused of fraud by a short seller.

column3: Tesla teams to visit Indonesia to discuss investment in EV components
column4: Tesla will send delegations to Indonesia next month to discuss potential investment in a supply chain for its electric vehicles. Government officials and Tesla CEO Elon Musk have discussed investment opportunities in Indonesia over a call. Indonesia earlier pointed out it has the "biggest" nickel reserves. Musk plans to offer a "giant contract for a long period of time".

column3: Musk asks Tesla staff to push output to max possible through Dec: Report
column4: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has sent an email to workers encouraging them to push output to the maximum possible through December, Bloomberg reported. "We are fortunate to have the high-class problem of demand being quite a bit higher than production this quarter," the report quoted Musk. The company has a target of delivering 5 lakh cars this year.

column3: Amazon's Zoox unveils autonomous EV that can travel both ways
column4: Amazon-owned self-driving car platform Zoox has unveiled a fully autonomous electric vehicle with no steering wheel which can travel in either direction. Equipped with two battery packs, the four-seater robotaxi can run for 16 hours on a single charge and can attain a maximum speed of 120 kmph. CEO Aicha Evans said Zoox plans on launching an app-based ride-hailing service.

column3: Mahindra's Korean unit SsangYong defaults on $55 million loan
column4: Automaker Mahindra & Mahindra's South Korean unit SsangYong Motor Company has defaulted on loan repayment of about $55 million. Around $27.5 million was owed to Bank of America, $18.3 million to JP Morgan Chase and $9.1 million to BNP Paribas on December 14. Mahindra has been looking for a buyer for all or most of its 75% stake since June.

column3: Delhi govt launches forum to discuss electric vehicle policy
column4: Delhi government on Friday launched the 'Delhi EV Forum', a common platform for multiple stakeholders to hold discussions on the government's electric vehicle (EV) policy. "Delhi EV Forum will be the first such forum in India...The first meeting will be held virtually on December 18," Delhi DDC Vice Chairperson said. The policy's objective is to combat air pollution in Delhi.

column3: Tesla to raise $5 billion as market cap crosses $600 billion
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla on Tuesday announced that it will be raising $5 billion, marking its second capital raise in the last three months. The additional shares will be sold "from time to time" and "at-the-market" prices. Its shares are up nearly 670% this year with its market capitalisation crossing $600 billion. Tesla will join S&P 500 index later this month.

column3: Hyundai, Kia agree to $210M US penalty for delay in vehicles' recall
column4: Hyundai and Kia Motors have agreed to $140 million and $70 million civil penalties, respectively, after US auto safety regulators said they delayed recall of 1.6 million vehicles for engine issues. The settlement covers recall in 2015 and 2017 for manufacturing issues. Kia denied the allegations but agreed to settle the matter to "avoid a protracted dispute with the government".

column3: Tesla would consider buying a legacy automaker on friendly terms: Musk
column4: Tesla would consider leveraging the company's $554 billion market capitalisation to buy a legacy automaker, CEO Elon Musk said in an interview with Axel Springer. "We're definitely not going to launch a hostile takeover," Musk said. "If somebody said, 'Hey, we think it would be a good idea to merge with Tesla,' we certainly could have that conversation," he added.

column3: Workers of Toyota unit near B'luru to continue strike over workload
column4: Factory workers at Toyota Kirloskar Private Limited's Bidadi unit, located near Bengaluru, announced that they will continue their ongoing strike over increased workload, among other concerns. They said that they don't get time to drink water or use the washroom. The unit has been in a lockout since November 10, after 41 workers were suspended for allegedly questioning the management.

column3: Volkswagen CEO reveals they began 'Mission T' to catch up with Tesla
column4: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess, in a blog post, revealed he organised a three-day workshop nicknamed 'Mission T' to discuss how they could "catch up with Tesla". He added that they brought 31 senior executives from Volkswagen, Audi and Porsche together amid the COVID-19 pandemic to discuss how they could further their Project Artemis to take on Tesla.

column3: Tesla to shut down production of Model S, X for 18 days: Report
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla will shut down the production of its high-end Model S and Model X electric vehicles from December 24 to January 11 in Fremont, California, CNBC reported. Employees will be given a full week's pay along with few paid holidays. Deliveries of these models amounted to only 11% of total vehicle deliveries during Tesla's third quarter of 2020.

column3: Fiat Chrysler to invest $150 mn to set up digital hub in Hyderabad
column4: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has said it will invest $150 million to set up a global digital hub in Hyderabad. The investment will help create nearly 1,000 jobs by the end of 2021. "One of the key objectives...is to digitalise every aspect of FCA's automotive operations globally and within India," Mamatha Chamarthi, CIO for North America and Asia-Pacific region, said.

column3: ISRO successfully launches India's 42nd communication satellite CMS-01
column4: The ISRO on Thursday successfully launched India's 42nd communication satellite from Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC) SHAR, Sriharikota. The PSLV-C50 launch vehicle put the communication satellite CMS-01 in orbit, that will provide coverage for disaster management and satellite internet connection. It's the first one in a new series of communication satellites after the INSAT and the GSAT series.

column3: Indian-American Raja Chari selected by NASA to fly to ISS on SpaceX mission
column4: Indian-American astronaut Raja Chari has been selected by NASA alongside two other astronauts to fly to the International Space Station (ISS) on SpaceX Crew-3 mission in 2021. It'll be the first spaceflight for Chari and Matthias Maurer, and the third for NASA astronaut Tom Marshburn. Raja Chari is the only Indian-American among 18 astronauts selected for NASA's Moon mission.

column3: Japan finds pieces of asteroid inside space capsule that returned to Earth
column4: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency has found pieces of an asteroid inside a space capsule delivered by the Hayabusa2 space probe. The capsule was recovered in Australia on December 6, following its journey through space. The Japanese probe collected surface dust last year from the asteroid Ryugu, around 300 million kilometres away, during two phases of its six-year mission.

column3: Pics of 2020's last solar eclipse seen in parts of the world surface online
column4: Pictures of the last solar eclipse of 2020, witnessed on December 14, have surfaced online. The total solar eclipse was visible for people living in parts of Chile and Argentina. In some parts of South America, south-west Africa and Antarctica, people witnessed a partial solar eclipse. The total solar eclipse was not visible from India.

column3: Videos of Geminids meteor shower surface online
column4: Videos of the Geminids meteor shower, recognised as the best annual meteor shower a stargazer can see, have surfaced online. According to NASA, the Geminids travel 78,000 mph (35 km/s). The parent of the Geminids is 3200 Phaethon, which is arguably considered to be either an asteroid or an extinct comet, NASA said.

column3: NASA shares pic of Himalayan mountains, Delhi's city lights captured from space
column4: NASA took to Instagram to share a picture of snow-covered Himalayan mountains and Delhi's city lights captured from space. "The bright city lights of New Delhi, India, and Lahore, Pakistan, are...visible below the faint, orange airglow of atmospheric particles reacting to solar radiation," NASA wrote. Reacting to the picture, a user wrote, "This is so beautiful."

column3: Flies turn into 'zombies' when infected by new fungi species, scientists discover
column4: Scientists in Denmark have discovered two new fungi species that 'zombify' flies and eject spores out of a large hole in the insect's abdomen "like small rockets". The fungi bore holes in the host but keep it alive with an amphetamine-like substance. The flies then buzz around for days, sprinkling more spores on other victims.

column3: NASA shares images of supermassive black holes merging
column4: NASA has shared images of two supermassive black holes in Galaxy NGC 6240 which are in the process of merging. "Seen as the bright dots near the center of this image, the black holes are just 3,000 light years apart," it said. "Eventually they will drift together, forming a larger black hole millions of years from now," NASA added.

column3: 30,000 tremors hit Antarctica in 3 months: Scientists
column4: More than 30,000 tremors have rocked Antarctica since the end of August, scientists at University of Chile said. The small earthquakes were detected in Bransfield Strait, an ocean channel between South Shetland Islands and Antarctic Peninsula. Several tectonic plates and microplates meet near the strait, leading to frequent rumbling, but the past three months have been unusual, scientists said.

column3: 'World's ugliest orchid' featured in Kew's list of 2020's top 10 discoveries
column4: Gastrodia agnicellus, nicknamed the 'ugliest orchid in the world', has featured in Kew's list of the top 10 discoveries of the year. The orchid depends on fungi for nutrition and has no leaves or any other photosynthetic tissue. As many as 156 plant and fungal species were named by Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, and partners worldwide in 2020.

column3: Human-made objects to outweigh living things by the end of 2020: Study
column4: Scientists have said that the weight of human-made objects will likely exceed that of living things by the end of the year. In a study published in the scientific journal Nature, scientists compared the overall living biomass on Earth, estimated to be around 1.1 teratonnes, to human-made mass. "We find that Earth is exactly at the crossover point," they said.

column3: Kangaroos can ask humans for help with their gaze: Study
column4: Kangaroos can learn to communicate with humans, a behaviour that was previously thought to be reserved for domesticated animals like dogs, by using their gaze to "point" and ask for help, a study revealed. It involved 11 kangaroos that lived in captivity. Ten of the 11 kangaroos gazed at researchers when they were unable to open a box with food.

column3: 1st known case of COVID-19 in non-captive wild mink found in US
column4: The first known case of COVID-19 in a non-captive wild mink has been confirmed, according to an alert issued by the US Department of Agriculture. The wild mink tested positive around an infected mink farm in Utah. The strain of the virus in the wild mink is "indistinguishable" from that in infected mink on farms around the state.

column3: Researchers develop first AI tool to detect COVID-19 probability
column4: A team of researchers from the University of Vermont and Cedars-Sinai has developed the first software to predict the probability of COVID-19 infections. AI-COVID uses details from routine blood tests and can assign the probability of a patient being COVID-19 negative with high accuracy. This can help hospitals reduce the number of patients referred for PCR testing.

column3: Delhi startup builds tech to do COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 cr samples per week
column4: Delhi-based IT startup Thalamus Irwine claims to have developed an artificial intelligence and IoT-based solution that can complete a COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 crore samples in one week. It has also partnered with state-run ITI to host its data. Serosurveys can help track the geographic spread of the virus by analysing antibodies in blood samples.

column3: Scientists digitally rebuild dinosaur's brain, learn about its diet
column4: The University of Bristol's scientists have "rebuilt" the brain of a Thecodontosaurus, that roamed England some 205 million years ago, using advanced imaging and 3D modelling techniques. They said unlike its plant-eating relatives, Thecodontosaurus may have eaten meat and could have walked on two legs. Experts also reconstructed its inner ears and estimated that it had a high hearing frequency.

column3: India to soon be manufacturing hub of space assets: PM Modi to space industry
column4: Prime Minister Narendra Modi in his interaction with the space sector's key industries, startups and academia expressed that India will soon become a manufacturing hub of space assets. He also assured participants that they will be co-passengers with ISRO in this age of space research. He added that private investment in the sector will lead to creation of hi-tech jobs.

column3: Blue Origin receives NASA approval to launch future uncrewed missions
column4: Amazon Founder Jeff Bezos-owned Blue Origin has received approval from NASA to launch future unmanned scientific and exploration missions aboard its reusable New Glenn launch vehicle. Under the contract, Blue Origin will be able to compete for national security launch contracts. The New Glenn booster is not expected to make its first flight until 2021.

column3: Superhighway system to travel via Solar System faster discovered: Scientists
column4: UC San Diego revealed researchers have discovered a new "superhighway" network to travel through the Solar System much faster. Such routes can drive comets and asteroids near Jupiter to Neptune in less than 10 years. Scientists found the routes by computing how "millions" of Solar System orbits fit within already-known space manifolds.

column3: New salamander species added to US' North Carolina's list of 63 species
column4: The US' North Carolina State added a new salamander species to its list of 63 species. The 'Carolina Sandhills Salamander' was previously categorised as an unusual population of the 'Southern Two-lined Salamander'. However, researchers used sequencing technology to show that the new species differs genetically. It also differs in colouration, size and natural history from complex's other members.

column3: China to open world's largest radio telescope to int'l scientists
column4: China will open the world's largest radio telescope for use by foreign astronomers. The Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST) has a diameter of half a kilometre and a receiving area equivalent to about 30 football fields. China has said it will accept requests in 2021 from foreign scientists wishing to carry out measurements.

column3: Bacteria can travel between continents via dust, impact climate: Study
column4: A study by scientists, including those from the University of Granada, revealed bacteria can travel between continents "hidden" in atmospheric dust. These microbes may not only affect human and animal health but also impact climate and ecosystems. Their transport occurs via atmospheric particles called iberulites that humans can inhale. These aerosols act like a "launch vehicle" for bacteria.

column3: Declare a State of Climate Emergency in your nations: UN to leaders
column4: World leaders should declare "States of Climate Emergency" in their countries until carbon neutrality is reached, UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said at a climate summit. "Can anybody still deny that we are facing a dramatic emergency?" he asked. He added G20 members are spending 50% more in their stimulus packages on fossil fuel-linked sectors and consumption, than on low-carbon energy.

column3: Corals from Aus' 'Coral IVF' trial survive bleaching, on track to reproduce
column4: Coral populations from Australia's first "Coral IVF" trial on the Great Barrier Reef in 2016 have survived bleaching events and are on track to reproduce next year. Scientists said the larvae restoration technique worked just as they predicted and large corals can grow from tiny microscopic larvae within few years. The technique was first used just off Heron Island.

column3: SL records 2nd-highest human deaths due to conflict with elephant: Report
column4: Sri Lanka has recorded the second-highest human deaths due to the human-elephant conflict in the world after India, Daily News reported. Sri Lanka's COPA revealed the number of human deaths has increased from an average of 85 humans to 122 per year in the past 12 months in Sri Lanka. However, it has recorded the highest number of elephant deaths.

column3: ISRO successfully launches India's 42nd communication satellite CMS-01
column4: The ISRO on Thursday successfully launched India's 42nd communication satellite from Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC) SHAR, Sriharikota. The PSLV-C50 launch vehicle put the communication satellite CMS-01 in orbit, that will provide coverage for disaster management and satellite internet connection. It's the first one in a new series of communication satellites after the INSAT and the GSAT series.

column3: Brazilian filmmaker drops iPhone from plane, it survives 300m drop & records free fall
column4: According to Brazilian media outlet G1's report, Brazilian documentary filmmaker Ernesto Galiotto dropped his iPhone 6s from a small plane's window accidentally while trying to capture a video. Galiotto claimed he found the phone near a beach by using GPS tracking and discovered it had survived the 300-metre drop. The phone had also recorded a video of the free fall.

column3: Sony removes Cyberpunk 2077 from PlayStation Store after complaints
column4: Sony on Friday said it is removing CD Projekt's Cyberpunk 2077 from its PlayStation Store and offering full refunds after gamers complained of bugs and compatibility issues. CD Projekt has promised to fix the bugs through updates. On Monday, the developers said they "should have paid more attention to making it play better on PlayStation 4 and Xbox One".

column3: No permission given for relaunch of PUBG Mobile in India: Govt
column4: The Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology in a response to an RTI query by GEM Esports clarified that the government has given "no permission" for the relaunch of PUBG Mobile app in the country. Earlier, reports claimed that PUBG Mobile made specifically for Indian public will be launched. PUBG Mobile was among several apps banned by government in September.

column3: Fake call centre that cheated 4,500 foreigners of ₹90 crore busted in Delhi
column4: Delhi Police busted a fake call centre where employees posed as personnel from law enforcement agencies and extorted money from foreigners saying that their details were found at crime scenes. The police made 54 arrests in connection with the call centre that cheated 4,500 foreigners of ₹90 crore. The mastermind of the fake call centre was allegedly operating from Dubai.

column3: Twitter to remove misleading tweets on COVID-19 vaccinations
column4: Twitter has said that starting next week, it will ask users to remove tweets that spread "false or misleading narratives about COVID-19 vaccinations". This rule will apply to tweets falsely claiming conspiracies, such as coronavirus vaccines are used to "intentionally cause harm to or control populations", or theories about adverse impacts of receiving vaccinations that have been widely debunked.

column3: Putting OTT under I&B aimed to bring content in one place: I&B Secy
column4: The idea behind government's move to bring OTT and content platforms under the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting (I&B) was to bring content at one place while keeping platforms at another, I&B Ministry Secretary Amit Khare said. "I am clarifying this because...there used to be a discussion that online and offline content should not be treated differently," Khare added.

column3: Google acquires firm that can turn old PCs into Chrome devices
column4: Google has acquired Neverware, a company that turns old PCs into Chrome devices, for an undisclosed amount. Neverware on its website said the company and its software CloudReady are now part of Google and the Chrome OS team. CloudReady converts old PCs into a system that runs Chrome OS, which is a lighter software and thereby reduces e-waste.

column3: Google wins EU approval for $2.1 billion Fitbit deal
column4: Google on Thursday won the European Union's antitrust approval for its $2.1 billion bid for Fitbit after it agreed to certain restrictions. Google pledged to maintain access for rival fitness and health apps and devices for 10 years. It also agreed to store the Fitbit user data separately from the Google data and to not use it for Google Ads.

column3: Addressing cybersecurity important for financial inclusion: RBI Guv
column4: RBI Governor Shaktikanta Das on Wednesday said that addressing the issues of cybersecurity and data protection is important for gaining confidence of the excluded section, which is necessary for promoting financial inclusion. He added that financial inclusion in India is poised to grow "exponentially" as millennials are joining the workforce and social media is blurring the urban-rural divide.

column3: Honda recalls 737,000 Accord, Insight cars in US over software flaw
column4: Honda is recalling 737,000 Accord gas and hybrid cars from 2018 to 2020 and Insight hybrid cars from 2019 to 2020 after discovering a glitch in its software. The programming flaw in its control computer can cause the rear camera, turn signals and windshield wipers to malfunction. The move comes as part of a larger recall of 1.79-million cars worldwide.

column3: Niue island demands redelegation of national webspace from ICANN
column4: Niue, an island in the South Pacific Ocean, has demanded a redelegation of national webspace .nu from the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN). Pär Brumark, who is leading the delegation on behalf of Niue, claims that no phone call was made to Niue when initial delegation happened. The .nu webspace is controlled by Internet Foundation in Sweden.

column3: Google faces 3rd antitrust lawsuit by US states over abuse of power
column4: A group of US State Attorneys General filed a lawsuit against Google on Wednesday for "anticompetitive conduct, exclusionary practices, and deceptive misrepresentations". This lawsuit focuses on Google's real-time auctions for ads. "Google repeatedly used its monopolistic powers to control pricing" and "engage in market collusions to rig auctions," Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton wrote.

column3: IBM CEO Arvind Krishna to take over as Chairman from January
column4: IBM Chief Executive Officer (CEO) Arvind Krishna will take over as the Chairman of the company from January 1, replacing Executive Chairman, Ginni Rometty. Rometty, who stepped down as IBM's CEO earlier this year, will occasionally be asked to act as an independent contractor after her retirement, the company said. Arvind Krishna has been a part of IBM since 1990.

column3: Twitter ends 'Quote Tweet' prompts, retweets back as before
column4: Twitter on Wednesday said it will no longer automatically show the 'Quote Tweet' prompt when users try to retweet something. It added its goal through the feature was to "encourage more thoughtful amplification", which "didn't happen in practice". Twitter said the use of Quote Tweets increased, but 45% of them included single-word affirmations and 70% had less than 25 characters.

column3: Google workers demand reinstatement, apology for allegedly fired AI expert
column4: A group of Google's AI researchers have demanded that the company reinstate and apologise to AI researcher Timnit Gebru who was allegedly fired over an academic paper she co-authored. They have also demanded that the team's Vice President Megan Kacholia be removed from its management chain, Bloomberg reported. CEO Sundar Pichai earlier said he was investigating the incident.

column3: Alibaba facial recognition tech specifically identifies Uighurs: IPVM
column4: Alibaba Cloud developed a facial recognition algorithm that can identify a person's ethnicity or whether a person is "Uighur", IPVM reported. Alibaba said it's "dismayed" to learn a unit developed software which can tag ethnicity in videos and that it never intended it to be used in this manner. It added the feature was "trial technology" not intended for customers.

column3: No element in Bajrang Dal's content that necessitates ban: Facebook
column4: Facebook’s India head Ajit Mohan on Wednesday said before a Parliamentary panel that its fact-checking team has not found any such element that necessitates a ban on the Bajrang Dal, as per reports. Mohan was questioned by a panel chaired by Shashi Tharoor about a media report suggesting that Facebook didn't ban Bajrang Dal due to business and safety reasons.

column3: Google's AR shopping feature to let users virtually try on makeup
column4: Google has launched an AR feature on Google app to allow users to virtually try on lipstick and eyeshadow from limited brands. When users search for a product on Google, they'll see the virtual try-on shopping experience at the top of search results. They will also see photos of models representing a range of skin tones wearing the product.

column3: Facebook, Google colluded to weaken ad competition: US antitrust lawsuit
column4: An antitrust lawsuit by Texas and nine other states alleged that Google and Facebook, two of the biggest players in online advertising, consolidated their power and weakened competition through collusion. "Facebook decided to dangle the threat of competition in Google's face and then cut a deal to manipulate the auction," it said. High-ranking company officials approved the deal, it said.

column3: Facebook claims Apple's iOS changes are bad for businesses in ads in US
column4: Facebook on Wednesday took out a series of full-page newspaper advertisements in US claiming Apple's mobile software changes are bad for small businesses. The ads targeted Apple's upcoming changes to its iOS 14 that prevent companies from gathering user data and using them for advertising. "We're standing up to Apple for small businesses everywhere," the headline of the ads said.

column3: Data Protection Bill won't get cleared in its current version: BJP MP
column4: BJP MP Rajeev Chandrasekhar, while speaking at the Global Technology Summit 2020, said the Data Protection Bill, 2019 will not get cleared in its current version. The committee is going to redraw the bill, he added. "Throughout this process witnesses would...argue as if privacy is a favour that is being done by the state for the citizens," he further said.

column3: Twitter shares hit 6-yr-high after JPMorgan upgrades its rating
column4: Shares of Twitter soared as much as 6% on Wednesday to record a six-year-high of $56.11 since October 2014 after JPMorgan upgraded its rating to "Overweight" from "Neutral". "We believe Twitter will show the biggest rebound [in online advertising] given its sharper pandemic-driven ad decline," JPMorgan said. Twitter shares are up more than 70% in 2020.

column3: Govt regulation isn't necessarily a bad thing: Instagram Head
column4: Adam Mosseri, the Head of Instagram, told Economic Times in an interview that government regulation is not "necessarily a bad thing and, very often, it is necessary". "We don't really want to be in the business of making content decisions," Mosseri said. "We think privacy is an area where we would love more specific guidance from governments," he further added.

column3: US board condemns naming local hospital after Mark Zuckerberg, his wife
column4: US' San Francisco Board of Supervisors has passed a resolution condemning the naming of a local hospital after Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Dr Priscilla Chan, alleging Facebook "endangered public health" by allowing misinformation to spread. The hospital was renamed the Priscilla Chan and Mark Zuckerberg San Francisco General Hospital and Trauma Center after they donated $75 million.

column3: Shane Warne calls Cheteshwar Pujara 'Steve', criticised for 'casual racism'
column4: Ex-Australia leg-spinner Shane Warne has been criticised for calling India batsman Cheteshwar Pujara as 'Steve' during the first day of the first Australia-India Test in Adelaide. "Referring to Pujara as ‘Steve’ is: a) unprofessional, b) disrespectful, c) racist...Learn to say his name," a fan wrote. "Sick, Casual racism," tweeted Jamie Alter.

column3: India lead by 62 runs after Day 2 as Ashwin records his best figures in Australia
