Talking about Bumrah, who is unbeaten on zero off 11 deliveries, Sunil Gavaskar said, "30-40 years down the road, Bumrah's going to tell his grandchildren, 'I batted number three for India'." Gavaskar added, "He won't tell the circumstances."

column3: You are welcome to have your child in Australia: Brett Lee to Virat Kohli
column4: Former Australia fast bowler Brett Lee, in a message to Team India captain Virat Kohli, said, "If you would like to Mr Kohli, you are welcome to have your child in Australia." He added, "If you have a little girl, fantastic. If you have a little boy, fantastic. They might become a Baggy Green."

column3: Indians are in Christmas mood, giving gifts a week early: Gavaskar on fielding
column4: Former India captain Sunil Gavaskar trolled India's fielding in the ongoing Test against Australia in Adelaide. After Prithvi Shaw dropped Marnus Labuschagne on the bowling of Jasprit Bumrah, Gavaskar said, "All I can think of is the Indians are in a Christmas mood. Giving their Christmas gifts a week early."  Labuschagne, who was dropped multiple times, scored 47(119).

column3: Shane Warne calls Cheteshwar Pujara 'Steve', criticised for 'casual racism'
column4: Ex-Australia leg-spinner Shane Warne has been criticised for calling India batsman Cheteshwar Pujara as 'Steve' during the first day of the first Australia-India Test in Adelaide. "Referring to Pujara as ‘Steve’ is: a) unprofessional, b) disrespectful, c) racist...Learn to say his name," a fan wrote. "Sick, Casual racism," tweeted Jamie Alter.

column3: Labuschagne trolled after video of him shouting 'No run' on leaving ball goes viral
column4: Australia batsman Marnus Labuschagne has been trolled for shouting 'No run' after leaving his first delivery in the first Test against India bowled by Jasprit Bumrah. "Labuschagne shouting 'No run' after a leave is peak Marnus Labuschagne," a fan tweeted. "Shrieking 'No run' as you aggressively leave the ball way outside off is pure boss mode," wrote another.

column3: Who won what at The Best FIFA Football Awards 2020?
column4: Bayern Munich forward Robert Lewandowski and England defender Lucy Bronze were named The Best FIFA Men's and Women's Player, respectively. Meanwhile, Jürgen Klopp claimed The Best FIFA Men’s Coach Award for the second consecutive year. Tottenham forward Son Heung-min won the Puskás Award for his goal against Burnley. Bayern Munich's Manuel Neuer was chosen as The Best FIFA Men’s Goalkeeper.

column3: Russia's int'l sporting ban halved to 2 years, country to still miss next 2 Olympics
column4: Russia has had a four-year ban from international sports events halved to two years by Court of Arbitration for Sport. The ban still covers events including the next editions of Summer and Winter Olympics. Russia was handed a four-year ban in December 2019 after allegations that falsified lab data was sent to WADA investigators by the Russian Anti-Doping Agency (RUSADA).

column3: Different pitches test different skillsets, about time we appreciate that: Jaffer
column4: Talking about the first Australia-India Test's second day, ex-India opener Wasim Jaffer tweeted, "While we rightly appreciate Adelaide pitch...can't help but wonder if 15 wickets were to fall on Day 2 on a subcontinent pitch with similar RR." He added, "It would've been termed as a "dustbowl" and what not. Different pitches test different skillsets. About time we appreciate that."

column3: What's he looking at: Warne on umpire Oxenford's blunder in Australia-India Test
column4: Ex-Australia leg-spinner Shane Warne criticised umpire Bruce Oxenford for his multiple errors during the ongoing first Australia-India Test. Referring to Oxenford declaring Nathan Lyon LBW out on Ravichandran Ashwin's bowling despite the ball hitting the bat, Warne said, "This is a huge mistake. Look how much that deviates. You could hear the two noises straight away. What's he looking at?"

column3: Virat Kohli fails to hit a hundred in 2020, goes 392 days without scoring a ton
column4: Playing his last international innings of 2020, India captain Virat Kohli got out for 4(8) against Australia in Adelaide Test. With this, he failed to score a hundred in 2020, marking the first instance of him failing to score an international hundred in a calendar year since 2008. Kohli last hit an international hundred 392 days and 30 innings ago.

column3: They've been defensive, sitting back: McGrath on Aus getting all out for 191
column4: Criticising Australia's batting in their first innings at Adelaide, former pacer Glenn McGrath said that Tim Paine-led side has been defensive in their approach. "[They were] sitting back, waiting for the bad ball and just taking singles...Indian bowlers have been able to bowl wherever they want," he stated. Australia got bundled out for 191, trailing India by 53 runs.

column3: Lyon builds pressure, he'll be a massive threat for India: Ponting
column4: Former Australia captain Ricky Ponting has said that spinner Nathan Lyon, who gave 68 runs in his 21 overs during India's first innings at Adelaide, will be a "massive threat" for the visitors. "Lyon looked like he troubled Pujara...He builds pressure, he bowls very few bad balls," Ponting added. Lyon has picked 390 wickets in 96 Tests.

column3: Give him to me and see wonders he does on ground: Akhtar on Amir's retirement
column4: After Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) accepted 28-year-old pacer Mohammad Amir's decision to retire from international cricket, ex-Pakistan pacer Shoaib Akhtar has urged PCB to not waste the pacer and let him train under him instead. Amir, who had already retired from Tests was not included in 35-member squad for the New Zealand series. Amir retired over "shabby" treatment from PCB.

column3: Not surprised that Prithvi Shaw got out early: Sanjay Manjrekar
column4: India opener Prithvi Shaw was dismissed for a duck in India's first innings at Adelaide and for four runs in the second. Reacting to it, Sanjay Manjrekar said that he was not surprised by Shaw's form. "We saw...signs in the IPL and the warm-up matches...but selectors supported him...[and] now...it's difficult for him to play the next Test match," he added.

column3: Australia underestimated him: Ponting on Ashwin's 4/55
column4: On Ravichandran Ashwin producing his best bowling figures on Australian soil at Adelaide, former Australia captain Ricky Ponting said that Tim Paine-led side underestimated the off-spinner. "They've looked to score their runs from him, and it's been their undoing," Ponting stated. Ashwin took four wickets in his 18 overs, giving 55 runs.

column3: Don't want to think if it's my best or not, there's still entire series: Ashwin on 4/55
column4: India off-spinner Ravichandran Ashwin on Friday produced his best bowling figures of 4/55 on Australian soil at Adelaide. On being asked about his performance, Ashwin said he doesn't want to "sit back" and think whether it's his best performance or not as there's still the entire series ahead. Australia got all out for 191 runs in their first innings.

column3: India bowled really well, put us under pressure: Paine after Day 2
column4: After India bundled out Australia for 191 in their first innings at Adelaide, Australia Test captain Tim Paine said India bowled "really well" and put them under pressure. "We just could not get any momentum or any partnerships together, we couldn't quite do that," he added. "We've got to chase...[and]...we know it is going to be a challenge," he added.

column3: Lyon only troubled batsmen, Ashwin took wickets as well: Ajay Jadeja
column4: Talking about India's bowling at the Adelaide Test, former Team India cricketer Ajay Jadeja said that off-spinner Ravichandran Ashwin today went one step further from Nathan Lyon. "[Australia spinner] only troubled the [Indian] batsmen but Ashwin took the wickets as well," he added. Ashwin took four wickets in his 18 overs, giving 55 runs.

column3: NZ defeat Pak in 1st T20I as Jacob Duffy registers best figures on debut by NZ player
column4: New Zealand on Friday chased down Pakistan's 153-run total and won the first T20I by five wickets, taking 1-0 lead in the three-match series. Jacob Duffy, 26-year-old, registered the best bowling figures of 33/4 on T20I debut by a New Zealand player. Pakistan had won the toss and elected bat first but were reduced to 20/4.

column3: Secret Covid-19 vaccine price list of EU revealed by Belgian minister
column4: A Belgian minister, Eva De Bleeker, on Thursday tweeted a list containing the confidential prices that the European Union has agreed to pay for six leading Covid-19 vaccines. The table showed the EU paid ₹160 per dose for the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine, ₹1,082 for Pfizer's and ₹1,325 for Moderna's vaccine. She subsequently deleted her tweet.

column3: US Vice President Mike Pence receives COVID-19 vaccine live on TV
column4: US Vice President Mike Pence received the coronavirus vaccine live on television on Friday. The White House said the aim of the move was to "promote the safety and efficacy of the vaccine and build confidence among the American people". Along with Pence, his wife Karen Pence and Surgeon General Jerome Adams were also administered the vaccine.

column3: Moderna COVID-19 vaccine overwhelmingly approved: Trump
column4: US President Donald Trump on Friday announced that Moderna's vaccine against coronavirus has been "overwhelmingly approved" and its distribution will start immediately. This comes after a recommendation by an expert panel on Thursday to grant emergency use approval for the vaccine in the US. Earlier, the US' Food and Drug Administration authorised the use of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine.

column3: India planning surgical strike against us: Pakistan
column4: Pakistan's Foreign Minister Shah Mahmood Qureshi has claimed that India is planning a surgical strike on its neighbouring country. "I have learnt through our intelligence sources...This is a serious development and I also have knowledge that they have tried to seek approval from...their partners," he stated. Qureshi said this during a press conference in Abu Dhabi on Friday.

column3: Biden names Indian-American Vedant Patel as Assistant WH Secretary
column4: US President-elect Joe Biden on Friday named Indian-American Vedant Patel as Assistant White House Secretary. Patel, who's the senior spokesperson of the Biden inaugural committee, had earlier served as Regional Communications Director on the Biden-Harris campaign. "I took the leap with Joe Biden when he announced because I believed in his vision for what this country could be," Patel said.

column3: South Africa identifies new coronavirus strain driving second wave of cases
column4: South Africa has identified a new variant of the coronavirus that is driving the second wave of infections, Health Minister Zweli Mkhize said. This comes days after the UK said it had also found a new variant of the virus boosting cases. The WHO said it was in touch with the South African researchers who identified the new variant.

column3: 'Zombie Angelina Jolie' seen for 1st time since she was released from prison
column4: Iranian Instagram star Sahar Tabar, also known as 'Zombie Angelina Jolie', has been seen for the first time since she was released from prison. Tabar, who was jailed for 10 years on charges including corruption and blasphemy, appeared in a TV interview. The state-run Rokna news agency did not reveal what she said in the interview.

column3: 1,000 vehicles stuck in 16-km-long traffic jam after snow storm in Japan
column4: More than 1,000 vehicles in Japan were stranded in a traffic jam that stretched up to 16 kilometres. The jam began after a car got stuck in deep snow in the middle of a highway, said NEXCO, Japan's highway operator. Self-Defense Force troops were delivering food, petrol and blankets, while fire service crews rescued some drivers, public broadcaster NHK said.

column3: 58-year-old man trapped for 10 hours after his car gets buried under 4 feet of snow
column4: A 58-year-old man has been rescued after his car was buried under four feet of snow in a severe storm in upstate New York. The man was left stranded in freezing temperatures for over 10 hours. The man had no heat in his car and was suffering from hypothermia and frostbite. He was taken to a hospital after being rescued.

column3: Kidnappers are tiny boys with big guns: Freed Nigerian schoolboy
column4: As many as 344 schoolboys who were rescued from kidnappers in Nigeria arrived back home on Friday. "They (kidnappers) said I should say they are Boko Haram...Sincerely speaking, they are not Boko Haram...They are just small and tiny, tiny boys with big guns," a schoolboy who was rescued said. Boko Haram had said it was behind the kidnapping.

column3: Men who dragged 70-yr-old woman naked over son's affair acquitted in Egypt
column4: Three men who stripped and dragged a 70-year-old Christian woman through an Egyptian village over rumours that her son was having an affair with a Muslim woman have been acquitted by a court. Soad Thabet, now 74, was the victim of the attack in 2016. "What can I say? God will bring back my rights," she said.

column3: 2 develop allergic reactions after receiving Pfizer's vaccine in US: Report
column4: Two US healthcare workers developed allergic reactions after receiving Pfizer's COVID-19 vaccine this week, The New York Times reported. One of the healthcare workers, a middle-aged woman, who had no history of allergies, had an anaphylactic reaction 10 minutes after receiving the vaccine. She experienced a rash over her face and torso, shortness of breath and an elevated heart rate.

column3: COVID-19 vaccine delivery to poor nations to start in early 2021: WHO
column4: World Health Organisation on Friday said that the coronavirus vaccine delivery to poorer countries, through its COVAX vaccine-sharing scheme, will begin in the first half of 2021. However, WHO added that the deliveries remained "contingent upon regulatory approvals and countries' readiness for delivery". The agency has secured almost two billion doses of candidate vaccines.

column3: China to vaccinate 5 crore people for Lunar New Year: Report
column4: China is planning to vaccinate 5 crore people against COVID-19 before peak Lunar New Year travel season begins in 2021, a report said. Officials have been told to complete first 5 crore doses by January 15 and the second by February 5. Beijing will distribute 10 crore doses of two-dose vaccines made by China's Sinopharm and Sinovac, the report added.

column3: China COVID-19 vaccine trials resume in Peru after 'adverse event'
column4: Peru has resumed the clinical trials of China's Sinopharm COVID-19 vaccine after an "adverse event" in one of the volunteers was "clarified", Health Minister Pilar Mazzetti said. The clinical trials were suspended last week after neurological problems were detected in the volunteer. Sinopharm is conducting its trials in Peru with nearly 12,000 volunteers.

column3: US President-elect Biden to get COVID-19 vaccine publicly on Monday
column4: US President-elect Joe Biden and his wife, Jill Biden, will take the coronavirus vaccine publicly to boost public confidence in the vaccine's safety on Monday, his press secretary said. Vice President-elect Kamala Harris and her husband, Doug Emhoff, will get their shots the following week. This comes as Vice President Mike Pence received the vaccination on live television on Friday.

column3: Contracted COVID-19 because of negligence, bad luck: French Prez
column4: French President Emmanuel Macron said that he contracted COVID-19 due to "a moment of negligence, a moment of bad luck". Urging people to stay safe, Macron added that his infection "shows that the virus really can touch everyone". Meanwhile, Slovakia's PM Igor Matovič, who met Macron at an EU summit last week, tested positive for COVID-19 on Friday.

column3: US Space Force personnel will be called 'Guardians': Vice Prez
column4: The members of the US Space Force will be called "Guardians", Vice President Mike Pence announced at an event celebrating Space Force's first anniversary. "The name Guardians connects our proud heritage and culture to the important mission we execute 24/7, protecting the people and interest of the US and its allies," the Space Force tweeted.

column3: Respect her sentiment: India after B'desh PM says Pak can't be forgiven for 1971
column4: India has said that it deeply "respects and understands" sentiments expressed by Bangladesh PM Sheikh Hasina after she said Pakistan can't be forgiven for the atrocities it committed during the 1971 war. "There is no denying that state sponsored oppression against Bangladesh's just war of liberation led to the death of 3 million people," the Ministry of External Affairs added.

column3: Spain's lower house approves bill legalising euthanasia
column4: Spain's lower house of parliament has voted in favour of a bill that will legalise euthanasia, despite strong opposition from religious groups. The legislation allows patients with "serious and incurable" diseases that cause "unbearable" suffering to choose to end their lives. The bill will now go to the Senate for vote. Currently, euthanasia is legal in three European Union countries.

column3: US lists China, Russia as main rivals in new maritime strategy
column4: The US has warned that its Navy will adopt a more "assertive" approach to Chinese and Russian aggression. China and Russia are "determined rivals" of the US, with China presenting "the most pressing long-term strategic threat", according to US maritime forces' strategy document. The report accused Russia and China of employing instruments of power to undermine the international system.

column3: Deaf S Korean pastor charged in Malaysia with sexually assaulting 2 men
column4: A Malaysian court on Friday charged a deaf South Korean pastor, Jee Jong Hoon, with sexually assaulting two men in separate incidents in 2013 and 2017, his lawyer said. Police said that the alleged victims, who were in their 20s, had speech and hearing impairments. Jee could face up to 10 years in prison, a fine or both, if convicted.

column3: Iran rejects IAEA's call for new nuclear deal after Biden takes office
column4: Iran rejected the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) chief's suggestion to strike a new nuclear deal with Joe Biden's administration. There would be no renegotiation on the 2015 nuclear deal, Kazem Gharibabadi, Iran's IAEA ambassador in Vienna, said. The commitments of the parties were delicately drafted and they know what to do to implement the deal, he added.

column3: World has entered era of consequences of global warming: French envoy
column4: Speaking at an event marking the fifth anniversary of Paris climate accord, French Ambassador to India Emmanuel Lenain said the world has "entered the era of consequences of global warming". Next year will be very important in fight against climate change, he added. The accord aims to limit global temperature rise this century to 2°C or 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels.

column3: Bihar Cabinet approves free coronavirus vaccine for all in state
column4: Bihar Cabinet on Tuesday approved a proposal to provide free COVID-19 vaccine to all the people of the state. "Our decision is a big gift to people of the state after formation of the government," Deputy Chief Minister Tarkishore Prasad said. The Cabinet also decided to generate 20 lakh jobs in government and non-government sectors in the next five years.

column3: TMC MLA Silbhadra resigns from party, 3rd leader to quit in 2 days
column4: Trinamool Congress MLA Silbhadra Datta has resigned from the party, becoming the third leader to quit in two days. Earlier, MLA Jitendra Tiwari quit the party and as chief of the Asansol Municipal Corporation, however, he said he won't resign from the MLA post. On Wednesday, TMC leader Suvendu Adhikari resigned from the membership of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly.

column3: Suvendu Adhikari quits as member of Trinamool Congress
column4: Trinamool Congress leader Suvendu Adhikari has quit as a member of the party as well as from all other positions held by him in the party and its associate organs. Adhikari resigned from the membership of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly on Wednesday. He had quit as West Bengal Transport Minister and from other posts earlier.

column3: Trinamool Congress leader Suvendu Adhikari resigns as MLA
column4: Trinamool Congress leader Suvendu Adhikari resigned from the membership of the West Bengal Legislative Assembly on Wednesday. This comes days after Adhikari quit as West Bengal transport minister and from other posts. "He is welcome in the party if he wishes to join us," BJP state unit president Dilip Ghosh was earlier quoted as saying by IANS.

column3: COVID-19 +ve Haryana minister Anil Vij shifted to Gurugram hospital
column4: Haryana minister Anil Vij, who had tested positive for COVID-19, was shifted to Medanta hospital in Gurugram from Rohtak's Post Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences on Tuesday. A doctor said, "The Health Minister has been diagnosed with COVID-19 pneumonia, leading to infection in lungs." Vij had got one shot of the two-dose trial of the COVID-19 vaccine Covaxin last month.

column3: AAP to contest UP elections in 2022: Arvind Kejriwal
column4: Aam Aadmi Party chief and Delhi CM Arvind Kejriwal has said the party will contest the state elections in Uttar Pradesh in 2022. "A lot of people from UP who live in Delhi have told us that UP too deserves the welfare and benefits like Delhi," he added. He also said that all parties in UP have betrayed the people.

column3: Cong MLCs manhandle, remove K'taka Legislative Council Dy Chairman
column4: Congress MLCs on Tuesday manhandled and forcefully removed Deputy Chairman SL Dharmegowda from the chair in Karnataka Legislative Council. Congress MLC Prakash Rathod said BJP and JD(S) made him sit illegally when the House was not in order and therefore they evicted him. BJP MLC Lehar Singh Siroya said, "We've never seen such a shameful day in our Council's history."

column3: PM lights Swarnim Vijay Mashaal to mark start of 50th anniversary of 1971 war win
column4: PM Narendra Modi on Wednesday lit up 'Swarnim Vijay Mashaal' at National War Memorial, marking the beginning of the 50th anniversary year of India's victory over Pakistan in 1971 war. Four Victory Mashaals lit from Eternal Flame will be carried to various parts of India including to villages of Param Vir Chakra and Maha Vir Chakra awardees of 1971 war.

column3: TMC MLA Banasri Maity resigns from party, 4th leader to quit in 48 hours
column4: Trinamool Congress MLA Banasri Maity from West Bengal's Kanthi Uttar on Friday tendered her resignation from the "primary membership and from each and every post" of the party. Maity is the fourth leader to resign from TMC in the past 48 hours after Suvendu Adhikari, Jitendra Tiwari and Silbhadra Datta. Notably, Tiwari on Friday took his resignation back.

column3: Centre asks WB to relieve 3 IPS officers immediately, CM criticises order
column4: The Centre on Thursday asked the West Bengal government to immediately relieve three Indian Police Service officers for joining a central deputation. In response to the Centre's order, Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee called it "blatant misuse of power" and said she won't cow-down before the "expansionist" and "undemocratic" forces. "It's unconstitutional and completely unacceptable," she tweeted.

column3: Kerala CM claims victory in local body polls, says BJP, UDF should introspect
column4: Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan claimed victory in local body polls and said it's "a befitting reply to those who are trying to destroy Kerala". "BJP and UDF who have taken anti-development campaign should withdraw from it and do an introspection," he added. Vijayan-led Left Democratic Front was leading in 514 out of 941 gram panchayats, according to State Election Commission.

column3: BJP launched campaign to divide farmers, defame movement: Akhilesh
column4: Samajwadi Party chief Akhilesh Yadav on Tuesday said that the farmers are agitating for the past 20 days and instead of listening to them, the government has adopted a stubborn attitude. He added, "Not only this, but the BJP has also launched a campaign to divide farmers and discredit the movement and defame it."

column3: 99.9% Congress members want Rahul Gandhi as party chief: Surjewala
column4: Congress leader Randeep Surjewala said on Friday that the party would soon start the procedure to elect a new President. He added that 99.9% of party members including him wanted Rahul Gandhi as the President of Congress. "Electoral college of Congress, AICC members, Congress workers and members will choose who is best suited," said Surjewala.

column3: Cong demands account of foreign donations made to PM CARES Fund
column4: The Congress on Wednesday demanded an account of the foreign donations received by the PM CARES Fund. Congress General Secretary Randeep Surjewala tweeted, "Questions to PM - Why did Indian Embassies publicise & receive donation to PM Cares Fund? Why was the Fund advertised on banned Chinese apps?" He added, "How much money was received from Pakistan & who donated?"

column3: CPI, CPI(M) leaders protest in Hyderabad against farm laws
column4: CPI and CPI(M) leaders, among other Left party leaders in Telangana, on Monday protested in Hyderabad against the government's three new farm laws. They held placards demanding abrogation of the three "pro-corporate" farm laws and boycott of certain big corporates. Senior Congress leader V Hanumantha Rao observed a fast from 10 am to 4 pm at his residence in Hyderabad.

column3: No coercive steps against BJP leaders: SC to WB govt over FIRs
column4: The Supreme Court on Friday directed the West Bengal government to not take any coercive steps against BJP leaders, including Arjun Singh, Kailash Vijayvargiya and Mukul Roy, regarding the FIRs registered against them. According to the petition, false cases were being foisted on BJP leaders in order to prevent them from entering the state ahead of assembly elections next year.

column3: Not a protest site: Javadekar after Rahul walks out of Standing Committee
column4: Union Minister and BJP leader Prakash Javadekar said that Congress' Rahul Gandhi attended two of the 14 meetings of Parliamentary Standing Committee on Defence in one and a half years. "He's himself absent and then blames govt...Standing Committee isn't a protest site," Javadekar added. This comes after Gandhi and Congress members walked out of Defence Parliamentary Panel meeting.

column3: Noida airport, Ganga Expressway are BSP's development models: Mayawati
column4: BSP National President and former UP CM Mayawati on Friday said, "In UP, be it Ganga Expressway...or the new airport to be built in Jewar (Noida)…these are the eminent models of development formulated in the BSP government." She added, "First, the SP and now the present BJP government keeps patting itself on its back over these."

column3: Kamal Haasan is spoiling families through 'Bigg Boss': TN CM
column4: Tamil Nadu CM Edappadi K Palaniswami alleged that Makkal Needhi Maiam chief and 'Bigg Boss' host Kamal Haasan is "spoiling" families through the Tamil TV series. "What will happen if a man hosting 'Bigg Boss' enters politics? Not one family...will be good if they watch it," he added. "Haasan [doesn't have] ambition to do good for the country," Palaniswami stated.

column3: Kolkata Municipal Corporation polls likely in March 2021: Official
column4: The Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) elections​ are likely to be held in March 2021, senior officials of West Bengal State Election Commission said. "As per the Supreme Court's directive, the state government has sent a communication to us saying that the KMC polls may be held within four weeks after the final electoral roll is adopted," an official said.

column3: Sonia Gandhi to convene a meeting with Cong leaders on Sat: Reports
column4: Congress party's Interim President Sonia Gandhi has called for a meeting of party leaders on Saturday to formulate the party's strategy on the current political scenario amid the ongoing farmers' agitation, according to reports. "The leaders who will be meeting Sonia Gandhi include those who...have specific concerns with [the party's] functioning," a party functionary said.

column3: Opposition leaders doing politics over farm bills: Smriti Irani
column4: Speaking at a farmers' conference in Uttar Pradesh's Meerut, Union Minister Smriti Irani said that the opposition leaders have never worked for the farmers and they are doing politics by opposing the farm bills. She added, "What's so objectionable in the bills that the Congress and other UPA supporters are protesting against it?"

column3: Farm laws issue can be solved in 5 mins if PM steps in: Sanjay Raut
column4: Shiv Sena leader Sanjay Raut said that the government can resolve the issue raised by protesting farmers in 30 minutes by sitting with them. "If the Prime Minister intervenes himself, it will be resolved in five minutes. Modi ji is such a big leader, everyone will listen to him," he added. Farmers have been protesting over Centre's new farm laws.

column3: Cong mayor candidate loses by 1 vote to BJP opponent in Kerala local body polls
column4: Congress mayoral candidate N Venugopal lost to BJP candidate by one vote in Kochi Corporation North Island ward in Kerala's local body elections. "There was problem with the voting machine. That may be reason for BJP's victory," Venugopal said. "I haven't decided to go to court with the voting machine issue so far. Will check what happened exactly," he added.

column3: TMC MLA Jitendra Tiwari quits party hours after Suvendu Adhikari
column4: Trinamool Congress MLA Jitendra Tiwari on Thursday quit the party and as chief of the Asansol Municipal Corporation. However, he said he won't resign from the MLA post. Tiwari had accused the West Bengal government of depriving Asansol of central funds under the Smart Cities Mission project. Earlier on Thursday, TMC leader Suvendu Adhikari quit as a party member.

column3: I never asked Sana to leave showbiz, even I was shocked when she quit: Husband
column4: Ex-actress Sana Khan's husband Anas Saiyad has said he never forced Sana to leave showbiz. "I've never forced her to lead life in a certain way...She always wanted to detach herself from what she was doing...I was shocked too when she quit," he added. He further said that "narrow-minded people" still ask him why he got married to an actress.

column3: Remo D'souza posts video after returning home from hospital
column4: Choreographer-filmmaker Remo D'souza, who was hospitalised after suffering a heart attack, has posted a video after returning home. "Thank you all for the love, prayers and blessings I am back," he wrote. Commenting on the video, choreographer Terence Lewis wrote, "This made my day! So happy to see you safe home with your loved ones! Stay blessed."

column3: TV actor Anas Rashid blessed with baby boy, shares pics
column4: TV actor Anas Rashid, known for show 'Diya Aur Baati Hum', and his wife Heena Iqbal have been blessed with their second child, a baby boy. He took to Instagram to share pictures of the newborn with his grandparents and wrote, "My father welcomes home his grandson -'Khabib Anas Rashid'. Thanks for all your...love and wishes on this awaited occasion."

column3: He's very simple: Kirti on working with Pankaj in 'Criminal Justice'
column4: Speaking about her experience of working with actor Pankaj Tripathi in the crime drama web series 'Criminal Justice: Behind Closed Doors', actress Kirti Kulhari said that the actor is a "very simple" man. "Most of my scenes are with Pankaj Tripathi and he is...easy to work with...He does his thing and I did mine...it all went very smooth," she added.

column3: 'Malang' allowed me to explore myself as an actor: Disha Patani
column4: Talking about her crime-drama film 'Malang', actress Disha Patani said, "[It] allowed me to explore myself as an actor and grow more." She added, "We're inching closer towards 2021 but the love that the film has been getting constantly feels like the film just released yesterday." Directed by Mohit Suri, 'Malang' also starred Aditya Roy Kapur and Anil Kapoor.

column3: NCB received reply from Johar, he said no drug was consumed at party: Official
column4: Karan Johar, in his response to the notice issued by the NCB, said that no drugs were consumed at a party hosted at his residence last year, an official told PTI. Johar was asked to send his response and produce documents/electronic evidence, with regard to the party video in which some celebrities were accused of being in a "drugged state".

column3: Today would've been his 50 yrs in Bollywood: Neetu remembers Rishi
column4: Neetu Kapoor on Friday remembered her late husband Rishi Kapoor as his film 'Mera Naam Joker' completed 50 years of release. Sharing a collage of Rishi on Instagram, she wrote, "'Mera Naam Joker' released on 18th December 1970...today would've been his 50 years in...Indian film industry." Commenting on Neetu's post, Anil Kapoor wrote, "Miss his presence on and off screen."

column3: Whatever we are today is because of theatres and our films: Rajkummar
column4: Commenting on the digital platforms versus theatres debate, actor Rajkummar Rao said, "Theatres are very important. Whatever we are today is because of theatres and our films. Nobody can deny their importance." He further said, " The OTT industry will always be there, as a very strong parallel industry, but nothing can replace the community viewing experience."

column3: Being a public figure does not mean public property: Kirti
column4: Stating that media should give actors some space for their personal lives, actress Kirti Kulhari said, "Being a public figure does not mean public property. We should not be forced to answer political and personal questions." During the interview with Navbharat Times, she said, "My biggest responsibility is my acting...I am responsible for the questions related to my work."

column3: YouTuber CarryMinati to make B'wood debut with Big B, Ajay's MayDay
column4: YouTuber CarryMinati, whose real name is Ajey Nagar, is set to make his Bollywood debut with Ajay Devgn and Amitabh Bachchan starrer 'MayDay'. "I agreed to be...part of this film because I'd to essay my own character (CarryMinati)," he said. "I'm hoping I get to learn a thing or two about acting from Amitabh Bachchan and Ajay Devgn," he added.

column3: If I can wear mask while giving birth, you can wear mask while shopping: Sophie
column4: Hollywood actress Sophie Turner, who welcomed a daughter with husband Joe Jonas in July, took to Instagram to urge people to wear masks amid the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. "If I can wear a mask while I give birth, you can wear a mask at Walmart," she said in a video posted on her Instagram stories.

column3: I've prayed for yrs for a man like him: Sana on marrying Anas Saiyad
column4: Sana Khan, who married Gujarat-based Anas Saiyad in November, spoke about her wedding and said, "Getting married to Anas wasn't an overnight decision." She added that she had prayed for years "for a man like him". Speaking about her plans of becoming a mother, she said, "My husband wants me to take time, but I definitely want to become...mother soon."

column3: Saw myself open up as a person: Saiee Manjrekar on life post debut
column4: Mahesh Manjrekar's daughter, actress Saiee Manjrekar, who made her debut with Salman Khan's 'Dabangg 3', has said her life after her debut has been "super". "Normally, I've always been a...shy person. I saw myself open up as a person after that," she added. "With all...interactions, and meeting people daily, I kind of started being more aware of...things happening," Saiee said.

column3: Swara Bhasker joins farmers' protest at Delhi's Singhu border
column4: Actress Swara Bhasker joined the farmers' protest at Delhi's Singhu border on Thursday. Taking to Twitter, she shared a few pictures from the ongoing protest and wrote, "A humbling day to see the grit, resolve and determination of protesting farmers and the elderly at #SinghuBorder #FarmersProtests." Earlier, actor-singer Diljit Dosanjh was also spotted at the protest at Singhu border.

column3: My husband was called a terrorist, a Pakistani: Urmila on trolling
column4: Talking about her experience with trolls, Urmila Matondkar revealed that her husband, Mohsin Akhtar, was called a terrorist and a Pakistani. She added, "My husband isn't only a Muslim but a Kashmiri Muslim. We both follow our religions in...equally staunch way...That gave them a bigger platform to troll me and constantly target him and his family. It was very unfortunate."

column3: Neetu returns to 'Jug Jugg Jeeyo' shoot post COVID-19 recovery
column4: After recovering from COVID-19, actress Neetu Kapoor resumed shooting for her upcoming film 'Jug Jugg Jeeyo' on Friday. The film's director Raj Mehta welcomed her with a handwritten note, which Neetu shared on Instagram. "I know it's been a strange roadblock, but just wanted to say "Thank You" for being such an integral part of the film," the note read.

column3: Social media is judging Bollywood wives from the beginning: Maheep
column4: Actor Sanjay Kapoor's wife Maheep Kapoor, who recently featured in the web show 'Fabulous Lives of Bollywood Wives', said the biggest pressure of being a Bollywood wife is being judged. "Right from the beginning, social media is judging them, taking pictures. That is difficult. Everyone has pressure...Everyone has tensions at home. Everyone has their own stories," she added.

column3: I was typecast in a mother's role very early in life: Shefali Shah
column4: In a recent interview, actress Shefali Shah mentioned that she got typecast as a mother quite early in her acting career. "I was 20. I did a show where I played the mother of a 15-year-old...And then, when I was around 28-30, I played mother to Akshay Kumar. According to screen time, I'm probably 133 years or something," she said.

column3: Not thinking about directing, I'm enjoying casting: Dil Bechara director
column4: Casting director Mukesh Chhabra, who directed late actor Sushant Singh Rajput's 'Dil Bechara', has said he has no plans to direct his second film as of now. He added that he may think about it when the right script comes his way. "I am enjoying the process of casting for all my projects at hand," Mukesh further said.

column3: A designer told my team they don't give clothes to TV actors: Shivangi Joshi
column4: TV actress Shivangi Joshi, who stars in show 'Yeh Rishta Kya Kehlata Hai', has said she feels hurt when people look down upon the medium. Sharing her experience with a fashion designer, she said, "I'd once wanted to wear a particular designer's clothes, but my team was told that they don't give their clothes to TV actors...It does feel bad."

column3: Remaking films makes things easier, but there's no fun: Anurag
column4: Stating that he has consciously decided to avoid remaking films, filmmaker Anurag Basu said, "There are many directors like me who don't make remakes. When you have a story to tell...it's better to attempt that." He further explained, "Making a remake makes it easier...your structure is ready. But there's no fun, we thrive on creating something new."

column3: Lopez to play FBI agent in 'The Cipher' movie adaptation: Reports
column4: Singer-actress Jennifer Lopez will reportedly star in the film adaptation of the bestselling book, 'The Cipher', written by Isabella Maldonado. In addition to featuring in the film, Lopez will also reportedly produce it. According to Variety, Lopez will play FBI agent Nina Guerrera, who tries to solve a serial killer's case. The film will release on a digital platform.

column3: Ajay to remake Telugu comedy film 'Brochevarevarura' in Hindi: Reports
column4: Bollywood actor-producer Ajay Devgn has reportedly purchased the Hindi remake rights of the 2019 Telugu crime-comedy film 'Brochevarevarura'. Reportedly, Ajay will produce the Hindi remake. The original film was directed by Vivek Athreya and it starred actors Sree Vishnu, Nivetha Thomas, Nivetha Pethuraj and Satyadev Kancharana. The Hindi remake will reportedly star Abhay Deol and Karan Deol.

column3: Felt like a child in a private magic show: Nimrat on watching Tenet in theatre
column4: Actress Nimrat Kaur took to Instagram to share her experience of watching Christopher Nolan's 'Tenet' in a theatre amid the coronavirus pandemic. "Today, nearly after 10 months, I was in a...theatre, all by myself, like a child in a private magic show," she wrote. "But for the first time ever, a story seemed lesser impossible than our reality," Nimrat added.

column3: NEXA gets India’s 1st multi-financier online car finance: Maruti Suzuki
column4: Maruti Suzuki India Limited has announced the launch of multi-financier 'Smart Finance' service for NEXA customers across 30 cities. With this, it has become India's 1st car OEM to offer online, end-to-end car finance services, Maruti Suzuki mentioned. The platform offers one-stop convenience with option to compare loan offerings from multiple financiers, enabling customers to make an informed choice.

column3: Own a car without buying it : Revv Subscriptions
column4: You can now drive a new car every month as Revv provides the option to subscribe to your favourite car for 1-36 months with ₹0 down payment, ₹0 road tax and without the hassle of maintenance and service. The car will be sanitized and delivered to your doorstep ensuring complete safety for you and your loved ones.

column3: Elon Musk only $20 billion away from becoming the world's richest person
column4: Tesla CEO Elon Musk is now only $20 billion away from becoming the world's richest person overtaking Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, according to Bloomberg. The 49-year-old's net worth jumped almost $9 billion to $167.3 billion on Friday as Tesla shares soared. He has added nearly $140 billion this year, which is more than the entire net worth of Bill Gates.

column3: Auto industry lost ₹2,300cr a day in lockdown: Parliamentary panel
column4: The automotive industry suffered ₹2,300 crore loss per day during the COVID-19 lockdown, according to a parliamentary panel report submitted to Rajya Sabha Chairman M Venkaiah Naidu. The sector witnessed an estimated job loss of about 3.45 lakh, the report said. All major original equipment manufacturers (OEM) cut down their production by 18-20% due to low demand, it added.

column3: Apple moves self-driving car unit under exec who oversees Siri: Report
column4: Apple has moved its self-driving car unit under the leadership of John Giannandrea, Senior Vice President of Machine Learning and AI Strategy, who also oversees the development of Apple's virtual assistant Siri, Bloomberg reported. Apple began working on its autonomous car project, known as Titan, in 2014. CEO Tim Cook in 2017 called autonomous systems "mother of all AI projects".

column3: Apple CFO, Apple's ex-design chief candidates for Ferrari CEO: Report
column4: Apple CFO Luca Maestri and former Chief Design Officer Jony Ive are reportedly candidates to be Ferrari's next CEO, Reuters reported. Ferrari CEO Louis Camilleri announced his retirement earlier due to "personal reasons". Former Vodafone CEO Vittorio Colao was allegedly in the running for the position too, but Reuters said a source close to Colao has called the claim "groundless".

column3: General Motors to not acquire 11% stake in Nikola
column4: General Motors (GM) and Nikola on Monday announced a reworked deal that replaced their previous agreement under which GM would acquire 11% equity stake in the startup and produce the proposed electric pickup Badger. The companies have instead signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding which is subject to negotiation. Nikola was previously accused of fraud by a short seller.

column3: Tesla teams to visit Indonesia to discuss investment in EV components
column4: Tesla will send delegations to Indonesia next month to discuss potential investment in a supply chain for its electric vehicles. Government officials and Tesla CEO Elon Musk have discussed investment opportunities in Indonesia over a call. Indonesia earlier pointed out it has the "biggest" nickel reserves. Musk plans to offer a "giant contract for a long period of time".

column3: US startup claims to have made 1st 'no charging' solar EV
column4: US-based Aptera Motors has introduced the "first solar electric vehicle" that requires "no charging" for most daily use and has a range of up to over 1,600 kilometres per full charge. Every Aptera is designed to harvest enough sunlight to travel over 17,702 kilometres per year in most regions. Liquid-cooled electric motors propel Aptera from 0-100 kilometres/hour in 3.5 seconds.

column3: Tesla asked to give ₹1 cr to used car buyer for hiding damage in China
column4: Tesla was ordered by a Chinese court to pay over ₹1 crore to the buyer of a used Model S car after concluding it concealed structural damage on the vehicle it sold on its official website. It was reportedly discovered part of the vehicle had been cut and welded back together. Tesla will appeal the ruling to a higher court.

column3: Baidu becomes 1st to get fully driverless road tests permit in Beijing
column4: Baidu has become the first to receive permits by the Beijing transportation authorities for five of its vehicles to conduct fully driverless road tests. It plans to remove safety drivers from test vehicles after gradually reducing human intervention. However, a remote safety operator will still be able to take control in an emergency via Baidu's 5G Remote Driving Service.

column3: Tesla reveals women comprise 17% of its total US leadership roles
column4: Tesla revealed in its first-ever US diversity report that women comprise 17% of the company's leadership roles and 21% of the overall workforce. It added that Black people make up 4% of its US leadership roles and 10% of its total workforce. "While women are historically underrepresented...we recognise we have work to do in this area," Tesla said.

column3: Battery-operated bikes to be included in Delhi's EV policy: Report
column4: Delhi's EV policy is being revised to include a segment on battery-operated bicycles and tricycles, HT reported. The government has drafted a proposal to offer monetary incentives on their purchase. The proposed revision includes cycles both in the passenger and cargo categories. In case of individual buyers, purchase incentive will be 25% of the MRP with a cap of ₹5,000.

column3: Honda recalls 737,000 Accord, Insight cars in US over software flaw
column4: Honda is recalling 737,000 Accord gas and hybrid cars from 2018 to 2020 and Insight hybrid cars from 2019 to 2020 after discovering a glitch in its software. The programming flaw in its control computer can cause the rear camera, turn signals and windshield wipers to malfunction. The move comes as part of a larger recall of 1.79-million cars worldwide.

column3: Musk asks Tesla staff to push output to max possible through Dec: Report
column4: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has sent an email to workers encouraging them to push output to the maximum possible through December, Bloomberg reported. "We are fortunate to have the high-class problem of demand being quite a bit higher than production this quarter," the report quoted Musk. The company has a target of delivering 5 lakh cars this year.

column3: Amazon's Zoox unveils autonomous EV that can travel both ways
column4: Amazon-owned self-driving car platform Zoox has unveiled a fully autonomous electric vehicle with no steering wheel which can travel in either direction. Equipped with two battery packs, the four-seater robotaxi can run for 16 hours on a single charge and can attain a maximum speed of 120 kmph. CEO Aicha Evans said Zoox plans on launching an app-based ride-hailing service.

column3: Tesla to shut down production of Model S, X for 18 days: Report
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla will shut down the production of its high-end Model S and Model X electric vehicles from December 24 to January 11 in Fremont, California, CNBC reported. Employees will be given a full week's pay along with few paid holidays. Deliveries of these models amounted to only 11% of total vehicle deliveries during Tesla's third quarter of 2020.

column3: Delhi govt launches forum to discuss electric vehicle policy
column4: Delhi government on Friday launched the 'Delhi EV Forum', a common platform for multiple stakeholders to hold discussions on the government's electric vehicle (EV) policy. "Delhi EV Forum will be the first such forum in India...The first meeting will be held virtually on December 18," Delhi DDC Vice Chairperson said. The policy's objective is to combat air pollution in Delhi.

column3: Tesla would consider buying a legacy automaker on friendly terms: Musk
column4: Tesla would consider leveraging the company's $554 billion market capitalisation to buy a legacy automaker, CEO Elon Musk said in an interview with Axel Springer. "We're definitely not going to launch a hostile takeover," Musk said. "If somebody said, 'Hey, we think it would be a good idea to merge with Tesla,' we certainly could have that conversation," he added.

column3: Fiat Chrysler to invest $150 mn to set up digital hub in Hyderabad
column4: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles (FCA) has said it will invest $150 million to set up a global digital hub in Hyderabad. The investment will help create nearly 1,000 jobs by the end of 2021. "One of the key objectives...is to digitalise every aspect of FCA's automotive operations globally and within India," Mamatha Chamarthi, CIO for North America and Asia-Pacific region, said.

column3: Volkswagen CEO reveals they began 'Mission T' to catch up with Tesla
column4: Volkswagen CEO Herbert Diess, in a blog post, revealed he organised a three-day workshop nicknamed 'Mission T' to discuss how they could "catch up with Tesla". He added that they brought 31 senior executives from Volkswagen, Audi and Porsche together amid the COVID-19 pandemic to discuss how they could further their Project Artemis to take on Tesla.

column3: Workers of Toyota unit near B'luru to continue strike over workload
column4: Factory workers at Toyota Kirloskar Private Limited's Bidadi unit, located near Bengaluru, announced that they will continue their ongoing strike over increased workload, among other concerns. They said that they don't get time to drink water or use the washroom. The unit has been in a lockout since November 10, after 41 workers were suspended for allegedly questioning the management.

column3: Tesla to raise $5 billion as market cap crosses $600 billion
column4: Elon Musk-led Tesla on Tuesday announced that it will be raising $5 billion, marking its second capital raise in the last three months. The additional shares will be sold "from time to time" and "at-the-market" prices. Its shares are up nearly 670% this year with its market capitalisation crossing $600 billion. Tesla will join S&P 500 index later this month.

column3: Mahindra's Korean unit SsangYong defaults on $55 million loan
column4: Automaker Mahindra & Mahindra's South Korean unit SsangYong Motor Company has defaulted on loan repayment of about $55 million. Around $27.5 million was owed to Bank of America, $18.3 million to JP Morgan Chase and $9.1 million to BNP Paribas on December 14. Mahindra has been looking for a buyer for all or most of its 75% stake since June.

column3: ISRO successfully launches India's 42nd communication satellite CMS-01
column4: The ISRO on Thursday successfully launched India's 42nd communication satellite from Satish Dhawan Space Centre (SDSC) SHAR, Sriharikota. The PSLV-C50 launch vehicle put the communication satellite CMS-01 in orbit, that will provide coverage for disaster management and satellite internet connection. It's the first one in a new series of communication satellites after the INSAT and the GSAT series.

column3: Indian-American Raja Chari selected by NASA to fly to ISS on SpaceX mission
column4: Indian-American astronaut Raja Chari has been selected by NASA alongside two other astronauts to fly to the International Space Station (ISS) on SpaceX Crew-3 mission in 2021. It'll be the first spaceflight for Chari and Matthias Maurer, and the third for NASA astronaut Tom Marshburn. Raja Chari is the only Indian-American among 18 astronauts selected for NASA's Moon mission.

column3: Pics of 2020's last solar eclipse seen in parts of the world surface online
column4: Pictures of the last solar eclipse of 2020, witnessed on December 14, have surfaced online. The total solar eclipse was visible for people living in parts of Chile and Argentina. In some parts of South America, south-west Africa and Antarctica, people witnessed a partial solar eclipse. The total solar eclipse was not visible from India.

column3: 30,000 tremors hit Antarctica in 3 months: Scientists
column4: More than 30,000 tremors have rocked Antarctica since the end of August, scientists at University of Chile said. The small earthquakes were detected in Bransfield Strait, an ocean channel between South Shetland Islands and Antarctic Peninsula. Several tectonic plates and microplates meet near the strait, leading to frequent rumbling, but the past three months have been unusual, scientists said.

column3: Kangaroos can ask humans for help with their gaze: Study
column4: Kangaroos can learn to communicate with humans, a behaviour that was previously thought to be reserved for domesticated animals like dogs, by using their gaze to "point" and ask for help, a study revealed. It involved 11 kangaroos that lived in captivity. Ten of the 11 kangaroos gazed at researchers when they were unable to open a box with food.

column3: Japan finds pieces of asteroid inside space capsule that returned to Earth
column4: The Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency has found pieces of an asteroid inside a space capsule delivered by the Hayabusa2 space probe. The capsule was recovered in Australia on December 6, following its journey through space. The Japanese probe collected surface dust last year from the asteroid Ryugu, around 300 million kilometres away, during two phases of its six-year mission.

column3: NASA shares images of supermassive black holes merging
column4: NASA has shared images of two supermassive black holes in Galaxy NGC 6240 which are in the process of merging. "Seen as the bright dots near the center of this image, the black holes are just 3,000 light years apart," it said. "Eventually they will drift together, forming a larger black hole millions of years from now," NASA added.

column3: 'World's ugliest orchid' featured in Kew's list of 2020's top 10 discoveries
column4: Gastrodia agnicellus, nicknamed the 'ugliest orchid in the world', has featured in Kew's list of the top 10 discoveries of the year. The orchid depends on fungi for nutrition and has no leaves or any other photosynthetic tissue. As many as 156 plant and fungal species were named by Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew, and partners worldwide in 2020.

column3: Flies turn into 'zombies' when infected by new fungi species, scientists discover
column4: Scientists in Denmark have discovered two new fungi species that 'zombify' flies and eject spores out of a large hole in the insect's abdomen "like small rockets". The fungi bore holes in the host but keep it alive with an amphetamine-like substance. The flies then buzz around for days, sprinkling more spores on other victims.

column3: Videos of Geminids meteor shower surface online
column4: Videos of the Geminids meteor shower, recognised as the best annual meteor shower a stargazer can see, have surfaced online. According to NASA, the Geminids travel 78,000 mph (35 km/s). The parent of the Geminids is 3200 Phaethon, which is arguably considered to be either an asteroid or an extinct comet, NASA said.

column3: NASA shares pic of Himalayan mountains, Delhi's city lights captured from space
column4: NASA took to Instagram to share a picture of snow-covered Himalayan mountains and Delhi's city lights captured from space. "The bright city lights of New Delhi, India, and Lahore, Pakistan, are...visible below the faint, orange airglow of atmospheric particles reacting to solar radiation," NASA wrote. Reacting to the picture, a user wrote, "This is so beautiful."

column3: Delhi startup builds tech to do COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 cr samples per week
column4: Delhi-based IT startup Thalamus Irwine claims to have developed an artificial intelligence and IoT-based solution that can complete a COVID-19 serosurvey of 1 crore samples in one week. It has also partnered with state-run ITI to host its data. Serosurveys can help track the geographic spread of the virus by analysing antibodies in blood samples.

column3: 1st known case of COVID-19 in non-captive wild mink found in US
column4: The first known case of COVID-19 in a non-captive wild mink has been confirmed, according to an alert issued by the US Department of Agriculture. The wild mink tested positive around an infected mink farm in Utah. The strain of the virus in the wild mink is "indistinguishable" from that in infected mink on farms around the state.

column3: Scientists digitally rebuild dinosaur's brain, learn about its diet
column4: The University of Bristol's scientists have "rebuilt" the brain of a Thecodontosaurus, that roamed England some 205 million years ago, using advanced imaging and 3D modelling techniques. They said unlike its plant-eating relatives, Thecodontosaurus may have eaten meat and could have walked on two legs. Experts also reconstructed its inner ears and estimated that it had a high hearing frequency.

column3: Blue Origin receives NASA approval to launch future uncrewed missions
column4: Amazon Founder Jeff Bezos-owned Blue Origin has received approval from NASA to launch future unmanned scientific and exploration missions aboard its reusable New Glenn launch vehicle. Under the contract, Blue Origin will be able to compete for national security launch contracts. The New Glenn booster is not expected to make its first flight until 2021.

column3: ISRO's next PSLV launch to carry spacetech startup Pixxel satellite
column4: ISRO has announced that the next PSLV-C51 launch will carry the first satellite by spacetech startup Pixxel India, 'Anand', which is an earth observation satellite, in early 2021. Along with Anand, a satellite by Space Kidz India and another by a consortium of universities will be launched. The primary payload of PSLV-C51 will be a Brazilian earth observation satellite 'Amazonia'.

column3: India to soon be manufacturing hub of space assets: PM Modi to space industry
column4: Prime Minister Narendra Modi in his interaction with the space sector's key industries, startups and academia expressed that India will soon become a manufacturing hub of space assets. He also assured participants that they will be co-passengers with ISRO in this age of space research. He added that private investment in the sector will lead to creation of hi-tech jobs.

column3: Bacteria can travel between continents via dust, impact climate: Study
column4: A study by scientists, including those from the University of Granada, revealed bacteria can travel between continents "hidden" in atmospheric dust. These microbes may not only affect human and animal health but also impact climate and ecosystems. Their transport occurs via atmospheric particles called iberulites that humans can inhale. These aerosols act like a "launch vehicle" for bacteria.

column3: Superhighway system to travel via Solar System faster discovered: Scientists
column4: UC San Diego revealed researchers have discovered a new "superhighway" network to travel through the Solar System much faster. Such routes can drive comets and asteroids near Jupiter to Neptune in less than 10 years. Scientists found the routes by computing how "millions" of Solar System orbits fit within already-known space manifolds.

column3: SL records 2nd-highest human deaths due to conflict with elephant: Report
column4: Sri Lanka has recorded the second-highest human deaths due to the human-elephant conflict in the world after India, Daily News reported. Sri Lanka's COPA revealed the number of human deaths has increased from an average of 85 humans to 122 per year in the past 12 months in Sri Lanka. However, it has recorded the highest number of elephant deaths.

column3: China to open world's largest radio telescope to int'l scientists
column4: China will open the world's largest radio telescope for use by foreign astronomers. The Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical radio Telescope (FAST) has a diameter of half a kilometre and a receiving area equivalent to about 30 football fields. China has said it will accept requests in 2021 from foreign scientists wishing to carry out measurements.

column3: Chinese spacecraft brings 1st lunar samples in over 40 years
column4: China's Chang'e-5 probe successfully landed in the northern Chinese region, bringing back the first lunar rocks and soil retrieved by any country in over 40 years. China is now the third country to have retrieved lunar samples. It will be sharing a portion of the lunar soil with other nations and organisations based on international cooperation conventions.

column3: 'Forever chemicals' used in outdoor gear found in snow on Mt Everest: Study
column4: "Forever chemicals" used in water-repellent outdoor gear have been found in snow near Mount Everest's summit, University of Maine reported. A research assistant professor at the university said these human-made PFAS could eventually pose a risk for residents who drink the water. This marks the first time that Everest snow and meltwater has been analysed for PFAS, the professor said.

column3: US Space Force personnel will be called 'Guardians': Vice Prez
column4: The members of the US Space Force will be called "Guardians", Vice President Mike Pence announced at an event celebrating Space Force's first anniversary. "The name Guardians connects our proud heritage and culture to the important mission we execute 24/7, protecting the people and interest of the US and its allies," the Space Force tweeted.

column3: Corals from Aus' 'Coral IVF' trial survive bleaching, on track to reproduce
column4: Coral populations from Australia's first "Coral IVF" trial on the Great Barrier Reef in 2016 have survived bleaching events and are on track to reproduce next year. Scientists said the larvae restoration technique worked just as they predicted and large corals can grow from tiny microscopic larvae within few years. The technique was first used just off Heron Island.
